debateinfo.title: MINISTER FOR REGIONAL SERVICES, TERRITORIES AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Werriwa from moving the fol-lowing motion: That this House compels the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government to give a full explan-ation to the House of:

(a) the circumstances under which he sought to influence proceedings in a South Australian court con-cerning his son by an approach to the Minister for Police in that State on his ministerial letterhead;

(b) how that action is inconsistent with the Prime Minister's Code of Ministerial Con-duct which reads that “it is important that ministers and parliamentary secretaries avoid giving any appearance of using pub-lic office for private purposes”; and
(c) how the Minister has provided misleading state-ments to the House about his follow-up letters and represent-ations to the South Aust-ralian Minister for Police.
The government that gave us the dirty deal for Stan Howard has now given us the dirty intervention for Michael Tuckey.
Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (9.02 a.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the Member be not further heard.

speech.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Speaker, where is Wilson? Where is the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government? He should come into this House—
—For the information of the member for Corio, I made a presumption that he was seconding the motion.

interjection.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (9.10 a.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the Member be not further heard.

interjection.para: Question put.

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Latham's) be agreed to.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —by leave—Mr Speaker, yesterday in answer to a question from the member for Corio, I advised the House in a matter relating to my son, who does not reside in my electorate, that I had made a constituent inquiry. Any representations that I make on behalf of others, wherever they reside, I have always treated as a constituent matter to differentiate it from official business. However, I wish to advise the House that if my words yesterday were construed as indicating my son is an elector in the seat of O'Connor, I wish to correct the record: he is not a voter in the electorate of O'Connor.

speech.para: The communications referred to yesterday were also on ministerial letterhead instead of O'Connor electorate letterhead. This was a mistake that was not intended to exert additional influence. However, I apologise to the House for this action. The additional letters I wrote related simply to a matter of natural justice and were not intended by me to do anything other than to make that point. I sought no personal gain in this matter. I would not have written such a letter if the offence were one such as speeding, but considering there are no logbook requirements in WA I considered that such an issue should be considered by the minister.

Mr Speaker, the issue of whether or not a member of parliament makes a representation on behalf of one of their children when they clearly identify that in their correspondence is, in my way, not an improper act. I think I have an entitlement, as we all have, to make a proper representation in that matter. I do apologise to the House that I made it on the ministerial letterhead.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to move a motion that the House take note of the statement.
—I wish to clarify this. For the House's information the Clerk has pointed out that, while leave has been granted to the member for Werriwa, in fact we do not have a statement in the sense—

—I am attempting to facilitate the House. I am merely seeking to ensure that what we do, as pointed out by the member for Brand, follows the standing orders. If leave were offered for the member for Werriwa to make a statement, that would assist.
—Mr Speaker, if the member for Werriwa wishes to make a brief statement, I think the House should accommodate him.
—When the Leader of the House is attempting to facilitate the House, it ought to be recognised. Leave has been granted. The member for Werriwa has the call.
—I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the statement.

speech.para: It is very important to do so because it is difficult to believe that the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government can, in fact, be believed on this matter. It would be extraordinary for a member in this House to claim that a constituent is someone who lives outside their constituency. This is one of the basic rules of a democracy: where we have a representative system in the parliament we each have a constituency and the people who live within our constituency are our constituents. So there is no doubt that the minister for regional services tried to mislead the police minister in South Australia. On 25 September last year he wrote:

quote.para: While I write this letter in the normal context of a constituent matter—

speech.para: I repeat `the normal context of a constituent matter'—that is, someone who lives in his constituency. He is not saying it is an abnormal matter, or someone living outside the constituency—

quote.para: it is necessary I identify the person involved as my son.

speech.para: Any reasonable person at that point would think that the minister is saying to the police minister in South Australia, `I am making a representation on behalf of my son and I want you to believe my son lives in my electorate.' That is what the minister for regional services was trying to convey to Mr Conlan on 25 September. He asked for the infringement—the breach of the law—to be reconsidered. He then followed it up with a letter on 11 November 2002, saying that he had written to raise a constituent matter regarding the issuance of an infringement notice.

Again, there is no attempt to point out the fact that the minister's son lived in the electorate of Canning rather than the electorate of O'Connor. He is again trying to mislead the Minister for Police in South Australia by saying `this is a constituent matter'. He goes on to refer to constituent correspondence and to `my constituent' in the letter of 11 November—he again refers to his `constituent'. There is no doubt that the minister for regional services was trying to mislead the Minister for Police in South Australia with his extraordinary intervention in this matter. Then we had the minister standing up in the parliament yesterday and saying that it was a constituent inquiry. This is a misleading of the House. The minister, having misled the South Australian police minister, is trying to convince the House of Representatives that someone who lives in the electorate of Canning is in fact a constituent of his.

talk.start.para: —It was Swan!
—That is the problem. It was a constituent inquiry for someone who lives outside his electorate.

speech.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (9.26 a.m.)—Mr Speaker, I think the government has extended a great deal of leniency to the member for Werriwa. I move:

motion.para: That the Member be not further heard.

speech.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: —I second the motion and—

—The member for Corio will resume his seat. Let me explain to the member for Corio that there is no motion. For his information, I will indicate precisely what happened. The Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government came into the House and made a statement. The Manager of Opposition Business was granted leave to make a statement. There can be no motion before the House without a suspension of standing orders, and the House had already resolved that there would not be a suspension of standing orders.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am not trying to extend this particular matter but to clarify it for future circumstances. Are you saying that if a member seeks leave to move a motion, and it is granted, he is not then authorised to move that motion?
—No, I am not. The member for Fraser is, of course, welcome to check the Hansard. Leave was granted to make a statement.
—No—
—I am sorry. Leave was granted to make a statement.
—I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Werriwa moving the following motion: That this House notes:

(1) the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government's in-adequate explanation about why he mis-led the South Australian Mini-ster for Police and the House of Representatives regarding the fact that his son was not one of his constituents; and
(2) the Minister's failure in his statement to address his misleading of the House on his follow-up action and intervention with the South Australian Minister for Police.
This is a very important suspension motion, because it goes to the heart of the minister's misleading.
Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (9.36 a.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the Member be not further heard.

speech.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to speak on the motion. This is a very weak explanation that has been made to the House.

speech.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (9.42 a.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the Member be not further heard.

speech.para: Question put.

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Latham's) be agreed to.

debateinfo.title: TELSTRA (TRANSITION TO FULL PRIVATE OWNERSHIP) BILL 2003

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. The purpose of this bill is to remove the restriction in the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 that requires the Commonwealth to retain 50.1 per cent of equity in Telstra Corporation Ltd—Telstra—thus enabling its full sale. The bill includes other provisions, such as a requirement for regular and independent reviews of regional telecommunication services. I will be addres-sing some of these proposed changes and also raising some items which I believe this bill could have and should have included.

speech.para: I agree with the member for Hotham that this will be one of the most important debates that will take place in this parliament this year. I believe that every Australian, no matter what they earn or where they live, should have access to a phone, a fax and an Internet connection. Further, I believe that the Australian public should be able to have confidence that this access will be continuous and consistent.

Telstra is a national icon and the Australian people do not want Telstra sold. This is more than just a debate; it is a test as to whether the government is prepared to listen to the people or will continue to arrogantly ignore them. It is a debate about what is best for Telstra: to be publicly or privately owned. In fact, does it matter who owns it? If we are to believe those opposite then ownership does not matter. They believe that, no matter who owns Telstra, through regulation and government handouts the same outcomes can be achieved more efficiently than government ownership delivers.

Of course this is just nonsense. The reality is that a majority publicly owned Telstra is the best means to deliver the latest in accessible and affordable telecommunications services to all Australians, regardless of where they live. I am aware that the best, most efficient service is not being delivered at the moment. But what I do know is that, if it cannot be delivered under a publicly owned Telstra, it will never be delivered if Telstra becomes privately owned.

As was pointed out the other day by the member for Hotham, this government has repeatedly promised Australians that it will not sell Telstra until it is fully satisfied that arrangements are in place to deliver adequate services to all Australians and maintain the improvements to existing services. If that is the test, it is not yet met. Australians know, having witnessed the Besley and Estens inquiries' whitewash on regional telecommunications services, that the government is deluding itself that it can be so fully satisfied.

The Howard government still has not responded to the Estens report into regional telecommunications—more than six months after the report was delivered. Given recent comments by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, we now know that the government has no intention of ensuring regional telecommunications improvements are guaranteed into the future. Whilst we, Labor, criticised the Estens report for glossing over many of the serious problems in regional telecommunications, such as poor mobile telephone coverage, inadequate broadband access, faulty phone networks and Internet line drop-out, there were some recommendations, like guaranteed minimum Internet speeds, fixing payphones and fixing pair gain problems, that we support. However, the government has not done anything about instigating these recommendations. As a result, many regional Australians are still suffering from slow Internet speeds.

Telecommunications services are essential, especially the telephone. We all depend on our telephones to keep in touch with family and friends and we need them for work and for safety. We must not forget that Telstra is a public utility that delivers an essential service to all Australians. As it is an important utility and a large monopoly, it is vital that this service not be privatised. If a monopoly of this size were privatised, the government would find it too powerful to regulate. A company of this size would be looking after the needs of its major shareholders, not necessarily its less lucrative customers. This would mean that, ultimately, people in the bush would suffer.

The government really has no intention of improving regional telecommunications services; its agenda is to sell Telstra. This will of course only make matters worse. On 5 November 2001 the Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... we believe that people in the bush are entitled to the sort of services from Telstra as their city counterparts.

speech.para: So what happened to that belief? Hundreds of regional Australians wrote to the Estens committee complaining of poor regional tele-communications services, poor mobile phone coverage, faulty telephone lines, poor broadband coverage and inadequate dial-up, Internet data speeds and constant Internet line drop-out. The efficient picture of regional telecommunications services painted by the Estens inquiry did not reflect what was said by the hundreds of Australians who felt strongly enough about the appalling service to put it into submissions. I am referring to those people who took the time to respond to the inquiry in the belief that this inquiry would help towards improving services for them. In fact, the inquiry was a contradiction of the hundreds of submissions it received.

We do not really need to look at the bush to see how inefficient telecommunications services are. In my central city electorate of Swan in Perth, the Belmont Forum Shopping Centre—a major regional centre not 20 kilometres from the Perth CBD, right next door to the Perth international and domestic airports—cannot get broadband. So if we cannot get broadband in major shopping centres in inner city Perth, what hope is there for people in remote and regional areas of Australia?

In March this year the member for Hasluck posed a number of questions to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts in relation to Internet, broadband and ADSL services in her electorate. The response to her question was that ADSL is limited to approximately 86 per cent of people with a telephone service in her electorate. Hasluck is also a metropolitan seat in Perth. In response to the member's questions, the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts replied that the reason that 14 per cent of her electorate cannot access ADSL services is due mainly to certain access line electronics and distance limit factors. That is the position in Perth.

So is this just a WA problem? Apparently not, because the member for Hotham in his speech last week said that he had discovered first-hand on recent trips north that, in towns and cities in Queensland, three out of 10 faults reported this year were not repaired within the one day required by law. Notwithstanding these stories, this government would have the Australian public believe that telecommunications services are up to scratch. Last Friday, 15 August, the West Australian newspaper ran a headline that read `Telstra backs ADSL service'. The story began:

quote.para: TELSTRA has defended its roll-out of the high-speed internet service, broadband, after criticism by Opposition communications spokesman Lindsay Tanner yesterday.

speech.para: Mr Tanner had told the House of Representatives that the City of Wanneroo—a northern suburb of Perth—had complained to him that Telstra refused to provide ADSL broadband to exchanges in the area. The Mayor of the City of Wanneroo had complained that the city's inadequate ADSL broadband services restricted the ability to attract, retain and meet business needs. Telstra's response was that ADSL services were available from nine of the 11 exchanges. But the City of Wanneroo say that the Wanneroo Business Association had lobbied Telstra for improved broadband but to no avail.

I am sure we all recall what happened with the banks when it came to country people. Yes, the banks left town and left in the lurch the ordinary hardworking Australians who had supported them. The banks took their services and moved them to places that were cost-effective to the banks—taking away banking services and jobs from rural communities. I think it is fair to say that banks are becoming a bit of a novelty in country towns. It will not be long before country children start to ask: `What is a bank? Where do we find one? What do they do? We haven't seen a bank for years.' One thing is sure: if Telstra is sold, it will follow the banks out of regional Australia. It will use the same economic arguments—with the same costs to rural Australians, including loss of jobs.

Recently in a small rural community north of Perth farmers were wanting to have mobile phone coverage improved, particularly during times of seeding and harvest, so that they could dial up if there were any problems or if they needed to order parts or make arrangements and also for safety reasons. Unfortunately, Telstra said to the local council that was representing the farmers, `We can put in a mobile phone tower, but you've got to come up with $150,000-odd to put the tower in yourself.' Of course, the local community did not have the money to do that and those farmers still do not have access to mobile telephones. I believe that that is absolutely not on. We need to be providing services to the bush. The standard of regional telecommunications, which is less than perfect, will only get worse—not better—if the sale of Telstra is allowed to go through.

One thing we can all be certain of is that a reassurance from Mr Howard, given his recent track record, does not augur well for the Australian people, particularly those who live in country Australia. The Prime Minister went to the last election with a promise that there would be no sale of Telstra until services improved. We know of course that we cannot believe all that Mr Howard tells us. Let us take a look at his recent track record in relation to promises and reassurances. This is the Prime Minister who said he would never ever introduce a GST. There was also a slight question about children overboard. Then there was the assistance given to Stan Howard's company but not others—I nearly forgot about that! More recently there was a slight furphy over weapons of mass destruction, which we are still trying to find. Then there was the issue of ethanol and whether or not certain meetings took place. A promise was made prior to the last election not to sell Telstra until services were improved. Notwithstanding that promise, the Prime Minister intends to persist with the sale of Telstra. Unfortunately, our Prime Minister is a serial offender with respect to telling porky pies.

talk.start.para: (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—The honourable member should be very careful about the form of language he is using.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We on this side of the House will oppose the sale of Telstra. The government will sell Telstra regardless of the standard of regional telecommunications and despite promising not to do so. Despite the hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars being poured into the company by the government through the social bonus spending, we have already seen Telstra's investment in its network fall from $4.7 billion in 1999-2000 to an estimated $3.2 billion in 2002-03. Full-time staff numbers have fallen from 50,700 to an estimated 37,600 over the same period. Many of those employees who lost their jobs were involved directly in customer service and network maintenance activities in regional Australia. That is happening when Telstra is still 51 per cent owned by the government. Imagine what will happen if all of it is sold.

speech.para: Under the Howard government Australia is already getting a taste of how Telstra will behave if it is allowed to be fully privatised. This government is obsessed with privatisation, and it has Telstra firmly in its sights. As soon as Telstra is sold, the political incentive to impose tough regulations on Telstra's service delivery will be gone. This type of regulation can quickly become grossly inefficient. With privatisation there will be no more Telstra billions to spend on improving the network. What will that mean to Australia? It can only mean one thing: there will be no money to fund future telecommunications services without increasing taxes. So the decision we have to make is: do we want inferior services or are we happy to pay higher taxes? These are not the kinds of decisions that Australians should be asked to make on the basis of this government's proposals. Labor sees telecommunications services as essential services, built around a fixed-line network which is largely a natural monopoly. In a huge country with a small and very unevenly distributed population, government ownership of the dominant telecommunications carrier remains critical.

The retention of Telstra in majority public ownership returns a dividend to taxpayers from what is a large enterprise. Because of the Howard government's overwhelming desire to privatise, Telstra is failing to fulfil its broader obligations of national development and social inclusion. To make matters worse—if that is possible—Telstra is also reducing investment in the network and charging you more just to own a phone. The cost of line rentals has more than doubled, from $11.65 a month just a few years ago to as much as $23.50 to $26.50 a month today. Telstra calls these increased costs `rebalancing'. What I see is Telstra pocketing hundreds of millions of dollars in extra revenue because of the government's flawed price control regime. I have elderly pensioners in my electorate, many of whom are frail and have difficulty moving outside their units. They are people who really need a phone. Yet my office is constantly contacted by such people advising me that they cannot afford to have a phone anymore. It angers me that we are in a situation where the people who really need these services are being priced out of the market.

The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 provides for the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts or the Australian Communications Authority to make licence conditions requiring Telstra to maintain a local presence in regional, rural and remote parts of Australia. Whilst this is great in theory—it looks good in writing and is indeed an extremely important aspect of this bill—there is no definition in the legislation as to what this means and no guarantee that the presence will in fact be guaranteed. The sale of Telstra is one of the most important decisions facing Australia. It is critically important that all the facts are presented so that an informed decision takes place and Australian taxpayers' interests are protected. I am very concerned when a government backbencher, the member for Hume, is reported as saying that the constituents of his country electorate are dismayed at service standards and that he may abstain from voting when the House of Representatives votes on the final sale bill.

It is my belief that this government will want to sell Telstra regardless of the standard of regional telecommunications. This of course is contrary to what the government was saying when it went to the last election. We saw yet another example of Mr Howard failing to convince the Australian public of his believability last week in relation to the issue of ethanol and whether he had certain meetings. This is a Prime Minister whose words simply cannot be believed. He went to the last election promising that there would not be a sale until services had been improved, but he intends to persist with that sale regardless of that. This government will sell Telstra regardless of its undertaking to do otherwise and regardless of the standard of regional telecommunications. Once Telstra is sold there will be no political incentive to impose tough regulations on Telstra's service delivery and there will be no income to government from Telstra, so there will be no more Telstra billions to spend on improving the network. Without an increase in taxes, there will be no money to fund future telecommunications services. What all this means is that if Telstra is sold then we will have to accept either higher taxes or lower services.

A publicly owned telecommunications service is vital to an equitable society and to our national economic success. The challenge we face is not to privatise Telstra but to keep it in public hands and facilitate more affordable access to the latest telecommunications services for all Australians, wherever they live. That is a goal worth committing to and working towards. That is a goal that I believe we should be committed to. Families must have affordable access to the latest in education, health, government and commercial services no matter where they reside. Telstra as a carrier can, and in many cases does, deliver that access. This affordability will also facilitate the development of industry and subsequent deployment of the latest high-speed education services to children living in remote locations. It can help put services back in places where they have been taken away. More affordable access improves both efficiency and equity and is essential to our opportunity and prosperity.

Small business has identified the cost of telecommunications as its third highest concern; only tax and tax compliance costs concern it more. In today's Australia, when we talk about telecommunications, we are talking about far more than having a telephone or a fax machine; we are talking about having the ability to connect throughout Australia to the World Wide Web to have access to information at our fingertips and the ability to speak and communicate with people throughout the world. As members of parliament, we know how much we rely on that technology to keep in touch with our electorates and families when we are travelling to and from parliament or on parliamentary business. Telecommunication is now about much more than just the standard telephone connection. This debate is narrow to the extreme, focusing merely on: should we or should we not sell Telstra? This is an issue of access and equity, not of point scoring and putting a lump sum in the government's coffers for the short term for what will become a long-term cost to the nation—a cost not only in dollars and cents but also in relation to the more important issues of service, competition and access.

While I am on the issue of costs, I note that the costs of all services—mobile phones, text messages and Internet fees—have gone up. Some schools have had their Internet charge increased by up to 100 per cent. Have these increased charges improved services? Apparently not. As I have pointed out today, the problems in regional and rural Australia still persist.

In recent times Australia has fallen from 13th to 19th in the OECD table of broadband access, and this is due not to the lack of majority ownership but, rather, to the lack of competition which is contributing to these problems. Telstra still occupies 75 per cent of the telecommunications market and earns over 90 per cent of its profits. Privatising Telstra is not going to fix the problem. The full privatisation of Telstra is irresponsible—not just from an access and equity point of view, as I have already outlined, but also from a fiscal point of view. The government falsely inflated the Telstra sale price in the budget papers. This untruth was exposed by Labor through Senate estimates, and the issue about the share price has flowed through since and has been widely canvassed.

I cannot see anything from a budget point of view or the people's point of view that would be of benefit to Australia to commend the further sale of Telstra. As I said at the beginning of this speech, the telephone is a lifeline for all Australians; it is one that allows even the most remote Australians access to family services and information. The basic right to enjoy access to communication is essential. Along with other members of the Labor Party, I oppose the further sale of Telstra.

talk.start.para: —Relin-quishing the government's remaining equity in Telstra is clearly in our national interest. It is in the interests of the Australian public, of Telstra shareholders, of Telstra itself and of the wider telecommunications industry. The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 amends the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 to repeal provisions requiring the Commonwealth to retain 50.1 per cent equity in Telstra. While the political debate over the merits of full private ownership of Telstra has continued unabated, the rationale and benefits from the potential sale of the government's shareholding still hold true. The proposed changes to the ownership of Telstra are not a stand-alone policy; they are, in fact, just one part of a comprehensive and ongoing reform process in telecommunications instituted by this government upon coming to office in 1996.

speech.para: There are many reasons for the government's approach to Telstra; important, however, is the recognition by the government that they are reasons not for reasons' sake but for the significant benefits that will flow to all Australians. Australians both young and old, whether they live in the city or in outer city or country areas, will all benefit from the government's approach. As a result, I want to outline what I believe are just some of the major benefits from the government's decision to introduce this bill.

The first point I want to make is a fundamental point of principle. That principle is that governments do not and should not have a role in the day-to-day management and operation of a business, particularly a business that operates in a highly competitive and dynamic market. The fact is that governments have a series of core competencies, and history has demonstrated time and time again that running and operating a stand-alone corporation is not one of them. Governments are responsible for key challenges that only they can address. Governments must be focused and highly attuned to those challenges and not be distracted by matters that are not within their core capabilities. When looking at the telecommunications industry, experience reveals and the facts prove that our telecommunications system can now be financed and much more effectively run by private enterprise; we just have to look at the benefits that have flowed to consumers in recent years.

The next benefit to all Australians that I would like to touch on is the removal of the burden of debt. Sale of the government's remaining equity in Telstra would provide an excellent opportunity for us—that is, all Australians—to pay off the $32 billion that remains from the $96 billion debt that Labor left the country with. You have to ask: what are the practical benefits of this debt reduction? One benefit so far from this government's prudent economic management is an extra $5 billion each year in interest savings that can now be invested in essential services—essential services such as schools, hospitals, roads, defence and all of the other areas that are important to our country. But the Commonwealth still pays around $3.5 billion each year in interest on Labor's debt. If the remainder of Telstra were sold, it could reduce the Commonwealth's debt position to zero. This would provide at least an additional $3½ billion extra each year for additional resources in the areas of education, health, transport and defence. Our failure to miss the opportunity of retiring the vast majority of Labor's remaining debt will mean leaving that debt as our legacy to be repaid by future generations of Australians.

The proposed sale would bring an end to the current conflict of interest faced by the Commonwealth in its dual role as regulator of the telecommunications industry and majority shareholder of the largest participant in that industry. It seems to me quite obvious why you would want to remove from the regulator, who is responsible for providing competition and consumer safeguards, a direct financial interest in maximising the profits of a participant. The primary reason is that it means that the regulator can focus solely on delivering outcomes that are in the best interests of consumers. It would provide both the regulator and the participant with real independence of action and strategies in achieving their divergent best interests.

The next benefit of the full private ownership of Telstra is that it would bring about the much needed end to the constraints on Telstra from the hybrid ownership arrangements of being part public and part private. Currently, Telstra is unable to realise its full potential as one of Australia's most important and largest companies and is therefore unable to compete effectively in the global telecommunications market. This is largely because Telstra cannot raise equity due to the legislative restraints it faces as a result of the government's ownership. So the question has to be asked: how can Telstra compete in a market when it is treated differently to its competitors, whether they be domestic players or huge international players? Full private ownership would give Telstra the flexibility it needs to raise capital and invest in new areas of revenue and growth, not just for today but for the future and for the benefit of all Australians.

The next benefit would be to remove the current exposure to the volatility of the share market that the taxpayer faces through the government's continuing shareholding in Telstra. Risk over the profit and losses of businesses should be held by those who choose to take it on—that is, the risk should be held by risk-taking private investors who explicitly choose to buy shares in that company. The current situation forces all taxpayers to accept the risk as a result of the government's stake in Telstra. Another reason for selling Telstra is that Telstra's 1.8 million shareholders should not have to suffer the political interference of a majority shareholder with divergent interests. Currently, shareholders face having their shares devalued by the threat or the potential of some governments meddling and making politically motivated decisions.

In this debate it is important to consider the alternative offered by Labor. Given that Labor have themselves considered splitting up Telstra and selling off its best performing assets, what credibility do they have in their promise to keep Telstra in government ownership? You just need to look at their track record on the issue of public ownership to see this. When Labor were last in government they privatised everything that moved. They promised in a share prospectus that they would not sell any more of the Commonwealth Bank and then went ahead and did so. They drew up a detailed proposal to sell 100 per cent of Telstra without telling the Australian public and then tried to get BHP to buy Telstra on the sly. The one thing that Labor's privatisation program distinctly lacked was any requirements about maintaining services—something that is a key feature of this government's policy for Telstra.

What about Labor's track record in telecommunications? It is worth remembering that under Labor there was little competition in telecommunications and no consumer safeguards. As a result, Australians had little choice of phone company, had access to very few services and had their phone installed or fixed only when the telco was good and ready. A further example of the contrast between this government and Labor is on mobile phone services in regional Australia. It may surprise you to know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in the early 1990s Labor signed a contract to close down the perfectly good analog mobile phone network, which would have left people in regional areas with no mobile coverage at all. Thankfully, the Howard government was able to rectify this problem by requiring the roll-out of the new CDMA network that now provides wider coverage and more functions than the analog network did.

As I said earlier, the coalition's record on telecommunications stands in stark contrast to that of Labor. When you look at Labor's `just say no' position on the ownership of Telstra you see that it adds to the long list of obstructionism. It is worth noting some of the many measures they have opposed. They opposed budget savings, tax reform, sustainable PBS and disability support pension systems, ending compulsory trade union fees, unfair dismissal laws, waterfront reform, construction industry reform, education reform, youth wages, cracking down on welfare cheats, national security measures and private health insurance incentives. Labor just oppose everything.

There are many strong reasons why the government should divest itself of its ownership of Telstra. However, in concluding my remarks, I want to outline the real reasons why Labor are opposed to this initiative. At the end of the day, the Labor Party do not care about the ownership structure of Telstra. What they care about are their own political fortunes, and that is very obvious in this debate. There are five key reasons why Labor do not support the Australian community and do not support the government on this bill. The first reason is political motivation. Labor very much understand the benefits that the full private ownership of Telstra will bring to Australia, and that is exactly why they oppose it. If Labor thought it was such a bad policy, they would support the bill. They would enable it to pass and would let the government receive its just desserts. It is for precisely that reason that Labor oppose this policy, because Labor know that the government will be rightly credited for helping to deliver the significant benefits that will flow from this policy.

The second reason is reflected in Labor's alternative policy. If Labor truly feel that having Telstra in public ownership is the best option, if they really feel that the government continuing to own Telstra is best for the Australian people, why have Labor not promised to buy back all of the existing shares if elected? If it is so important to have Telstra in government ownership, why have Labor not promised all of the existing shareholders of Telstra that if they are elected they will buy back all the shares?

talk.start.para: —And nationalise the company.

—Yes. Why have they not promised to do that? It is because they do not believe that at all. It is just one of their increasingly irresponsible acts in their game of political survival. The third reason is the traditional Labor motivation of wanting to appease their union mates. These union mates do not want to see any potential threat to their role in Telstra's work force, so no news is good news. The fourth reason that Labor oppose the proposed sale is that they do not want to see Australia's debt retired. You have to ask yourself why Labor would not want to see Australia's debt retired. The reason is that it is their debt—it is the debt that Labor ran up when they were last in office. Labor do not want people to see the benefit of the gov-ernment's prudent economic manage-ment and debt retirement program.

speech.para: The fifth and final reason is one that I have already briefly noted in my remarks, and that is that Labor oppose everything. They have quite literally become the party of opposition for opposition's sake, not for the benefit of Australia. They make no constructive contribution whatsoever to the national political debate, and the ongoing debate on the future of Telstra's ownership is a prime example of that. The case for this bill is clear, as are the motivations for Labor's opposition—something that is increasingly recognised in the Australian community. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003, which is the government's bill to enable the future sale of Telstra. This legislation empowers the government to privatise the remaining government shareholding of Telstra. It empowers the government to ensure that Telstra becomes a fully privatised company and ceases to have any government ownership. It is a bill I oppose. It is a bill that the majority of the Australian people oppose. The only people in Australia who want Telstra sold are federal members of the Liberal and National parties who want to get their hands on the proceeds of the sale. Also, there are a few corporate executives and consultants who will make substantial profits from the sale. The majority of Australians know that they will not benefit, and they are against this sale.

speech.para: Telecommunications are essential services. They are not a luxury item. They make the difference in many communities in the connection that we feel with our families, with our neighbourhoods, with our friends and with the organisations that we belong to. They make the difference in being connected to our local neighbourhoods, the community, the state and often the world. They are fundamental to people's access to information and knowledge, and they are fundamental to the possibilities that towns, particularly in rural and regional Australia, such as the ones I represent, have of growing into the future.

Labor is the only party that has consistently opposed the sale of Telstra. Labor regional and country members of parliament are the only members who are truly representing the wishes of rural and regional Australia on this issue. Labor regional and country members of parliament are prepared to stand up against the interests of the government on this issue and vote no on the further privatisation of Telstra. National Party members and the handful of Liberal Party members who claim to represent regional and rural Australia have let their constituencies down on this issue. This bill is a product of the failure of rural and regional members of this government to stand up for their constituents. They know what effect a fully privatised Telstra will have on their electorates: services will get worse and prices will rise. They have neither the interest nor the courage to stand up to the Prime Minister and the minister and, in fact, their own leader of the National Party on this issue.

The only National Party MP in the South Australian state parliament, Ms Maywald, knows what the further privatisation of Telstra will mean for Australia. In an interview on the ABC in July, she said she certainly feels that there is a lot of disappointment within the National Party on this issue. In the same interview, the Minister for Trade made the following comments:

quote.para: I know there's been concerns expressed about process, but at the end of the day what do we need? What do our constituents need? Our constituents need better access to the Internet, our constituents need better mobile phone coverage, our constituents need better services from Telstra in terms of repairing damaged lines.

speech.para: The minister is correct in saying that the highest priority for people in our electorates is better access to the Internet, better mobile phone coverage and better services in infrastructure. But he knows, and every member on this side of the House knows, that we are not going to get that with a fully privatised Telstra. Regional Liberal Party members need to stand up and be counted on this issue. When will the members for McEwen, Corangamite, Wannon and Indi, who represent regional and rural areas, answer the one simple question that their electorates want to know: can they guarantee that services will improve under a privatised Telstra? The answer is no.

Many members on the other side of the House sat and debated the privatisation of Telstra in 1996 during the T1 debate. They gave commitments to their electorates that T1 would be it—no further sell-off; services would improve. One regional Liberal member has had the courage to campaign to save Telstra. Alone in this among members of the government is the member for Hume. The member for Hume has had the courage to acknowledge that people in his electorate do not want Telstra sold, and he has stood up and said that. However, it is a lone voice and one the communications minister has gone out of his way to silence.

What the government fails to understand is that not everyone enjoys the level of telecommunications available to the minister in his comfortable suburb of Brighton; not everyone has good mobile phone coverage, broadband availability or even a reliable standard phone service; not everyone has a range of service providers to choose from. In addition, very few Australians get privileged access to Telstra freebies, like plasma television sets. The people in my electorate do not enjoy the same telecommunications services enjoyed by Australians who live in capital cities, and they understand what the full sale of Telstra will mean for them. Not for a moment do they believe that the so-called protections contained in this bill will provide any cover for them.

They know that any improvements in services they have enjoyed have been delivered because of public ownership—because the government continues to have leverage over Telstra and is able to regulate and make sure that those services are provided. Full private ownership would mean only one set of interests would be pursued by Telstra: the interests of its private shareholders, whether they reside here in Australia or overseas. The interests of people in my electorate and other regional electorates would be a long way from the minds of Telstra directors under a fully privatised regime. We already know where the minds of Telstra directors have been over the past few years—wasting scarce taxpayers' money on failed ventures in Hong Kong.

Anyone who thinks that the provisions in the bill would compel Telstra to put the people of Ballarat, Daylesford or Bacchus Marsh ahead of maximising profit is naive and does not understand how monopolies work. The fact is, once freed from the harness of public interest, Telstra would be a giant private monopoly, too powerful for government to control. The government tries to pretend that Telstra does not have a monopoly—that there is pretty strong competition out there in the telecommunications market. Roughly 95 per cent of the profits made in telecommunications today in Australia are made by Telstra. Telstra constitutes over two-thirds of the entire industry. I do not know what the government's definition of a monopoly is, but that sounds pretty close to me. Telstra exerts enormous power in telecommunications and its reach is far and wide. That monopoly power must be constrained because most of it is a natural monopoly, which is one of the traditional bases for public ownership in a system of government.

Last week the Prime Minister told Sky News that we had more or less got things up to scratch in the bush. Australians are no strangers to the Prime Minister's arrogance, but this statement I have to say takes the cake. Despite the fact that Ballarat is a major provincial centre with a raft of higher learning institutions, a burgeoning arts culture, major manufacturing plants and a vibrant and expanding service community and that the major towns in my electorate of Bacchus Marsh, Ballan, Daylesford and others are major growth centres for people wanting to escape from major cities, we are often referred to, quite patronisingly, as `the bush'. I can tell the Prime Minister that most of the services in `the bush' are not `more or less up to scratch'. Over recent months, complaints to my electorate office have included concerns about fixed line rental repair delays, mobile phone black spots, inadequate Internet access and intrusive calls from Telstra offering unwanted services.

I realise the Prime Minister does not talk to ordinary people and I know the government has stopped listening to them, but many people in my electorate are concerned about the impact that the privatisation of Telstra will have on them. Yesterday I was contacted by a constituent who is sight and hearing impaired. She is particularly concerned about the impact that a privatised Telstra will have on people who have specialised access needs. Despite the government's so-called guarantees of service provision, she and I are convinced that letting Telstra off the pretty limited regulatory leash it has at the moment will mean that people like her are well and truly left behind. We have already seen Telstra closing its disability service centres. We have already seen the adverse impact that line rental increases have had on the elderly, people with disabilities and those on fixed incomes. Telstra's response to concerns of access and equity has been to engage consultants to put a better spin on its decision and not to substantially address the concerns raised—sounds a little like it has been giving lessons to the government!

I listened to the member for Page's somewhat interrupted contribution to the debate last night and I fail to understand how he can think in the way that he does. His constituents are not raising the same issues as mine. The member for Page tried to argue that this bill is about protecting the future telecommunications services for the country. Nothing could be further from the truth. Increasingly, when you privatise an essential service the only way that people who live in less densely populated and less profitable areas of this country can get access to services or get improved services is if governments and individual customers pay. And the price that privatised companies charge governments for maintaining and improving infrastructure under those circumstances just keeps going up and up. In Victoria we have seen that with gas and electricity and we have certainly seen it with other services. In country areas when services are privatised, people leave town very quickly. By selling Telstra, the government is creating an enormous millstone for future generations of taxpayers. Telstra has already reduced its capital works budget and sacked thousands of workers who were involved in line maintenance as well as technicians, and the network is in decline. It has been doing this to gear itself up to get the best sale price.

In my electorate, we know what will happen under a fully privatised Telstra. It will be the smaller communities that miss out. Residents in the small town of Blackwood have talked to me about the lack of mobile phone coverage in their areas. Travellers along the Western Highway well know about the mobile phone black hole which you hit just near Bungaree and also near Ballan. CDMA coverage has not been much better. Only 100 metres off the Western Highway coverage drops out yet again. The residents of Blackwood are inconvenienced by the lack of mobile phone coverage and concerned that this service failure will restrict the area's tourism growth. The towns in this area have large proportions of their populations who operate small businesses from their homes. We want to encourage this, but mobile phone coverage and broadband access is critical.

Early last year I conducted a survey in the small town of Blampied, near Daylesford, that has no mobile phone coverage. Despite letters from Telstra stating that they would fix the problem and build a mobile phone tower up to two years ago, nothing has been done. I got over 90 responses from this very small farming community—over 95 per cent were against the further privatisation of Telstra and even more were dissatisfied with the services they received from Telstra in regard to mobile telephone coverage. Perhaps, more importantly, they fear what it will mean during a fire or local emergency. We have seen some improvements in mobile phone coverage in these areas—a mobile phone tower is being built—but this is because the government has paid for it.

What we will see continuously under a privatised Telstra is the government having to pay yet again. Not only will taxpayers be paying for their coverage through the taxes that they pay; they will then have to have specialised government programs to ensure that an essential service such as telecommunications is provided in small rural and regional areas. The government and taxpayers will have to pay for it. At the moment we think that it is Telstra's responsibility to pay to make sure that people have access regardless of where they live.

The issue of broadband access is equally concerning. Access to high speed Internet is limited in many areas of my electorate. The use of old technology in some areas in Ballarat has also meant that access is limited in some of the new housing estates as Telstra struggles to find a cheap solution to fixing the problem it has created by installing old technology. One of the cheaper forms of broadband access is ADSL, but there are some limitations. An exchange must be firstly ADSL enabled and, of the 5,200 exchanges, currently only around 800 are enabled and not many of them are in my electorate. Typically they are not in small country towns either. Even where an exchange is enabled, it can only reach distances of around 3.5 kilometres from an exchange in order to be reliable. It has really not been a particularly reliable service at all.

Telstra obviously offers other types of broadband such as cable, as does Neighbourhood Cable, a private company in my electorate that has invested in rural and regional Australia. Satellite is generally far too expensive for people in my electorate to afford and ISDN, whilst not very expensive, does not have the line speed that many areas require. Broadband in the town of Ballarat is minimal to say the least. In the new housing areas of Lake Gardens and Invermay Park there have been significant problems accessing ADSL. It is taking some time to find a technical solution to the installation of old technology. Ballarat at least has the advantage of having a strong competitor in Neigh-bourhood Cable, which has invested strongly in regional areas.

As the member for Ballarat, I have been critical of the impact of Telstra's changing pricing structure on my constituents—a policy that has seen service costs escalate without compensatory changes in call costs. The decision by Telstra in April this year to increase standard line rentals and dump the 15c local neighbourhood call feature has hit Ballarat families, pensioners and low-income workers hard. The Telstra decision increased the standard line rental by $1.60, on top of a 10 per cent increase last year. Telstra also dropped the neighbourhood call feature, which will see local calls increase to standard rates. This decision will affect many families in my electorate. Those on a pension or on low incomes will be hit hard by the increase in their line rentals. Consumers who have opted for the low-income HomeLine Budget plan will also find that they will be slugged 30c for a local call. Even if Telstra changed its mind and call costs fell for average customers at an equivalent rate to rising service charges, non-average customers would still pay a higher price, because the main service costs are fixed. So, whether a Ballarat resident makes one call a week to their doctor, chemist or friend—and no more—or spends all day and night on the Internet day trading on the international stock markets, the service costs are the same.

Telstra has slashed its work force in preparation for the government's privatisation push, and it is inconceivable that further massive job cuts would not follow the sale. Staff numbers in Telstra have fallen by more than 13,000 over the last four years. These massive job cuts, including jobs from customer service and technical areas, have inevitably led to poorer service. In April this year media reports implied that Telstra was in negotiations with Swedish company Ericsson to potentially outsource thousands of jobs. This comes after the disastrous outsourcing of NDC that saw over 500 workers in Victoria and almost a third of workers in Ballarat either lose their jobs or have their jobs threatened and a disintegration of the telecommunications network. I called on Telstra to concentrate on maintaining and improving its networks in rural and regional Australia, but all it was doing was negotiating with a foreign country to outsource its work force. And as staffing was cut and problems continued with Telstra services in regional Australia, the Prime Minister and the communications minister allowed the saga on plasma televisions provided by Telstra to continue.

Labor will pursue a four-point reform strategy designed to bring Telstra back to its primary role and maximise the benefits of telecommunications competition. The key features of Labor's strategy include that Telstra will be required to intensify its focus on its core responsibilities to the Australian community and reduce its emphasis on foreign and media investments. Telstra will be asked to intensify its focus on the provision of affordable, accessible broadband services to all Australians. The competition regime will be strengthened to require much stricter internal separation of Telstra's wholesale and retail activities, and the minister for communications will be removed from the process of ACCC scrutiny and regulation of accounting separation within Telstra to ensure the process is independent and rigorous. Consumers will be given stronger protection from sharp practices by telecommunications companies, and the price control regime will be made fairer.

A Labor government will bring Telstra back to its primary, core responsibilities. It will be required to operate in a more transparent and accountable way in order to maximise opportunities for genuine competition. It will focus its energies on maintaining its network at a high standard and accelerating the roll-out of broadband services. Telstra will be prevented from continuing to increase line rental fees without returning those increases in lower call costs. Along with all other telecommunications companies, it will be subject to stricter consumer protection regulations to ensure that consumers are not subject to unfair practices.

Labor believes in public ownership of Telstra because telecommunications services are essential services. They are not a luxury item. A privately owned Telstra would be a massive private monopoly too powerful for any future government to effectively regulate. It would focus on the more lucrative markets in the bigger cities—

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—Order! The parliamentary secretary will cease interjecting. The member for Flinders will have an opportunity to speak shortly.

—and neglect the interests of lower income and regional Australians, just as we have seen with the banks. It would use its muscle to squash effective competition and spread its monopoly power into other sectors, like media and information. Under a Labor government Telstra will deliver high-quality telecommunications services for all Australians and decent returns for its shareholders. Telstra will be responsive to the needs of people in my electorate. It will be responsive to the needs of people in Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh, Creswick, Clunes, Haddon, Blampied and Blackwood. It will be responsive to the needs of smaller communities. A privatised Telstra would mean that services would decline in regional and rural Australia, and so I oppose this bill.

—In rising to support the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 I want to start in an unusual place. This morning I had in my office five-year-old Justin Babare from Phillip Island. Justin is a sufferer of juvenile diabetes. He and his mother, Lisa Rogers, visited to discuss research funding. This brought into focus the fact that, at this point in our history as a society, we struggle with the basic proposition that there are scarce resources, which have to be allocated as best as government can manage across a variety of needs. The question is: how can we do so in a way which is most efficient, will benefit the most people and will contribute to national development?

speech.para: If we waste money on an ideological pursuit, that means there is less for core functions of government and society, such as researching issues like juvenile diabetes, promoting and developing national water infrastructure or developing core educational facilities. If we waste our capital and recurrent expenditure by not allowing the market to operate in a way which most efficiently delivers services, then there are costs in every section of society. The story of Justin Babare is the story of limited funds. That is the reality we deal with. As a society today, the things that we can achieve vastly outstrip what was achievable 100 years ago. That is because there are more resources, and those resources have come not from some 19th century notion of capital ownership by government but through a structure which throughout society has encouraged investment by private individuals, with private money going in to create an efficient, effective system.

This brings me to the second interesting point as a beginning to this discussion about the privatisation of Telstra. Last night I spoke on the motion to support Australia's actions in the Solomon Islands. I mentioned that the notion of governance, as opposed to government, is about taking long-term decisions which are not in the short-term political interest but are dedicated to the concept of national development and of building a long-term sustainable and viable country. It is very easy to be political; it is very hard to practise governance. This bill is all about governance. I acknowledge that there are many Australians who do not support the concept and I respect their views. Why would a government do something which is difficult? Why would a government do something which does not win the support of all Australians, which has many who would object to it—particularly within the bush and many within my own electorate of Flinders, whom I acknowledge? It does it because there is a deep and profound recognition that not to do so has enormous consequences and costs for Australia. It has an enormous recurrent loss of income to government because the cost of interest paid out on government debt which could be retired is greater than the income which might otherwise be used. In essence, the net effect on Commonwealth annual recurrent expenditure would be positive if each Telstra share is sold above $4.85, so we should not do it until that time. Once we reach that point there is a net effect on recurrent government expenditure, not to mention the capacity of Telstra to raise equity rather than having to raise debt.

This bill is about two things. Firstly, it is about investment. What this means is that if Telstra is privatised it will then be able to raise equity rather than having to raise debt. That impacts on the capacity and flexibility of the corporation to bring in investment, to participate in the great international trends and to work towards a global telecommunications company rather than the nationalised local loop provider which is the natural corollary of the arguments put forward by the previous speaker, the member for Ballarat, and by the opposition as the alternative government in Australia. What the opposition are proposing is ultimately the inadvertent destruction of Telstra as an international communications player. That means that Australia as a country will be utterly let down by the policy that the opposition proposes. If you do not embrace the changes which are occurring within the world, if you do not upgrade your telecommunications infrastructure through investment and if you do not use the natural market mechanism which would allow investment—because that is what this bill does: it offers the greatest potential for injection of funds into Telstra—then you let down the next generation. Our telecommunications infrastructure, our highways of the future, will be far weaker than that of other countries. We will place Australia outside the great historic dynamic, outside the opportunities for development. This bill is fundamentally important because it is about the future and the capacity for investment in Telstra which ultimately means Australia's capacity to participate in the global economy of the present and of the future.

The second great reason for supporting this bill is that, ultimately, it is about the notion of retiring debt. If you retire debt, you achieve two things: firstly, you decrease the government's interest payments and, secondly, you may be able to use a portion of the funds for activities such as the Natural Heritage Trust. I unashamedly am a supporter of the Natural Heritage Trust. I helped to draft the initial provisions of the trust when this government was in opposition. It has been the greatest single boon to capital expenditure on the Australian environment in the history of Australia since Federation. This offers the same opportunity, and I advocate in particular that we use a small portion of the funds—if it is a $30 billion sale, a small portion of 10 per cent is $3 billion—to assist with developing and upgrading our national water infrastructure. The rest should be used for retirement of debt. The result is a capital infusion into the environment and, at the same time, an annual increase in recurrent income available to the government. That occurs the moment the price exceeds $4.85. So let us forget these arguments about whether there is a decrease in government income as a result of the loss of share income. The share income is outweighed by interest repayments below $4.85, so every year that the government holds it is a net loss to recurrent expenditures. That is very important.

I wish to finish by pointing to three key elements in relation to Telstra's activities within my local electorate of Flinders. Firstly, there have been significant developments made in mobile coverage over the last couple of years. New towers have been or will be built in Tooradin, Tyabb, Blind Bight and San Remo. I am delighted to inform the House today that we have had a successful campaign within the Blind Bight area to have GSM technology added to the CDMA tower. All of those existing users of GSM will be able to benefit directly from the new tower within the Blind Bight area.

Secondly, there is a strong push—and I am part of this—to continue to extend the STD telephone dialling range to include the Mornington Peninsula and the Cranbourne region. That is a very important step forward, but it will only be achieved through competition, not through regulation. In the long term I am strongly in favour of local calling regimes being open to competitors beyond Telstra. I think that is an extremely important step we must take, and it is the single best way to guarantee that the Mornington Peninsula and the Cranbourne region are included within the subscriber trunk dialling regions. Thirdly, I have been working with the new Telstra Country Wide region, which covers the Mornington Peninsula and Cranbourne and which is a great step forward to focus on additional broadband capabilities and to work, in particular, to ensure that the southern peninsula has greater and readier access at affordable prices to broadband capabilities.

There is work to be done. These things do not come for free and we would be kidding ourselves if we said they did. But ultimately this bill is about two things. Firstly, it is about ensuring that for the long term there is a genuine and sustainable level of investment in Australia's telecommunications, and that investment comes through giving Telstra the capacity to raise equity rather than it having to generate debt. At the moment, the only way that it can ensure it has sufficient funds for investment is through straight cash debt—and that is a problem. But if it is able to participate in the global market—that is the way the world is moving and to think anything otherwise is to hide our heads in the sand—then it will open itself to the capacity to invest and to be part of the great telecommunications developments in the coming years, whether they are in broadband, satellite, microwave or digital technology. That is fundamental to national development.

Secondly, this bill is about allowing in the long term for increased recurrent funding for the government—for people such as Justin Babare of Phillip Island—because there are scarce resources. If we waste money by not maximising the return to the government and at the same time refuse to increase services by choking the investment, it would not be in Australia's interests. The full privatisation of Telstra would ultimately bring two things to Australia: it would bring investment in telecommunications, and it would make more funds available on a recurrent basis—so long as Telstra is sold at greater than $4.85 per share—for expenditure across the variety of government services outside of telecommunications. For those reasons I strongly support the bill and I recommend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Greens oppose the sale of Telstra. The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 seeks to amend the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 to repeal the provisions that require the Commonwealth to retain 50.1 per cent equity in Telstra. In other words, the bill seeks to allow the government to sell off the rest of one of this nation's prime pieces of public infrastructure. The sale of such a valuable public asset is both fiscally and socially irresponsible and, what is worse, the government refuses to listen to the people of Australia on this issue.

speech.para: Before referring to my own electorate of Cunningham, I would like to briefly comment on statements by some of the previous speakers. The member for New England pointed out that in rural and regional Australia the opposition to the sale is overwhelming. Surveys have shown that more than 92 per cent of people are against it, and it is undoubtedly high in metropolitan areas as well. Likewise, Telstra as a business continues to make a substantial contribution to the public coffers, with an annual dividend of $1.4 billion. Here we have the unpopular sale of a valuable asset. The Australian Greens' policy has always been to oppose the sale of Telstra, despite comments by the member for Melbourne that Labor, and Labor alone, has been the only party to maintain such a position. The Greens go further—we believe that the government should in fact increase its ownership of the telco and claw back some of the 49.9 per cent at present in private ownership.

The government's misguided position is clear: support its rich mates, support the big end of town, reduce capital expenditure, sack staff and sell off Telstra. The member for Eden-Monaro, in defence of the government's position, told us that `the real issue is service, not ownership'. Well, ownership in public hands equals service; ownership in private hands equals profit. The member for Eden-Monaro also told us to rest assured for service standards are entrenched in law. He said that the Howard government had put in place:

quote.para: ... the safeguards needed, particularly for rural and regional Australia—safeguards such as the customer service guarantee, which requires all telephone companies to meet specified time frames to connect fixed-line services, repair faults and keep appointments. If a telephone company fails to meet these time frames, they are required by law to make automatic compensation payments to customers. This is fixed in legislation. It is the law.

speech.para: It is the law? The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, has stated clearly on this matter that `legislation does bind future governments unless they change it'. So much for the law. I am afraid that the government's shallow assurances give me no solace, nor do they give the people of rural and regional Australia solace, for there is no guarantee that service standards will be maintained or improved just because the government says so. We just have to look around us and talk to our constituents to find ample examples of the failure to provide adequate and up-to-date telecommunications services to all Australians, especially those in rural, regional and remote areas. For example, there are a number of black spots in my electorate of Cunningham, located just 80 kilometres south of Sydney, so I can only imagine what the service is like in more remote areas of Australia.
The member for Eden-Monaro also brushed aside earlier speakers' claims that the vast majority of ordinary Australians are opposed to the sale of Telstra. He told us:

quote.para: ... the easy thing for me to do would have been the populist thing, that is, oppose this policy. But I know that to be a cop out.

As a community leader, it is always easy just to do what you think the majority of people perceive to be best about a particular issue at a particular point in time. There is no great courage in that. As elected representatives, we must make our own decisions; otherwise one would spend their whole time asking 90,000 people what they think about every single matter which comes before us. It is not credible to single out one issue; you either make your decision or you never do.

speech.para: `You either make your decision or you never do.' Is the member for Eden-Monaro telling us to disregard the views of our constituents? Is the full sale of Telstra the member's own decision, or has he been told to support it by the minister? We know the member for Hume has made his own decision about the sale, and look what trouble that has landed him in with the party. He has abstained from speaking in this debate on an issue so dear to his heart and to his constituents. On such an important issue as the sale of Telstra, I can do nothing but support my constituents and oppose its further sale. If this government is arrogant enough to think that it can continue to so flagrantly oppose what is in the best interests of this country—and what the people of Australia are clearly telling them they want—then the government will surely pay the price at the ballot box. In his second reading speech on this bill, the Minister for Education, Science and Training said that the government:

quote.para: ... has undertaken not to proceed with any further sale of Telstra until it is fully satisfied that arrangements are in place to deliver adequate telecommunications services to all Australians, including maintaining the improvements to existing services.

speech.para: The member for Eden-Monaro told us that Telstra will be sold off when `service levels get to acceptable standards'. Acceptable to whom? To the government? To the community? It is clear that the community is not satisfied with Telstra's performance. I do not know how adequate telecommunications services are in the minister's metropolitan seat of Bradfield or in the rural seat of Eden-Monaro, but I can assure both members of the government that in my seat of Cunningham they are pretty pathetic—not through any fault of Telstra workers but because of the specific privatisation policy of this government and the pressure being put on management to prune back staff in preparation for a full sale.

We have heard numerous accounts in this House over recent months of the inadequacies of Telstra services in electorates throughout Australia. I will not bore honourable members with a litany of Telstra woes from my electorate of Cunningham, but a couple of brief case studies will illustrate the point. On 4 July this year, I joined eight sacked Telstra maintenance workers and their union representative in a protest in central Wollongong. The workers had just been given notice of their sacking—they were declared redundant—and were on seven weeks leave with pay whilst they came to terms with the announcement. All of those workers wanted to keep their jobs. However, as we stood outside the Telstra building in Wollongong, Telstra management instructed those workers, by SMS, not to join the so-called protest. If they did, it would affect their redundancy entitlements. The workers were being gagged by the Telstra management. Why? What did Telstra have to hide?

These unfortunate workers, many with mortgages and family commitments, were being denied the opportunity to speak to the media about how they truly felt, having been sacked from positions which some of them had been in for 20 to 30 years or more. There was over 200 years worth of local experience amongst the eight workers sacked that day, and all of this experience was lost to Telstra and the local community. They had been sacked for no good reason. They had been declared redundant by Telstra management despite the fact that service standards in Wollongong could not be guaranteed. In fact, Telstra management had told us that major cable faults in the Illawarra had been fixed, but domestic and business customers are still hung out at the end of a network of smaller cables which are subject to interruption every time it rains—and it rains a lot in Cunningham.

I was frankly appalled that the national telecommunications carrier would sack eight maintenance workers, one of whom had 34 years experience, at a time when they and their colleagues were being forced to work regular overtime—to do the very same fault repair work for which they were now told they were not needed. There was no genuine justification for these job cuts. This action could result only in a decrease in the quality of service available to the people of the Illawarra. There is more than enough work just to maintain the present system, and the local experience of the sacked workers is sorely needed.

At the same time that Telstra was sacking workers in Wollongong and Sydney, it was also running a publicity campaign, proclaiming `local people, local knowledge, local solutions'. What hypocrisy!
