People need to be sure that those services will improve in the future and will remain at a level that gives them security in their telecommunications service. The future-proofing of services and infrastructure has demonstrated that people can be sure that they will share in a sound telecommunications service into the future.

I have also written to a great range of my constituents right across the electorate to tell them what has been done and to ask them their views. In response to that personally written letter which was widely distributed to each constituent—in the form of `Dear Mr and Mrs Smith'—asking people to contact my office with their views and concerns, do you know how many responses were made to my office? I have had 10. The Independents and the Labor Party have been going on and on about this. I have contacted my constituents twice—not once. I did not lead but told them what has been done and asked for their opinion on a second occasion, for them to contact the office—to write in, ring, tell me, email, whatever they like—and we have had 10 responses.

For those who want to go out and campaign on this issue, please do. I would be delighted if you wasted your time and efforts. Go out and tell people in my electorate what they should think—they will really appreciate that! Independent, fair-minded North Queenslanders love to be told by a slick southerner how they should think! I do not do that. I go out and ask them what they think. I then ask them again to make sure, and I listen very carefully to what they say. I wrote to them again and said, `Tell me what you think,' and I received 10 responses. As I said, people want to see the money well spent. That is what they want. They would like to build jobs and opportunities for the future. I welcome those who want to turn the next federal election into a referendum on Telstra. That is a campaign I very much look forward to, because I am happy to go out to my constituents to tell them and to assure them they have a sound telecommunications system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The member for Dawson's contribution on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 is certainly in contradiction to the views that she expressed so forthrightly in May of last year, which I will come to later. I notice she spent some time talking about Saddam Hussein. I am not sure that Saddam Hussein has got an interest in this debate, but I would have thought it behoved the member for Dawson to acknowledge the tragedy that occurred in Iraq this morning with the untimely and murderous death of Mr de Mello, the United Nations representative in Baghdad, and of a number of other United Nations employees. If the member for Dawson wants to talk about Saddam Hussein, let us talk about the real story in Iraq at the moment.

speech.para: I notice that the member for Dawson has left the chamber. She introduced this topic into the debate. In a debate about Australian telecommunications, the member for Dawson talks about Saddam Hussein! What we know is that the United Nations did not cause the conflict in Iraq. The United Nations ought not to be the target of those people, those terrorists, who are insisting upon imposing their will upon the Iraqi community and other communities around the world.

Given that the member for Dawson was conferring on this chamber her views about Saddam Hussein, she might at the very least have acknowledged the travesty of the attack on the United Nations that took place in Iraq overnight. But no, we did not get that from the National Party; we did not get that from the member for Dawson. In discussing this issue the member for Dawson ought to have acknowledged that the United Nations are very important in gaining a peaceful outcome in Iraq and should not be the target of attacks such as the one which was so cowardly made upon the United Nations headquarters in Iraq last night.
The member for Dawson also talked about a survey. She told us that 81 per cent of her community oppose the full sale of Telstra.

talk.start.para: —And she is listening to them!

—This is a person, as my colleague says, who is listening to her community! She said she was listening to her community last year and she insisted that there should not be the full sale of Telstra. She now tells us that even though 81 per cent of her community oppose any further sale of Telstra, she thinks it is a good idea. And then she has the hide to tell us that she believes that she is listening to the community. You can ask exactly what that means and it is this: ask a question, get the answer; do not like the answer, tell a fib. A number of fibs have been told by the government over the last little while, not the least of which has been one in the performance by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Mr Tuckey, over the last 24 hours.

speech.para: We know not to trust the government. Now we know not to trust the National Party. It is very clear that you cannot rely on the National Party now to tell the truth about what their communities are doing and to properly represent them in this place. That is of grave concern to me as one of those people in this place who represent a large rural electorate.

My electorate—unlike the member for Dawson's, I have to admit—covers an area of 1.34 million square kilometres. I can tell her that the telecommunications services in that community are far from adequate. The future proofing idea which has been posited by the government will not solve the problems that remote Australia has in relation to the current provision of services or the downstreamed provision of services that will come about when new technologies are introduced.

This debate has revealed the extent to which the National Party has turned on its constituents. We have seen ample evidence of that today in the member for Dawson's contribution. But we ought to understand the context in which this debate is being had. Less than a week ago, approximately 50 million people in the north-east of the United States and the bordering parts of Canada were left without power after an unprecedented network failure. The precise cause of this failure has not been determined but it has long been acknowledged that the privately owned utilities in the US have neglected to appropriately maintain their networks in the interests of increasing their profit margins.

A debate is raging in the United States—and I daresay elsewhere in the world now—that is centred on the difficulties that government has in regulating these privately owned utilities. This is not, as we know, a new debate. The residents of California have been suffering rolling blackouts and are paying almost twice the rates for power than they paid before the radical deregulation measures were implemented in 1995. In the face of these problems, including the recent crisis in New York, the United States Congress is now struggling to find a way to implement the regulations and controls of the industry that are obviously needed.

Does this sound familiar? It should because it is the message that the member for Dawson has given in her numerous warnings against the sale of Telstra. As she told the Canberra Times on 28 May last year:

quote.para: It is certainly questionable that further legislation would be enforceable on a totally privatised Telstra. What is known is that legislation for banks to re-open branches in country towns would not succeed. Why would future Telstra services be any different?

speech.para: Now she is in here advancing the argument that somehow or other you can future proof—whatever `future proofing' means—tele-communications services to Australians. What nonsense.

We do not hear the member for Dawson or any of her coalition colleagues telling the community the truth these days. A once proud party—and I have spoken about this before in this chamber—that my grandfather was associated with which was once prepared to stand up for people in country Australia is clearly not prepared to stand up for people in country Australia any more, at least when it comes to telecommunications.

In terms of speaking up for the communities that we represent, I note that the member for Solomon is not listed to speak in this debate. He is not in the chamber because he is at another function, and I respect his need to be there. But he is a person who will try and convince the Northern Territory community that they will get a positive outcome as a result of the full sale of Telstra. He is not even listed to speak, to advance an argument, so that they might understand what his position is. He comes from the CLP, another one of the coalition partners.

The only person on the other side of the chamber who has had the courage of his convictions is the member for Hume. He is the only member of the government who has the guts to say what everyone in the House knows: that Australians want to keep Telstra in majority government ownership because they know that it is in the national interest to do so.

We know—as has been repeated here ad nauseam in this debate—that the government and its representatives in this chamber have been trying to tell the Australian community the opposite. They have tried to sell the message that the full privatisation of Telstra will enhance the strength and competitiveness of our economy. They have also tried to sell the message that opposition to this sale is nonsensical and based on outdated ideology. The member for Cook berated the shadow minister for communications in a contribution on Monday this week. He said:

quote.para: ... the member for Melbourne ... would masquerade as an economic rationalist but ... inside this parliament, gave a speech worthy of Karl Marx or Leon Trotsky in terms of returning to the Das Kapital days of the good socialist period. What we have today is clear evidence of an ideologically retro party.

speech.para: Well, I have news for the member for Cook and all of his colleagues: there is only one ideologically retro party in this place, and it is those people who sit on the other side of the chamber. I will read what one of the most respected conservative publications had to say about privatisation of utilities in Europe. An article in The Economist on 27 June last year stated:

quote.para: In most of Europe, privatisation has been more about raising money than promoting enterprise. In several countries, including the Netherlands and Germany, planned privatisation of infrastructure has been postponed or cancelled ...

In France ... there is still deep political concern that the whole policy may backfire ...There is a big question-mark over the willingness of even a right-wing government to sell more than 49 per cent of [its electricity utility, one of Europe's biggest companies].
There is a strong belief, by no means unique in France, that certain industrial holdings remain “strategic”.

speech.para: That is what this government fails to understand, or refuses to understand—the strategic interest that the nation has in maintaining ownership of Telstra.

This government cannot see past the ideology that drives it. It sees telecommunications infrastructure as just another commodity, which of course—as you know, Madam Deputy Speaker Corcoran, from your travels around Australia—it is not. It is not just another good that is best left to the free market to provide. As you know, Madam Deputy Speaker, and as all members of this parliament know, telecommunications infrastructure is a public good.

Australia, in particular, is disproportionately dependent on telecommunications because of our relative isolation from the rest of the world and because of the vast distances between population centres. Nowhere is that more obvious than in my own communities in Lingiari, which of course, as I have pointed out on many occasions, makes up the bulk of the Northern Territory—and, indeed, in Christmas and Cocos Islands in the Indian Ocean. This is what makes telecommunications so important to the social and economic fabric of our nation. This is why we cannot afford to subject this infrastructure to the very real risks of private ownership that have been demonstrated in the failures of public utilities elsewhere in the world.

While the government continues its long march away from Australia's national economic interests, the rest of the world is heading the other way. These recent international developments were noted by John Quiggan, a senior research fellow with the Australian Research Council. Dr Quiggan wrote in the journal Growth in December last year:

quote.para: In the first few years of the 21st century, the rate of privatisation has slowed even further, particularly in Europe and Latin America. More significantly, a countervailing trend has emerged in the English-speaking countries. For the first time in decades, nationalisation or re-nationalisation has taken place on a significant scale. Notable examples include the nationalisation of airport security in the United States, the effective re-national-isation of the railway system owner Railtrack in the United Kingdom and the establishment of a new publicly-owned bank in New Zealand.

speech.para: In fact, there are many other governments around the world that have retained partial-government ownership of their national telecommunications carriers, despite this government's insistence that the current arrangements are unsustainable. Some of these countries include France, Ireland, Finland, Indonesia, Thailand and Pakistan and the list goes on. SingTel, one of the world's most competitive international telcos, is fully government owned.

If you sift through the government's rhetoric, you can even find occasional admissions of the risks involved in leaving important public industries in the hands of the market. As the Minister for Small Business and Tourism told ABC's AM program on 28 May last year, the insurance market could benefit from governments renationalising privatised insurance companies. He told the program:

quote.para: [W]here there is a market failure, as there is in builders' warranty insurance, as there is in public liability insurance, the States have had a history of going into the marketplace with a state insurance body. They did it in the 1930s, they've done it in Queensland in relation to builders' warranty, now it's time for the other States to follow.

speech.para: When asked what this meant in terms of the coalition's privatisation ethos, he said:

quote.para: It's the only short-term solution to what is a growing crisis out there with the small business community.

speech.para: The minister was on the money on that score, but clearly there is a long way between his admissions in relation to the need to have government involvement in the insurance market and what he is currently providing in terms of his support for the government's proposals to privatise Telstra. The importance of telecommunications infrastructure to the communities in my electorate and to the national economy cannot and should not be underestimated. There is a very real risk that a market failure may require a future government to regain control and ownership of the sector at great financial cost to the taxpayers of the day.

There are other economic arguments against full privatisation which are also worth a brief mention. Many believe that the Australian share market is far too small to effectively support a major new float of the remaining government stake in Telstra. Another important argument is that continuing government ownership of Telstra has a beneficial effect on the Commonwealth budget. Telstra has never been a loss-maker—not once. Instead, it has been a significant payer of dividends to the Commonwealth over many years. The flow of dividend streams would be terminated by the sale proposed by this bill, with adverse revenue consequences for future budgets.

Some of the National Party sell-outs have been arguing that the capital raised by a sale could potentially be used to improve rural and regional telecommunications infrastructure. I am surprised by this argument because, for the past 12 months, they have been telling their constituents how wonderful this infrastructure is and what a great job Telstra has done in providing services to the bush. How can they go into their electorates and say that the infrastructure crisis will only be solved through a massive spending campaign following the full privatisation of Telstra?

There are a number of ways in which you could fund future infrastructure—not the ways in which the government is proposing, but by using and earmarking some of the Telstra's annual dividend payments to the Commonwealth and quarantining them for re-investment in Telstra's regional infrastructure. I believe that would be an appropriate way to use those funds. In the same way, the universal service obligation levies that are paid by private carriers like Optus could be diverted to regional infrastructure investment. To me, these alternatives are good public policy and good economic policy.

I will now speak about my electorate in particular. On 1 August, comments made by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, were reported on radio in the Northern Territory. It was stated that:

quote.para: The Federal Telecommunications Minister says mobile phone coverage in the Territory is phenomenal ...

speech.para: It was further stated that the minister said that this `phenomenal' mobile phone coverage has:

quote.para: ... been achieved in part through the Telecommunications Action Plan for remote indigenous communities.

speech.para: The minister might be happy to claim that he has `broken the back of the problems' in remote communities, but of course he has not. At the same time he has denied new services to some of the largest of these communities in northern Australia. I remind the House of the commitment that the minister gave on 5 April last year to provide Australian towns with populations over 500 with mobile phone coverage. He said at the time:

quote.para: The program to improve mobile phone coverage in towns over 500 is an important component of the Federal Government package of initiatives responding to the Telecommunications Service Inquiry.

speech.para: Under that program, the government pledged to provide 132 towns with a population of more than 500 with CDMA coverage and a further 40 towns with GSM base stations. However, when you looked at the fine print you could see that the government made four exceptions—four only—to that pledge: all large Indigenous communities in my electorate in the Northern Territory. Wadeye, with a population of over 2,400, is the fifth largest town in the Northern Territory and the largest Aboriginal community in Australia. Yet the minister decided it was too costly to provide this community with mobile phone coverage. The same goes for the sixth- and seventh-largest towns in the Northern Territory—Maningrida and Galiwinku—and another large town, Milingimbi, was also left off the list of places that the minister was interested in. The minister did promise to investigate alternative telecommunications solutions in these places but—as I might inform you in the chamber, Madam Deputy Speaker—these communities are still waiting. They are still wondering about and still wanting to know what the minister and the government are proposing to do about extending to them the same sorts of services that other Australians expect. If this were a non-Indigenous community, we know what would happen: they would have their services. But when we are talking about a community of about 2½ thousand, as in the case of Wadeye—a remote Indigenous community and one of the poorest communities in Australia—it has no services. It would not happen in regional New South Wales or in small towns in Victoria or South Australia.

I will relate another couple of issues to do with telecommunications in the electorate. From Howard Springs, a town just 25 kilometres south of Darwin, I have had three complaints from constituents who have no coverage for their mobile phones. The same story exists in Acacia, just 60 kilometres south of Darwin on the Stuart Highway. The constituents of this town have neither digital nor CDMA coverage. Travelling on down the Stuart Highway, just 80 kilometres from Darwin, is a small business owner in Darwin River. This constituent owns a mobile hydraulic hose business and he needs to be able to offer his customers EFTPOS through his mobile. This service is normally available on digital phones but he has no digital coverage and the CDMA network, which is meant to be the panacea for all of those woes in rural Australia, cannot apply this technology. From the remote Aboriginal communities of Kintore, Daly River and Yirrkala I have received many complaints about the difficulty in getting Internet connections and the servicing of phone lines and equipment. It often takes more than two weeks for these communities to get their broken phones and lines serviceable again. It is time the government came clean, it is time the National Party stood up for rural constituents and it is time the government got rid of this nonsense—this view that somehow or other the Australian community will be advantaged by selling off any further parts of Telstra. Telstra should remain in public ownership. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in the House to speak on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. It is important to note that on any issue of public policy there will always be a range of views, but the debate on this matter revolves around two critical issues: the issue of ownership and the issue of services. On any issue of public policy there will always be those who show leadership, those who are keen to pursue good policy and those who chase a cheap, populist line. The members opposite seem to equate ownership to the quality of services. The members opposite cling to the notion that public ownership provides the guarantee to the community that a high level of services will be achieved. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth. If you ask people in my electorate, they will tell you that the worst level of services was in fact provided when Telstra was in full government ownership. Yes, the PMG—the good old Postmaster General—presided over an era of party lines and expensive trunk calls. It used to be cost prohibitive to make long-distance calls in the days of the PMG; they were in fact the days when, compared to today, very few people had phones. Since those days costs have come down and services have improved but, despite this, the members opposite cling to the notion that government ownership somehow means better telecommunications. The notion is absolutely laughable.

speech.para: Since the privatisation of Telstra began, the coalition government has spent over a billion dollars on improvements to telecommunications services, most of it in rural and regional areas. The Networking the Nation program, funded from the partial sale of Telstra, provided huge improvements in the level of telecommunications services in regional areas. The members opposite obviously do not believe that the building of additional telecommunications networks is a good thing. They obviously do not believe that providing funding to get local government services online is a good thing. They obviously do not believe that providing funding for public Internet access or an improvement in mobile services is a good thing. They obviously do not believe that connecting Tasmanian schools to the Internet is a good thing. All of these things have been achieved since the privatisation of Telstra. They cannot have it both ways: if they want to have Telstra in public hands and have improved telecommunications in regional areas, they cannot keep the farm.

Since coming to government, the National Party—and the coalition—have had a strong record in the area of telecommunications policy. This government did not just sit back after spending $464 million on Networking the Nation; the government established the independent Telecommunications Service Inquiry—the Besley inquiry—to asses the adequacy of telecommunications service levels in Australia. The government listened to the public concerns voiced to the Besley inquiry and responded with further funding and further consumer protection packages to improve telecommunications in regional, rural and remote Australia. Besley provided an additional $163 million to strengthen the customer service guarantee and the universal service obligation. It provided an additional $50.5 million for mobile phone coverage for towns of over 500 people; $50 million for the Internet access program for faster, better quality dial-up Internet services; and $52.2 million for the National Communications Fund, to build networks for health and education sectors. Besley provided funding for improved pay phone services for Indigenous communities. I am sure the members opposite would have to agree that is a good thing.

It was a privatised Telstra that delivered improved mobile phone services in the electorate of Cowper and across the nation; it was a privatised Telstra that provided the Internet Assistance Program; and it was a privatised Telstra that provided improved health and education telecommunications networks in regional Australia. The members opposite obviously do not believe that these are good initiatives and the members opposite obviously do not support initiatives such as pay phones for Indigenous communities. I think the members opposite may have forgotten about how far we have come since the days of the PMG and Telecom and how much better services are today.

The National Party is committed to continuing to improve regional and rural telecommunications. The National Party understands the vital role these services play in driving economic growth in non-metro-politan Australia. In response to National Party concerns on the adequacy of services in the bush, the federal government established the Estens inquiry, which reported in November 2002. Estens made 39 recommendations which this government is adopting in full at a cost of $181 million—yet another raft of initiatives to ensure that regional areas have adequate access to telecommunications services. This government—the National-Liberal Party coalition government—is absolutely committed to ensuring that we not only have good telecommunications services now but also work to constantly improve them and have equitable access to telecommunications services into the future.

Outdated radio concentrator phone systems will be upgraded under Estens. The quality of phone services and dial-up Internet speeds on underperforming pair gains systems will be improved under Estens. There will be further improvements to mobile phone coverage and further funding for the satellite phone subsidy scheme—a scheme which has been highly successful for communities in regional Australia such as Willawarrin and Bellbrook in my electorate. Under Estens there will be $140 million for a national broadband strategy, as the roll-out of broadband is central to improved prosperity in regional and rural areas.

This government is committed to equity in the delivery of telecommunications services. The National Party under John Anderson is committed to ensuring that equity of services is achieved not only now but also into the future. That is an important thing. Members opposite are very silent on the issue of future-proofing. They scoff at the idea that we not only want to ensure that people in rural areas have access to the best of telecommunications currently available but also want to ensure that they have access to technologies that are yet to be invented. While we are ensuring that there is equity into the future, those opposite are absolutely silent.

The benefits of Telstra Country Wide are obvious to anyone living in regional and rural areas. It has certainly been a very good move by the government. I believe Telstra has been very successful in improving services, and Telstra Country Wide certainly in my electorate has been a great step forward. My local area manager Jim Atkins and his team on the New South Wales mid-North Coast have been very good in meeting customer concerns. Certainly there is always going to be work to do out there, but I and also many of my constituents believe that Telstra Country Wide has been a great step in the right direction and is proving a very effective way of providing better telecommunications services for people in rural areas.

Government legislation also provides for regular reviews of the adequacy of telecommunications services. These reviews will be undertaken by an independent expert panel appointed by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, and the government will be required to respond publicly to the findings and recommendations in the report that the committee puts out. A special task force will be established which will be led by my National Party colleague and the member for Hinkler, Paul Neville. It will be reporting to the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister on a quarterly basis on the progress of the implementation of the Estens recommendations. Estens is not just a report that is going to be filed in the cupboard; it is a report that is going to deliver real outcomes to people in rural and regional Australia. It is very important.

With regard to the issue of continued improvement in services, this government introduced the universal service obligation, the customer service guarantee and the network reliability framework. Mobile phone coverage is available to 98 per cent of Australians. The government rolled out the CDMA network and provided a subsidy for satellite phone users in remote areas. And what did Labor do? They got rid of the analog network; that was their contribution to telecom-munications in Australia. They took away the analog phone network, and what did they put in its place? Absolutely nothing.

Let us consider the cost of telecommunications. As I said earlier, in the days of the Postmaster General we had expensive trunk phone calls and party lines; we had very expensive trunk phone calls in those days. Under a privatised Telstra, telecommunications prices have fallen 25 per cent since 1996. This government also introduced untimed local calls in extended zones at a cost of $150 million and provided all Australians with Internet access for the price of a local call. On the price front, we are seeing prices coming down at the same time that services are going up, and I think that is a great trend.

In my electorate we are seeing constant improvements in services, as we are right around the country. We have benefited substantially with new mobile phone towers in places such as Dorrigo, Stuarts Point, Wooli and Sawtell. And more are on the way, with towers proposed for Bowraville and Smithtown, and work is progressing on those. For areas where the topography is not suitable for mobile phone technology, the government has not let those areas down. We have provided them with the satellite phone subsidy. These are very important measures—measures that are being realised on the ground in the electorate of Cowper.

The availability of ISDN in Cowper is greater than 90 per cent, with BigPond ISDN launched on 28 July this year. ADSL continues to be rolled out throughout the region and is available in Coffs Harbour, Sawtell, Macksville, Nambucca Heads, Woolgoolga and Bellingen, with the roll-out continuing. There is still more work to do; we acknowledge that but things are progressing. Services are getting better and that is what we are about. Improved services and cheaper prices are related not to ownership but to good management and regulation. The continuing fallacy of the opposition ties the idea of government ownership to the provision of services. They are wedded to the Postmaster General way of doing things. They are wedded to looking backwards, looking back towards party lines and expensive trunk calls, rather than to providing better services.

In my electorate there have also been rural network upgrades in the Upper Orara, Korora, Ulong, Nana Glen, North Dorrigo and Megan, and upgrades are currently in progress at Bowraville, Coramba, Fernbank, Bellingen and Corindi. Work is going on constantly and services are being improved constantly. Of course, there is still more work to be done but it is good to see that we are making progress. As I said, no-one in the electorate would want to go back to party lines; no-one would want to go back to expensive trunk calls.

So what do we get from Labor on telecommunications? We get the same old mindless opposition—no policies, just mindless opposition. They may well snipe at the legislation but they put nothing in its place. As I said in that contribution, they eliminated the analogue phone network but put nothing in its place. That is a really visionary policy. A policy black hole is what they have—and all they do is snipe. The Australian public deserve better. The Labor Party should get on board with the government and support the idea of improved services in regional Australia, support the idea of falling prices in telecommunications and support the idea of future proofing. They scoff at the idea of future proofing. They scoff at the thought that we might want to make services better into the future. Rather than setting an arbitrary benchmark now, we want to make services better into the future.

Labor have form on privatisation and provision of services. When they privatised the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas, there were no service guarantees. There were no guarantees that bank branches would remain open or that airline services would continue to be delivered. They left regional Australia in the lurch. They were happy to take the money to fund their deficits and leave regional and rural Australia without adequate services. This government is not doing that in relation to telecommunications services. We are putting in those benchmarks of services and we are looking to improve telecommunications services into the future. There is a big contrast between what we have done and what Labor have done.

This bill before us will not affect the parliament's jurisdiction under the Constitution to make laws about telecommunications matters. In fact, the Labor Party have done nothing in this debate to substantiate their claim that telecommunications will be worse off under a fully privatised Telstra. It has all been merely rhetoric; purely rhetoric. There have been no facts, just hollow rhetoric. They are very good at hollow rhetoric. The government believe that ownership is not the key to monitoring services. Proper licensing conditions are the key, and that is the approach we are taking. We are coming at this debate from the point of view of having Telstra properly monitored and licensed so that it provides a degree of service that people in regional and rural areas rightly want and rightly deserve. It is just a furphy to say that Telstra is such a giant that it cannot be controlled. Certainly the people of Australia expect better of their government than to arbitrarily declare a particular no-go zone that cannot be controlled. Quite obviously, proper legislation put in place and proper regulation from government can ensure the level of services. We did not have good services under full public ownership. It is regulation, not ownership, that is providing those services.

I was interested to read the Hansard on this debate, where the members for Calare and New England made some interesting contributions. In reading the Hansard, I am quite justified in saying that there was a lot more rhetoric from these members, who hold themselves out to be Independents, than there is substance. Just as the Labor Party do, these members tend to spend more time whinging than coming up with any positive policy pronouncements on this matter. They do not have any positive policies, just mindless opposition. That is all they have. The member for New England said he had conducted a survey in his electorate. I noticed the survey was completely discredited by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. He described the survey as bogus and a political stunt. Apparently, and I have not read the survey, it started off by saying, `The full sale of Telstra is not inevitable, you can do something about it—act now.' So it is an interesting impartial survey that is tendered by the member for New England. The House might expect an explanation from the member for New England of how a politically motivated stunt conducted under the guise of market research is going to accurately gauge the electorate's view on this issue.

Perhaps I could suggest a few questions that the member for New England might like to include in such a survey. He might ask questions such as: are you against the reduction in prices for telecommunications services? Are you against improvements to the quality of the mobile phone network? Are you against the implementation of a broadband strategy? Are you against improving telecommunications services in regional and rural areas? Are you against connecting Tasmanian schools to the Internet? These are the sorts of good questions that could be in a survey if the member for New England would like to put one out.

The member for Calare gave us a short list of instances which he had come across of people complaining about services. I can only suggest that the member for Calare should perhaps contact his local Telstra Country Wide management. If you have a concern, don't sit on your hands. Don't do nothing and whinge. Contact Telstra Country Wide and get them on to the problem. I can certainly say that Telstra Country Wide have been very effective in my electorate in resolving concerns. Obviously there are some concerns that cannot be resolved—they cannot fix everything—but certainly they are a very effective conduit for better telecommunications services. Rather than our independent party just providing this rhetoric, they should perhaps get in touch and form a link with Telstra Country Wide—to be the liaison point, if you like, to be able to bring the concerns of constituents to Telstra's attention so it can get on and fix them.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. He described us as a party. We are not a party—not officially, not legally nor in any other way.
—So the member for Kennedy suggests he is not a party. I hear that suggestion.

speech.para: Telstra Country Wide is an initiative that is going to be maintained and one which I can recommend the Independents use more frequently to resolve problems for their constituents.

In conclusion, I would like to revisit the idea that the privatisation debate is one of ownership as opposed to services. The opposition and our band of Independents seem to claim that there is a nexus between full government ownership and better services. Progress over time has totally discredited that. The level of services under a privatised Telstra—or, in this case so far, a partly privatised Telstra—is dramatically better than the level of services in its fully publicly owned form. That argument is purely a furphy. It is a furphy that is dredged up again and again in the spirit of mindless opposition. They have no policy to take this country forward. There is no policy of future proofing. There is no move to guarantee the services of people in regional and rural Australia or to guarantee the people in regional and rural Australia a higher degree of services. There is nothing but rhetoric and nothing but mindless opposition.

talk.start.para: —We'll have a debate in your electorate—I challenge you.
—Absolutely.

—I preface my remarks on the bill by congratulating the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation on the Kids in the House program. I thank the JDRF and the 100 young delegates, particularly Bryce Chambers, for reminding me and my colleagues how great our responsibility is to the children of Australia. All is not well with the health dollar and the research dollar, and we certainly need to do more.

speech.para: Today, like my opposition colleagues, I oppose the bill before the House. The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 has been put forward to facilitate or enable the government to completely privatise Telstra. Their agenda on this issue has been clear. `Sell off this public asset that belongs to the Australian people and use the windfall to pay off public debt,' they claim. But no doubt there will be a price to be paid for National Party support and the sell-out by those members of parliament of the needs of their constituents and communities. So I anticipate some significant pork-barrelling in those seats before the next election—court-esy, of course, of Telstra.

Well, a one-off grab for cash makes no economic sense compared with the ongoing economic and social dividend the people of Australia would receive forever if Telstra remained in majority public ownership. And public ownership is what we are defending in the debate on this bill. With regard to Telstra, the Australian Labor Party's position has been consistent and long supported, according to surveys, by over 80 per cent of Australians. We will oppose the privatisation of Telstra and we do commit to the development of an outstanding telecommunications industry that is accessible to all Australians wherever they live, be it in isolated rural areas, in the CBD of capital cities or in regional Australia.

As the member for Newcastle, a regional capital totally dependent on telecommunications capacity for competition in this globalised world, I applaud the Labor position. Too frequently the needs of regional Australia have been overlooked by the present government and, unfortunately, telecommunications has been no exception. My electorate has been vocal on this issue. I commend to the House the efforts of the Hunter Tech industry cluster in their collaborative approach to supporting the IT industry in Newcastle. I also acknowledge the work of the Hunter Economic Development Corporation, which has a strong strategic focus on the importance of telecommunications to our regional economic development. In presentations to parliamentary inquiries, representations from Newcastle have drawn attention to the inadequate state of the existing copper networks, the failings of the rim and pair gain system as a limit to broadband access in our region, and the inadequate and slow provision of broadband access for all the people of our region.

Through the combined efforts of the telecommunications sector in Newcastle and the Hunter as well as public representatives in my region, we now have a Telstra Country Wide regional office located in the Newcastle CBD. I can only praise the management and staff of Newcastle Telstra Country Wide for their responsiveness and their determination to support our regional telecommunications needs within the commercial restrictions and restraints under which they currently operate. But let's be honest: Telstra has a lot of service delivery issues to contend with—poor mobile phone coverage, faulty telephone lines, non-water resistant cable infrastructure, inadequate and frustrating dial-up Internet data speeds and constant Internet line dropouts are all issues raised directly by my constituents weekly.

In this bill the government repeats its claim that it will not sell off Telstra until it is fully satisfied that arrangements are in place to deliver adequate services to all Australians, including improvements to existing services. Well, we would prefer their commitment to be to never sell off Telstra at all, but at least we would expect the real test to be actual customer satisfaction; that is, all Australians' satisfaction with their Telstra service, not the government's interpretation of that satisfaction level. We saw in the Estens report how hundreds of negative complaints and submissions can be overlooked or minimised. But, in spite of the Estens inquiry whitewash, regional Australia and the people of Newcastle know that their telecommunications service levels are nowhere near up to scratch when compared with those of our capital city cousins.

For cities like Newcastle and regions such as the Hunter, what we really need is state-of-the-art telecommunications and, in particular, accessible and affordable broadband access. I draw from an article by Paul Budde, who is a well-known international consultant and who lives in the Hunter region. He reminds us:

quote.para: ... telecommunications is a very important national infrastructure, essential for our economy and essential for our society.

speech.para: He also said that, as in other countries, Australia at the moment has a significant part of the network that is economically unviable because of its remoteness and distance. He said that, like any other form of infrastructure, it does need ongoing government support. Only government support, policies and funding will always have regard for remote and isolated areas. Paul Budde went on to say:

quote.para: ... very few comparable countries have privatised their national telecommunications company.

speech.para: That position has been validated by the actions of other countries. He reminds us:

quote.para: The copper network is nearing its end and around the world new investments are made in the next generation—fibre-to-the-home.

speech.para: That is, fibre direct to each home. At some stage Australia will need to take on that challenge. It is very doubtful that that challenge will be taken on by a wholly commercial entity.

The problem is that this government just doesn't get it when it comes to telecommunications. It has no idea that telecommunications is the most important determinant of economic participation and success. It is not just about promoting competition, reducing competition, providing a better service or ensuring a budget surplus. It is actually about the future of Australia, ensuring our competitiveness as a clever nation and becoming a leader in innovation and knowledge in the information age. You see, the information superhighway has been long in place and it is already much travelled and quite worn. We are now talking about the virtual information world, and Australia is really not a player in that world.

There is a new information culture out there. I refer to the September 11 incident, when the dreadful terrorist attacks on the World Trade Centre towers occurred. Most Australians will remember exactly where they were when that event happened. For me, I was in my home, watching television. Naturally, I watched the CNN broadcast and interpreted those events. My youngest daughter was there, and all her friends arrived at my house. They did not watch CNN, they went straight to the Internet. They interpreted that event by talking to real people in New York—young people their age who were witnessing that event and who could hold a camera up to a window and share that event. Young people interpret their world in very different ways and they are certainly hooked onto telecommunications. They are the generations who will demand wireless broadband, they are the ones who will demand changes in technology, and we are certainly not there.

In submissions to a parliamentary inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Information Technology and the Arts into connecting Australia and wireless broadband, I heard bureaucrats say that text messages and phones using video would not take off. Get real: it is the most amazing development and it will not stop; it will continue. In another parliamentary report, Riding the innovation wave, welooked at innovation in this country and how we are going to succeed in terms of research, development and innovation. We learnt that data speeds are absolutely essential in this sector. Our competitive edge in this world can never be the market size of this country or access to investment capital—we just do not have those opportunities; the edge we do have has always been our knowledge and our innovation. Getting that right in the technological age is the real challenge for government.

In the Riding the innovation wave report we made a recommendation that the Commonwealth government review the current definition of R&D to ensure that its technological orientation continues to be relevant to the type and extent of innovation occurring in Australia, and in particular that it recognises the importance of R&D. Of course, an important way that R&D innovation happens in Australia is through telecommunications.

Another inquiry that I am involved in at the moment is into the film and electronic games industry. This week we visited Micro Forte and the Academy of Interactive Entertainment in Canberra. We are looking at a billion-dollar industry, where people play games interactively around the world at the one time. Only broadband provides the sort of speed and process of communication we will need in the future. That level of access is going to be very difficult for any private company to maintain in a country like Australia, where remoteness and isolation are very real.

The message to the Prime Minister is: the white picket fence was last century. We need a proactive government that at least tries to be relevant to what is really happening in our country and in the world. Selling off Telstra can only diminish our competitiveness in the communications world and provide a real commercial barrier to our success.

The bill before the House is open regarding the timing of the process of this sell-off—or the privatisation. It allows the government to decide the timing for the sales that increase private equity in Telstra. The shareholders would be trembling if the gov-ernment's gambling skills were to determine the success of any further share floats. They have already seen T1 and T2 share prices fall, with no sign in the world market of a substantial lift. I cite the foreign currency debacle as an example of this government's inability to play the market. So to any members of the public hoping for a killing: do not count on it.

When we look at the value of Telstra, we should perhaps apply more scrutiny to its valuation. The government suggests that the price has to be right, but what will be the right price? I again draw from Paul Budde:

quote.para: Telstra has been valued at $38 billion, placing it 11th on the list of the world's telcos, but in size of assets it ranks at around 25th. It is valued higher than British Telecom in the UK and AT&T in the USA, and this does not make sense as these companies have assets worth many more times those of Telstra. The reason why Telstra is so highly valued is because of its virtual monopoly on telco infrastructure. It is, for example, the only incumbent telco in the Western world allowed to own the telco network as well as a cable TV network. As other comparable countries use this two-technology platform to compete with each other, this may increase its value, but it is artificial because in the end Australia will have to follow the world's lead.

speech.para: The government sees the sale of Telstra as a way to create some politically useful budget surplus again or reduce public debt. The public of Australia have seen the legacy of selling off our assets. They are starting to realise that there is a pattern that we can anticipate, and Telstra will be no exception. Reduced investment in capital improvements is usually par for the course. Staff reduction programs and redundancies are entirely predictable. The loss of job security and employment conditions for workers generally follows privatisation. There are no assurances of quality upgrades and there is the absolute assurance of user-pays—and pays and keeps paying. There are usually higher charges and fees, a more sophisticated but remote complaint structure—I think phone rage would be guaranteed—and a growing lack of confidence that privatisation means any improvements for ordinary Australians.

Labor do have an alternative policy. Part of our unconditional opposition to any further sale of Telstra is that we have chosen to commit to some key features to make sure that everyone in Australia benefits from telecommunications. Telstra will be required to intensify its focus on its core responsibilities to the Australian community and reduce its emphasis on foreign ventures and media investments. Previous speakers have spoken about the $2 billion losses that Telstra has incurred on foreign ventures so far. Of course, higher line rental charges are how we all pay for that bungling and mismanagement. Under Labor, Telstra will be asked to intensify its focus on the provision of affordable and accessible broadband services to all Australians.

I remind the House: let us get with it! Broadband take-up and access in this country is not good enough. It is worse than in Korea and it is worse than in most of the competitive nations in our region.

Under Labor, the competition regime will be strengthened by requiring much stricter internal separation of Telstra's wholesale and retail activities. The minister for communications will be removed from the process of ACCC scrutiny and regulation of accounting separation within Telstra to ensure the process is genuinely independent and rigorous. Government intervention certainly needs to be appropriate. Consumers will be given stronger protection from sharp practices by telecommunications companies, and the price control regime will be made fairer.

Through listening to the debate, we all know that our costs will go up. We all know that the costs of telecommunications will increase because telecommunications will become such a greater part of our lives, but that is the reality and that is the future.

In concluding today, I would just like to say that for the people of Australia it is a real case of user beware. We are all users of Telstra and we all stand to be losers if Telstra is sold. According to the bill before the House, Telstra will be sold regardless of any evidence of what people in Australia want and regardless of the national interest. The Liberal-National Party members of parliament, who sit in this chamber because of the votes of individuals who rely on them to represent their interests, know what their constituents believe about privatising Telstra—they oppose it. But they are not listening and they are not telling it as honestly as they should. They know that their electors want to be sure that the security that comes through having a good telecommunications carrier serving our nation, and through its being watched over by the government that has a major share in its ownership, will continue to be there for them. The people of Australia want to know that no matter where they live, no matter whether it is in a capital city, a regional community, a rural town or a remote and isolated location in the far corners of this great southern land, Telstra will provide for them a reliable, affordable and accessible service. That will not happen if it is sold off.

Australians want to be well and truly hooked, wired and interconnected and they know that once Telstra is sold there can be no going back. We will not be able to afford to buy it back; if it is sold, that is it. They want to be sure, before anyone puts our security of contact and communication at risk by handing over our national asset lock, stock and barrel to the private sector, that the service we have is guaranteed first class, best practice, affordable and available to all, and will always continue to be maintained at that level. It is not and it will not be, and the Australian people know that as well. Our service is getting better and there is some funding commitment to make that service better, but our service needs a lot more attention and a lot more investment before it can be described as benchmark or best practice.

There has been very little support by the government in encouraging take-up of communications. In my electorate we have seen companies come and go. We have seen great support from the community, and I particularly pay reference to the SaskTel telecommunications company, which is looking at putting cable into every home in Newcastle and the region as a commercial service. However, it needs investment support. It needs government incentives and they are not there, because this government has had one agenda: to maximise Telstra's share price so that it can sell it. In my region, that means we continue to miss out. I urge the House to oppose this bill and to retain Telstra in public ownership for the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. The people of Australia are not fools. They recognise that Telstra is not an end in itself but, rather, a means to an end, and that end is high-quality, accessible and keenly priced telecommunications to all Australians. I do not come to this debate with some philosophical or sentimental attachment to Telstra but, rather, I am concerned about what it can deliver to Australians, and in particular what it can deliver to rural and regional Australians, many of whom cannot access the benefits of capital city and provincial lifestyles.

speech.para: It seems to me that one of the salient features that guarantee connectivity with fellow Australians is functional communications. There are several aspects to communications, one being broadcast communications and another being telecommunications, and that is what we are talking about today. I make no apology for being the author of the Bundaberg resolution, which set out seven areas of broadcast and telecommunications requirements that were a precondition to the National Party's agreement to the sale of public infrastructure. The Bundaberg resolution was carried by the Queensland party unanimously in March 1998, and its ambitions are as valid today as they were then. But all seven requirements have been delivered or are in the final process of delivery.

Two essential components of those requirements are Internet speed and the digitising of television networks in such a way that regional and rural viewers will have the same opportunities as capital city viewers and that the reach of digitisation will be at least equal to that of current analog. I make no apology for the stand I took in requiring that the sale of Telstra not go beyond 50 per cent; that it be delayed until a raft of measures was secured for regional Australia and that future technologies would be delivered in some equitable way. I make no apologies for demanding that there be mechanisms whereby government backbenchers can monitor how well the last phase of this roll-out is delivered and that there is no slippage in the interim. It also follows that we, and more particularly Telstra itself, should understand what future-proofing means. That is my starting point.

For 10 or more years now, the opposition have subjected us to one of the most dishonest and profligate fire sales of national infrastructure. Let us be clear where I stand on this issue: I am not against the sale of public infrastructure if that infrastructure continues to serve the public well in private ownership. I am not against the sale of public infrastructure if the proceeds are devoted to the reduction of Commonwealth debt or to new and exciting infrastructure for people living in regional areas and more widely for all Australians. That was not the case under the ALP. They told the nation that they would not sell off Qantas, but they did. They said that they would not sell the Commonwealth Bank, but they did. They showed no compunction at all in selling the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the AIDC and 12 other government entities. What we have heard in this debate from the ALP side of the House is hypocrisy on a grand scale. But while they reaped the benefits of those sales, they did not use the profits to reduce debt or for new Commonwealth infrastructure. Rather, they used the proceeds as part of their bottom line budgeting—an appalling and profligate waste and a manifestation of the worst sort of management. Nor did they future-proof, as well they might have. Had they guaranteed that the Commonwealth Bank would be a provider of last resort in regional towns, perhaps they would have had some justification, but they did not.

We have seen the fallout from the ALP ineptitude, and I can say to you there will be no such recklessness with the Telstra arrangements. For good measure, that same ALP racked up Commonwealth debt of $96 billion, which we are still paying off today. The sight of the member for Brand touring electorates during the last election campaign with a phoney corflute pledge saying the ALP would never sell Telstra was as grotesque as it was laughable, as it was plainly inconsistent with the ALP's own actions. There is plenty of evidence around that the ALP was flirting with the sale of Telstra at the time of the change of government. In fact, the member for Brand is on the record espousing the value of the privatisation of government entities. On a number of occasions he went on the record about privatising public infrastructure. I have a couple of damning quotes from him. He said:

quote.para: ... despite some critics suggesting asset sales amount to “selling off the family jewels”, they do not result in a loss of infrastructure, but rather a transfer of ownership.

speech.para: That was in May 1994 in their last term of government. In the same month of the same year he told parliament:

quote.para: The [Labor] government has a proud record of successful privatisations, privatisations which have not only incorporated a substantial return to the taxpayer but have also incorporated a whole series of other objectives in terms of strengthening the companies concerned, giving them very substantial ownership base and improving the efficiency of the enterprises.

speech.para: Both quotes fly in the face of almost every contribution from the opposition in this debate. In light of the member for Brand's previous comments, I make no apologies now for this government thinking about Australia's future and planning for better days by reducing our national debt with the majority of the proceeds from the future sale of Telstra. I do not want to foreshadow the actions of future governments, but I think we can craft a very strong argument for using some of that revenue for new wealth creation and wealth-sustaining infrastructure in regional Australia—inland rail, dams and enterprise zones, just to name a few.

This government has already invested $1 billion in telecommunications infrastructure and services for non-urban areas of Australia. Let me detail the roll-out of improved telecommunications in my electorate, thanks to the National Party holding its strong line on the sale of the remaining 51 per cent of Telstra. We have seen CDMA mobile coverage introduced to the townships of Mount Morgan and Moore Park under the program for mobile coverage of towns of more than 500 people. The growing coastal town of Woodgate received the double blessing of both CDMA and GSM mobile coverage, under the same program, as will the booming Yarwun industrial area, bordering Gladstone, in the near future. ADSL—high-speed Internet connection—has been brought to the suburban areas of Boyne Island, Avoca and Bargara.

Our Regional Network Taskforce has been responsible for $2.1 million in local network upgrades for small communities. This comprises a half-million dollar upgrade of the network at Wooderson, near Calliope, and a $1.1 million upgrading program for the rural communities of Rules Beach and Winfield, north of Bundaberg. A further $230,000 upgrade at the outer-Bundaberg settlement of Sharon is due at the end of this financial year and there will be a $270,000 upgrade of the Mount Larcom exchange sometime in 2003. A further $2.5 million is progressively being spent this year on network upgrades in Gladstone and its suburbs of Bororan and Boyne Island and in the Isis district and the township of Yandaran, not to mention the smaller towns just outside my electorate, such as Gin Gin and Wallaville.

Interestingly, the Australian Communications Authority recently identified 54 exchange services around Australia that need upgrading, Three of these are in my electorate—Sharon, Mount Larcom and Yandaran. A journalist questioned me on the significance of these three centres in my electorate needing upgrades. I was quite happy to say that their appearance on the list meant that the Estens inquiry's work was clearly producing results. The government have nothing to hide. We want problematic areas identified and remedied as soon as possible.

The fact is that millions of dollars have been spent on improving telecommunications in my little patch of rural and regional Australia, and this is a story that is being repeated across the country. Since 1997, under the $670 million Networking the Nation program, this government has introduced the five-year, $250 million Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. This fund is specifically focused on closing the gap in telecommunications services, the gap in access to those services, and the gap in cost between urban and non-urban Australia.

That initial $250 million investment, under Networking the Nation, was followed by $214 million in June 1999—the second tranche of the payment—which bestowed funding directly on the states and territories. In Queensland's case, its portion of the funding—a $51.3 million injection—was used to study the telecommunications needs of regional, rural and isolated communities. It also produced more tangible results, such as the establishment of public Internet facilities at Boulia, Charter Towers and Moranbah and other remote communities, the upgrading of telecommunications equipment for the Royal Flying Doctor Service, and the installation of videoconferencing facilities in western Queensland centres.

All that money went beyond simply closing the gaps in service provision and pricing. It was put in place to create an environment of sustainable and progressive improvements in regional telecommunications services. Other programs such as the $70 million Building Additional Rural Networks program, the $45 million Local Government Fund, the $36 million Internet access for rural and regional Australians initiative and $20 million specifically for remote and isolated communities to improve their access to telecommunications—that is a total of $171 million—have all contributed to lifting the standard of telecommunications in the bush.

In 2001 the government responded to 17 recommendations of the Telecommunications Services Inquiry—the Besley inquiry—which brought a greater funding focus on fixed and mobile phone services and Internet speed and reliability, and promoted awareness of telecommunications issues in regional, rural and remote areas.

The second tranche of the sale of Telstra brought perhaps one of the greatest benefits to people living in rural, regional and remote areas—the introduction of untimed local calls and Internet connections to extended zones. That resulted in around 40,000 telephone services, scattered across 80 per cent of the land mass of Australia, receiving better services. There are around 100 of these zones and they can be as large as 300,000 square kilometres. Now, people living in those areas can pay the untimed call rate for access across these massive tracts of land. It may be a call to a neighbour or a local service centre, but the fact stands that this program is putting dollars back into the pockets of people living in regional, rural and remote Australia.

It goes further. There are a lot of government runs on the board to report; let me add a few more. We provided $25 million for continuous mobile phone coverage on national highways. We invested $3 million in expanding mobile phone coverage in regional centres in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. We provided $15 million to connect Tasmanian schools to a program. Now, of course, we have the $181 million commitment flowing from the Regional Telecommunications Inquiry, or the Estens inquiry, as it is known. This will go towards improving Australia's broadband services and the future-proofing investments we have made. What a list! All in all, more than $1 billion has been invested in telecommunications services in the last five years.

Members of the House might be interested to hear that some of our Democrat and Labor colleagues spent much of their winter break sunning themselves in my electorate, peddling the news on the Telstra front, that things were bad, and ostensibly trying to gauge public opinion. The efforts of Senators Andrew Bartlett and John Cherry involved distributing 50,000 surveys to households in the Hinkler and Wide Bay electorates. Would that be political opportunism, I ask, or a genuine interest in the opinions of people in those regions? I doubt the latter.

These senators are keen to record the public's misgivings over the future sale of Telstra, but they consistently fail to mention any of the legislative guarantees which ensure Telstra's ongoing commitment to regional and rural Australia. The future-proofing of Telstra guarantees that Australians can continue to have supreme confidence in the service and relevance of Telstra as the major service provider. But it is much more than that. The fact is that two-thirds of Telstra will continue to be owned by Australians. Let me tell you another lie that has been peddled in this debate: that somehow, if the next stage of Telstra is sold, Telstra will move offshore and Australian jobs will be lost. In fact, that cannot happen, because two-thirds of the shares must be held by Australians. That is required by legislation.

The legislation also requires that no private or individual owner or corporation can hold more than five per cent of the shares. Beyond that, the majority of the directors must be Australian. Two of those directors must be sourced from regional or rural Australia. The Telstra chairman must be an Australian. Regardless of whom the organisation's future purchasers might be, the company must continue to be headquartered in Australia. These provisions will apply regardless of the ownership structure of the company.

Of course, other features such as the universal service obligation and the customer service guarantee, which provide compensation when services are not delivered, remain in place. Furthermore, there will be a licence condition on Telstra that will require it to maintain a network of offices. Whether or not that network will be called Telstra Country Wide is not the important thing. The offices will provide proactive, hands-on access to ensure that, as any problems arise, the company, which has millions of contracts with regional and rural Australians, will act with speed and focus on their concerns. In fact, not only will that be a licence condition, but also Telstra will be required to have a local presence plan—a structure of continued presence. The florid statement by the member for Melbourne that Telstra would leave town faster than the banks is colourful nonsense. What a pity the ALP, when it got the banks out of the bush, did not have a similar focus on requiring the banks to stay.

Finally, there is the matter of future-proofing. That means mechanisms will be put in place to ensure that regional Australians can share equitably in the benefits of future technology, even though some of these may not yet be known or fully developed. It means that Telstra and the other telcos will be required to roll out these technologies so that we do not see services stopping dead, as happened under the ALP, when, with mobile telephony, we got to 92 or 93 per cent and it all became too hard. At a point such as this, the government will request that Telstra go beyond that. If it is not financially reasonable for Telstra to do this, we will assist Telstra with the provision of those services.

I have outlined in this address today what we have done so far. Do not judge us by what we say—judge us by what we have done so far in strengthening Telstra. Of course, those are not the only guarantees we have in place. Let me restate some of the others: the stipulation of the shareholder ratios, the composition of the Telstra board and Telstra's ongoing presence in country areas. This means that the government is fully committed to the continuation of Telstra as a vibrant organisation in regional Australia. I challenge members of the House to stand up and say whether they would allow these regulations to be watered down. I am sure that none of them would. Some members of this House would have us believe that telecommunications services can be maintained or improved only if the government has a continuing interest in Telstra. What a load of rubbish! The government does have this power, but it is not a function of ownership—it is because the government has the jurisdiction.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent:
(a) the Prime Minister moving forthwith a motion relating to terrorism; and
(b) debate on the motion ensuing with speech time limits being as follows:
Prime Minister—not specified;
Leader of the Opposition—a period of time equal to that taken by the Prime Minister, and
Four other Members—10 minutes each.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) expresses its outrage at the suicide bombings against the United Nations compound in Baghdad and civilian buses in Jerusalem on 19 August;

(2) expresses its deepest condolences at the tragic loss of the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative, Mr Sergio Vieira de Mello, and other UN staff in the murderous attack on the UN compound in Baghdad;
(3) extends to the families and friends of all the victims of these terrorist attacks its profound sympathy in their bereavement and wishes a speedy recovery to the injured;
(4) condemns in the strongest possible terms international terrorism in all its forms; and
(5) calls on the international community to strengthen its cooperation to combat this grave threat to peace and security.

In a world accustomed to acts of terrorism, all too tragically, and given a chain of events that might have conditioned us, I think most Australians and most decent men and women around the world would have been profoundly distressed at the double outrage that occurred in the Middle East in the last 24 hours. When I saw on television the news of the attack on the United Nations compound and that that attack had claimed the life of Sergio de Mello I quite spontaneously called out, `Oh no,' because his death added a particular poignancy to a tragic chain of behaviour which challenges all of us. Mr de Mello's death robs the world of a very decent man, a person who has been a great crusader for peace, a person who was in Baghdad doing the bidding of common humanity. He was not doing the bidding of any particular country. Incidentally, not for a moment do I believe that acts of terrorism against people representing individual countries can, in any event, be justified.

Sergio de Mello was there to lead a United Nations team that was concerned with the future of Iraq. He was there to help rebuild the lives of the Iraqi people. He was there to promote better health, better sanitation, better food programs, better infrastructure and to help, in cooperation with the American administrating authority, with the restoration of the infrastructure and the basic services of Iraq. He was also there to help lay the groundwork for the handing over of the government of Iraq to the Iraqi people. In every way, he was there to do good to the men and women of Iraq. His death is a reminder that there is no hierarchy of targets when it comes to international terrorism. His death is a reminder that terrorism will claim the lives of anybody, irrespective of the person's contribution to humanity, irrespective of the person's country of origin, irrespective of the person's political beliefs, irrespective of the person's religious beliefs and irrespective of the person's views on whether or not an individual political action should have been taken. His death is a metaphor for the reality that no-one is immune from the reach of terrorist action and terrorist outrage. What occurred in Baghdad, and the claiming of his life, is a terrible reminder to all of us.

I not only extend my sympathy to the families of the victims but I record on behalf of all Australians our gratitude for the particular contribution that Sergio de Mello made to international peacekeeping. He is well-known to many of us in this place. He was the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and United Nations Transitional Administrator in East Timor. I met him on quite a number of occasions, as did the Minister for Foreign Affairs. He had a very close association with the current Chief of the Defence Force, General Cosgrove, when the general lead the INTERFET force. Recently Mr de Mello was the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. He took leave from that position—I am sure at the suggestion of many to the secretary-general, including me—to take the position in Baghdad.

I well remember a discussion that I had with the Secretary-General of the United Nations in New York in May, after the end of the war in Iraq, when we discussed the need to have a very effective voice for the United Nations in Baghdad. I suggested to the Secretary-General that nobody was better qualified to be that voice than Sergio de Mello, and I am sure many other people would have made similar representations. Australia very strongly supported his elevation to the leadership of the United Nations agency dealing with human rights. We do mourn his loss. He exemplified all that is best in the United Nations—somebody who is dedicated, somebody who is intelligent, somebody who has a good understanding of diplomacy and history and somebody who is without any prejudice when it comes to country or race; they are the best attributes of the United Nations—and he is a particularly grievous loss.

The nature of this attack was apparently a huge bomb, apparently a suicide bomber. There is no direct evidence of this, but I think people are entitled to assume that in some way this act was carried out on behalf of either the remnants of the terrible Saddam Hussein regime or international terrorists, or some combination of the two. The message should go out from this parliament that those acts of terrorism will not deter the United Nations work in Iraq; they will not deter the work of the coalition forces.

My current advice is that two Australian civilians were slightly injured during the attack and are receiving assistance as required, although I am told that the injuries were not in any way serious. The rest of the some 700 to 800 personnel in the Iraqi area—including the Iraq mainland, and of course the many naval personnel who are in the gulf—are, on latest advice, safe.
