We should remind ourselves that, although the number of Australians in Iraq now is far fewer than was the case at the height of hostilities, there are still some hundreds of Australians there and they are still embarked upon what is potentially dangerous activity.

As if the attack in Baghdad were not enough, we received the news of the terrible, apparently Hamas-inspired, attack in Israel. Our hearts go out to the people of Israel and to the Jewish people again. They are again suffering the terrible experience of suicide bomber attacks claiming the lives of young children and maiming innocent civilians for the rest of their lives. We had all been heartened in the past few weeks that it appeared as if there were real prospects for a peace settlement in the Middle East. It is important that the terrorists do not succeed by derailing indefinitely the peace process.

The understandable response of the Israelis has been to suspend discussions. As a long-time and unapologetic supporter of the Israelis and the Jewish state let me say that, whilst I understand that, I plead with the government of Israel to recognise that in the long run the only hope of some kind of sanity and peace is to implement the road map. The only way we can have a lasting peace in the Middle East is to achieve a settlement based upon the absolute right of the people of Israel to exist behind secure and defensible boundaries, along with a recognition of the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people for a homeland.

I applaud the efforts of President Bush and others to achieve the implementation of the road map. I had hoped that the events of recent months had given a renewed emphasis and created better circumstances for the achievement of a lasting settlement in the Middle East—and, of course, that is the reason why these attacks go on. Hamas does not want a lasting settlement in the Middle East. Those who perpetrated the outrage in Baghdad do not want the lives of the Iraqi people to be better; they want the lives of the Iraqi people to remain miserable. We have to understand that what we are dealing with now is an unconditional kind of evil that does not conform to accepted strategic and political goals of the kind that we have been used to in the past. You cannot negotiate on the basis of reason or enlightened self-interest with international terrorists in the way that you could negotiate even with the vilest of nation states in the past—and that represents a particular challenge to mankind in the 21st century.

This is a very sad day indeed. We have had resolutions dealing with the aftermath of the attack on 11 September, the terrible tragedy in Bali that claimed the lives of 88 of our fellow Australians and many other terrible incidents, and this is but the latest. But, whatever the tragedy involved, it must not be a reason for the world or a reason for Australia to in any way resile from its continued fight against terrorism. The work and the death of Sergio de Mello would have been in vain if, as a consequence, people of goodwill around the world threw up their hands and said, `It's all too difficult. Let us leave Iraq. Let us no longer contribute to the rebuilding of that country. Let us give up any attempts to achieve a peace settlement in the Middle East. Let them fight it out. Let us withdraw, let us go home and turn our backs on the difficulties that these countries face.'

As is proper in a democratic parliament, we will argue and debate the wisdom or propriety of particular actions taken by this government and by other governments, and we will have our differences of opinion. But I hope that on certain issues there will be no difference of opinion, and one of those issues is our respect for people who dedicate their lives to the service of mankind—and Sergio de Mello was an example of that. I think we would all speak with one voice on that. I also hope that we would all speak with one voice in repudiating terrorism in all its forms.

There is injustice in the world, and part of the international system is to work for the elimination of injustice. But nothing can justify the wanton, indiscriminate evil and unconditionally hateful behaviour of terrorists who claim the lives of people irrespective of whether those people are good or bad, irrespective of where those people come from and irrespective of what their beliefs are. Whenever we try in some way to temporise in relation to acts of terrorism, and perhaps by implication to suggest that some are a little more justifiable or understandable than others, we give some kind of sanction to the unspeakable evil of terrorism, and this motion today gives all of us in this parliament an opportunity of expressing that view.

I want to say on behalf of the government that Australia remains committed to playing its role in the rehabilitation and reconstruction of Iraq. I commend those Australians—military personnel and civilians—who are working so hard in Iraq under such difficult circumstances. We will continue to play our very constructive role along with our coalition partners. Let me say my thoughts are also very much with those men and women of the American and British forces, which constitute the bulk of the coalition forces in Iraq. Many of them face daily danger and many of them have been subjected to cowardly, murderous attacks. They are as deserving of our concern and sympathy—and the relatives of those who have lost their lives, our profound compassion—as anyone else.

The world has united today in condemning the attacks in Baghdad. The world has united in condemning the attacks on the people of Israel by the murderous suicide bombers. We continue to support all efforts to achieve a peaceful settlement to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and we will continue to support unreservedly the efforts of the coalition forces and the United Nations to rebuild the lives of the people of Iraq. The overnight attack in Baghdad was an attack against Iraq's future. It was an attack against the Iraqi people more than an attack against the people of the United States, the people of United Kingdom or the people of the United Nations. It claimed the lives of some of brave men and women working in the service of the United Nations, but let us be in no doubt: this was an attack aimed to destroy hope for the Iraqi people. Let us respond to that evil design by renewing our determination to go the distance and do what is necessary to build a brighter future for those people. In that way, we can properly honour the memory of a decent human being, Sergio de Mello.

talk.start.para: —I join with the government in this motion that remembers those who paid the ultimate sacrifice overnight in two horrific items of news. This is not only a motion that remembers those people but a motion that condemns the actions of the perpetrators. There were two separate incidents. As far as we know to date, 38 people have been killed and over 200 have been injured. The peace process in the Middle East has again been threatened—this time seriously—and the body that most represents hope and peace in international relations has been assaulted and the man spoken of as a possible future Secretary-General of the United Nations has been murdered. This is a sad, terrible and shocking day. It is appropriate that this parliament recognises it, considers it and passes this motion.

speech.para: It does appear that Hamas was responsible for the bus bombing in Israel. We do not know who was responsible for the attack on the United Nations compound. It may have been al-Qaeda. But whoever it was, the killers have one thing in common: a total disregard for human life and wanton destruction in unsettling, and attempting to destroy, hopes and peace. Their actions mean that parents have had to pull the bloodied bodies of their children from buses. There is no justification for murdering, in particular for murdering civilians, whether it is in Baghdad, Bali, Jakarta or Jerusalem. Whoever they are, they are criminals. They have no regard for human life. They refuse peace, and they reject a civilised society.

Our response has to be twofold: to bring these terrorists to justice swiftly as part of our wider commitment to stamp out terrorism and to not let them deter us from the path of peace in the Middle East or in the reconstruction of Iraq. We are united in our commitment to defeat terrorism. When the world was threatened after September 11 and when Australians were threatened in Bali, we stood as one and said, `We've got to fight terrorism together. We have to hunt the terrorists down.' Our resolve is not diminished by what happened overnight. Our commitment is not deterred. In fact, it is strengthened. Sadly, the events overnight also demonstrate how far we still have to go to defeat terror, why we have to be united in our objectives and why we have to understand that the key strategy to deal with it is international cooperation—the pooling and exchanging of resources, especially our intelligence gathering and usage. We have to root this evil out.

The tragic death of Sergio de Mello, head of the United Nations team in Iraq, and many of his colleagues is a huge loss. It is as tragic as the loss of all 38 lives that I talked of earlier. These things always have added poignancy when someone you know has been taken. Sergio de Mello was an outstanding international civil servant and diplomat. He was highly respected throughout the international community for his 30-year commitment to United Nations peacekeeping operations, from the Balkans to Africa to the Middle East. Sergio was a friend to many on both sides of politics, including on this side both the current and the former shadow ministers for foreign affairs. He was serving the United Nations as High Commissioner for Human Rights.

In particular, we in Australia remember his excellent work as head of the United Nations Transitional Authority in East Timor. I was with him at the historic independence celebrations in East Timor last year. As I said before, as with all of these tragedies, they take on added significance when you know the people. More importantly, though, he was a father, he was a husband, he was a friend to many and he was a fighter for freedom and peace. There will be many who mourn him today. The UN flag flies at half mast. He will be sadly missed.

Apart from Sergio, there were many other loyal UN workers and Iraqis who died in the attack. Among the others killed in Baghdad were American, Egyptian, British, Filipino and Canadian citizens. They were there as well to bring peace, but they were cut down by an outrageous act of undeclared war—what we too readily see these days as terrorism. Their heroism and their idealism in the face of real threats to their lives must in all of this tragedy still serve as an inspiration to freedom-loving people. They did put their lives at risk; they put them on the line to serve the community and to bring peace to troubled parts of the world. So our thoughts are with the families and the friends of these victims.

The attack itself just shows how difficult the task of rebuilding Iraq has become. This was an attack on the very institution that is trying to provide humanitarian support to the Iraqi people. It graphically underlines the fact that, three months after the end of the war, the situation is now less secure, not more secure. The threat is not just to a United Nations operation or to the forces of the United States, the United Kingdom and Australia; it is a threat to the very future of a free, democratic Iraq. The international com-munity must use this terrible incident to recommit to building the peace in Iraq. But that will only happen when there is a broad-based peacekeeping and peace-building operation, with an independent Iraqi political system in place.

The situation is confusing as to the Australians involved in this. Fortunately, the one Australian in the United Nations compound at the time has survived. Polly Brennan, UNICEF's Global Landmines Coordinator, is well known to many on this side of the House, including my colleague the member for Melbourne. She is also known to many of our colleagues in the trade union movement, whose congress is being held this week. We are, obviously, glad that she is alive. But there are still over 700 Australian troops stationed in Iraq. In addition, there are several Australian officials working out of the new Australian mission in Baghdad, as well as Australians working for NGOs involved in humanitarian aid relief. Their safety and security is paramount. Every effort must be made to ensure that they have the highest level of protection.

Despite all of these dangers, the United Nations effort must continue. It is only through the long-term, nation-building effort and humanitarian support for the people of Iraq that we will build a better future, free from violence, for them. We welcome the United Nations resolution from just last week that decided to establish the UN Assistance Mission for Iraq to help create an internationally recognised representative government for Iraq so that people of that nation can continue their journey towards democracy. The United Nations mission in Iraq was in the front line of that effort. It has suffered, as a result of the terrorist attack, an enormous setback, but I am deeply encouraged by the words from the United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan that they, the United Nations, will not be deterred from their mission and that the international community will not give up on Iraq. We welcome this statement because we have said that the long-term rebuilding of Iraq will only be done under the auspices of the United Nations banner. Just as we have got to fight terror together, together we have got to do the rebuilding.

The bus bombing in Jerusalem which killed more than 20 people, including many children, and injured over 100 is also condemned in the strongest possible terms. It is a massive setback for the road map. It has shattered the peace; it could be the end of the road map. But, given the motion that we passed in this House only on Monday, let us hope that that is not the case. I join with the Prime Minister in urging the Israeli leadership to persist, despite this shocking activity. For the road map to end is what the terrorists want—not peace but violence. We cannot give them that victory. Apart from the human tragedy, the political implications and fallout from this bombing are enormous. I have said on many occasions that we will not get peace unless we end terrorism. Hamas has claimed responsibility. The Palestinian leadership, in the wake of this act of terror, must immediately dismantle the infrastructure of terrorism—not just Hamas but Islamic Jihad as well.

So today the world is in shock and we mourn those who have been lost. Innocent people and innocent children have been killed. Families have been destroyed. We grieve for them. We send our sincere condolences to those around the world who have lost their loved ones. From this horror, from this shock, the world has to recommit to stamping out the scourge of terrorism everywhere it is found. One by one, the terrorists have to be hunted down; the criminals have to be brought to justice. This cannot be and will not be done by one country alone, no matter how large, how powerful or how important it is. What we have to do is draw on the collective will of all in the civilised world committed to stamping out terrorism.

Australia is at one: our response must be made through the international community. Although these terrible events may have happened far from our borders, they do affect all of us. We cannot solve it alone. No one country can. In deference to those who have been lost and out of respect for those who grieve, our task as a parliament—our task as a nation—is to urge the international solution not just to the end of terrorism but to the bringing of peace to a troubled, unsettled world. Our condolences go to the families. I hope that the world takes stock from this and I hope that internationally we can address this problem as one.

talk.start.para: —I join the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in expressing our outrage and resolution in the face of the suicide bombings against the civilian buses in Jerusalem and the UN headquarters in Baghdad. In Jerusalem a suicide bomber killed at least 18 people and wounded more than 100 on a double bus. It was filled with Jewish worshippers who were returning from a visit to the Wailing Wall. We now know that the attack on the UN headquarters in Baghdad was caused by a bomb in a concrete mixer truck which destroyed a large section of the building. It is thought that it has killed at least 20 people, including the UN special representative for Iraq, Sergio Vieira de Mello, and wounded at least 100 people, including one Australian United Nations worker.

speech.para: Mr Vieira de Mello was an outstanding international diplomat, who began his career with the United Nations High Commission for Refugees in 1969. He served the cause of humanity with distinction in some of the world's most dangerous places, including Cambodia, Rwanda, Bosnia and Kosovo. In October 1999, he was appointed to lead the United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor, following the INTERFET mission, to restore peace and security there. He led the transitional administration until East Timor gained its independence in 2002. His achievements as the leader of UNTAET included the establishment of new defence and police forces, massive reconstruction, functioning schools, improved farm production and the creation of its new political institutions. He was indeed a friend of East Timor, a friend of Australia and a friend of international peace.

The attacks in Jerusalem and Baghdad have at least one common characteristic: they were carried out by terrorists intent upon causing as much chaos and death as possible in pursuit of their objectives. In Jerusalem the terrorists cannot bear the thought that the road map to peace might be successful. They cannot bear the idea that the ordinary people of the Middle East might want to turn away from violence and warfare and live in peace. In Iraq it would appear that the terrorists have a similar goal: to prevent the establishment of a free and democratic Iraq. They have already caused huge floods in Baghdad and deprived 300,000 people of running water; now they are trying to prevent the United Nations providing leadership and humanitarian relief and supporting reconstruction. It seems that all of them are appalled by the thought that there are places in the world where people can think whatever they want, say whatever they want and worship in peace.

As I think about this, I believe that we need to understand that there must be very powerful—dark and evil, but very powerful nonetheless—and identifiable ideas behind the terrorism of the sort we now see all too frequently. It is not enough to talk of senseless hatred, senseless violence or senseless evil, no matter how abhorrent or hard it may be for us to understand. Surely, we need to recognise that only the most powerful of beliefs, not mere ill-defined prejudices or unfocused irrational hatred, could produce such carefully premeditated, planned, callous, wanton evil. People who not only rejoice in their own death but gloat at the killing, the pain and the agony that they inflict on others in the pursuit of their objectives must be driven by powerful beliefs indeed.

I believe that it is going to be very important for us in the battle against terrorism, a battle we cannot lose, to seek to understand those dark and powerful ideas, to bring them out into the sunlight, so to speak—to expose them to honest and rational examination and close scrutiny in the hope that the greater the understanding of these terrible ideologies the greater will be the rejection and repudiation of them, just as so many of the dark and evil superstitions of the Dark Ages retreated over time in the face of enlightened examination.

But in the meantime, let me reiterate that we must be strong. It seems that when terrorists look at the world's great democracies in particular—putative democracies it would seem as well now—they not only seethe with ideologically driven hatred but see weakness. We must not allow them to see weakness. That has been a great mistake made by tyrants of many sorts over the ages. We cannot be weak. Freedom is at stake. Bravery is called for. Let us be truly thankful for the courageous who have been prepared to stand for good, for humanity, and today that is especially, though not only, the case as we remember Mr Vieira de Mello.

talk.start.para: —I support the Prime Minister's motion, and I join with the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Prime Minister in condemning what they have all described as deplorable acts of murder that occurred last night in both Jerusalem and Baghdad. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to all who have been touched by this senseless violence and terrible waste of life. We mourn all those who have died and offer our condolences to their families.

speech.para: We have a very different sentiment for the cowards who are responsible for these gross acts of violence, which have been rightly described as murder. The terrorist attack on the UN building in Baghdad is an attack on human decency, and its perpetrators have not a thread of morality with which to justify themselves. News reports today indicate that this building was an easy target because the UN deliberately did not want to lock itself up in a fortified building. It is just so unjust—

talk.start.para: —I am sure if it would facilitate the House I could call someone from the other side and then allow the member for Jagajaga to continue.
—I think that would be a better idea, Mr Speaker.
—I recognise the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I join with the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in supporting this motion. Not all of us had very much sleep last night, as we have dealt yet again with the brutality and sheer inhumanity of terrorism and of the acts of those people who have perpetrated this terrorism. The separate attacks in Jerusalem and Baghdad have claimed some 40 lives and injured many more people. Unfortunately, the fact is that that death toll will probably rise. While the motivations behind these two attacks may well have been different, they share something fundamental: an evil that does not discriminate between a young child in Jerusalem and the UN's most senior official in Iraq. The government condemns acts of violence such as this in the strongest possible terms. Nothing—no cause whatsoever—can possibly justify such senseless, vicious acts.

speech.para: These attacks are reminders to us all that the war against terrorism is far from over. We have made some substantial progress in that fight, including in our own region. Hambali's recent arrest showed that. Closer ties between our police, intelligence and security services and their regional counterparts have helped to head off further attacks and combat the spread of extremist terrorist networks. Over the past 18 months countries in the region have detained around 190 members and supporters of terrorist groups, including Jemaah Islamiah members. Globally, nearly two-thirds of al-Qaeda's leadership have been captured or killed, and over 3,000 people connected to al-Qaeda are in custody. Over $100 million in terrorist assets have been frozen. But the attacks in Jerusalem and Baghdad remind us that there is no room for complacency. It will be a long battle and, unfortunately, there will almost certainly be many more casualties. We cannot afford, though, to be bystanders. We will not purchase immunity by silence or by inaction. We must show that we will not be cowed or swayed and that the international community will join together, unhesitatingly and unswervingly, to defeat our common foe.

The brutal murder in Jerusalem came at a time when efforts to end the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians through the road map to peace were showing some promise. Of course, this is no coincidence. In their killing of innocents, the attackers have shown themselves to be not just enemies of the Israeli people but also enemies of peace. We believe that Palestinian statehood is a legitimate aspiration, but it is not a legitimate justification for terror and violence. To realise their dream of a state the Palestinians must act to end terror—and they must act immediately. I welcome Prime Minister Abbas's condemnation of the bombing, and his initiation of an investigation is a promising sign. The three-month cease-fire negotiated by him some months ago has been a promising first step down the road to ending violence, but this bombing in Jerusalem has illustrated that there is a long way still to go. The Palestinians must ensure that the cease-fire will be the beginning of the end of violence, not just an opportunity for terrorists to regroup and rearm. Both sides will now need to work all the harder to ensure that extremists do not seize the agenda.

In Baghdad last night we saw an act of terror equally callous and equally calculated. It is almost inconceivable that the targets of this violence should be the United Nations and its staff, the very people working to help Iraqis build a new future for themselves and for their country. Not only was Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations chief representative in Iraq, killed but so was the country head of UNICEF, an organisation that has worked tirelessly and without controversy to address the humanitarian plight of Iraqi children. The country head of the organisation was killed. This serves to underline, if it were not already obvious enough, that those behind the violence in Iraq could not care less about the interests and wellbeing of their fellow citizens. The target of last night's attack was not so much the United Nations as Iraq itself—that is, a democratic and prosperous Iraq, free from thuggery, intimidation and fear.

This cowardly terrorist attack, and others like it, will not deter the coalition or the international community more broadly. This act will only strengthen our resolve to root out those who remain implacably opposed to peace and reconstruction in Iraq. I welcome the statement by the Syrian presidency of the Security Council and the United Nations Secretary-General for Political Affairs confirming that this attack will not affect the United Nations' determination to continue its mission of peace and reconstruction in Iraq. Indeed, this attack should serve to galvanise us all.

The Prime Minister and others have spoken about Sergio Vieira de Mello, who was a good friend of mine. I share some of the emotion of others on hearing of his death. He was a good friend to us in Australia. He was a very decent man, he was a very honourable man and he was a kind man. I remember first meeting him in a dining room in New York at the lunch that the Secretary-General gives every year for visiting foreign ministers. I was introduced to him by Dick Holbrook, who a lot of you would know. At that stage Sergio de Mello was the head of the Office for the Coordination of Human Affairs. Dick said, `This is a great man and you will find him a good man working with you in East Timor, if we can get him up into that job.' That is revealing a bit too much; the Americans did push pretty hard to get him up into that job once we made it clear that we really wanted him in that job in East Timor.

He served as the head of UNTAET—the United Nations Transitional Authority in East Timor—with great distinction. We dealt with him day in and day out, on the phone, personally and in all sorts of different of ways. He was always a good friend to Australia. He was a great friend to the people of East Timor. He had enormous emotion for the people of East Timor as time went on; he was quite an emotional person—I feel emotional talking about him. He captured the hearts of the people of East Timor. Many of the honourable members know that the East Timorese are very political people and they hold a lot of very different views. One thinks that this forum is political; it is nothing compared to East Timor. He managed to unite the people; he managed to win the hearts and minds of the people of East Timor extraordinarily well. I do not believe that the United Nations' great success in East Timor would have been as easily done—perhaps not at all—if it had not been for Sergio de Mello. He helped us a lot. When we had some difficulties, he intervened and helped with those difficulties. For example, he was extremely helpful to both sides during some of the early discussions on the Timor Sea and the renegotiation of the Timor Sea Treaty. He will be enormously missed by us in Australia.

Unfortunately Sergio was not in Iraq when I was in Baghdad recently, but everybody I talked to spoke highly of the work that Sergio Vieira de Mello was doing there—everybody. As members know, there is a lot of controversy about the United Nations and what it can or cannot do in Iraq. But there was never any controversy about Sergio. Everybody believed that this was a man who could do the job. He built excellent relations with the Americans, with Jerry Bremer, the head of the Coalition Provisional Authority, and with the Iraqis. He built excellent relationships with diplomats from other countries there. Again, as in East Timor, it was an extraordinary achievement. For terrorists to come and take his life like that was a wicked thing to do at such a fragile time. As the Prime Minister and others have said, it is very much to the detriment of the people of Iraq. This is a very sad day—a sad day for Australia, a sad day for the world. I support the motion.

talk.start.para: —Like many in this House, I was watching television late last night and watched with horror as the first reports and then the live coverage of the attack on the UN headquarters in Baghdad unfolded. At first it seemed that the casualties might not be great. Sergio, we were told, had survived; although he had been injured, he was drinking water. The deaths were limited at that stage. That was last night. This morning we woke to the news that Sergio and some 17 others were dead. All our hearts sank, as did the hearts of all men and women of goodwill everywhere

speech.para: Sergio de Mello was a good man who worked for the good of all men, as did all those who died with him. Sergio was a servant of the United Nations, as he saw this as the best vehicle to serve our common humanity. He had served the UN all his professional life. He saw it as an imperfect institution; as he said to me one day, `The worst system of international government in the world—except for all the others.' He was echoing, of course, Churchill's great saying that democracy was the worst system of government in the world—except for all the others.

We in this country first came to know Sergio through his work in East Timor. Sergio de Mello and the United Nations were the midwives of East Timor's independence, and there was no greater moment in his career than when he saw the UN flag had come down in Dili to be replaced by that of an independent East Timor. Sergio de Mello regarded Alexander Downer as a friend. I know that because Sergio said as much to me during my various visits to East Timor. He appreciated working with Alexander Downer and Alexander's contribution to East Timor's independence. And he appreciated the central role of the Australian Defence Force under General Cosgrove in providing the security underpinnings of the East Timor independence process.

It was his success in East Timor that paved the way for his subsequent appointment by Kofi Annan as the UN special envoy to Iraq. This was a good appointment, one which I know Foreign Minister Downer actively supported. It was also an exceptionally difficult appointment: a divided world on the question of Iraq and the war, a divided Security Council, and a difficult debate that resulted in UN Security Council resolution 1483, which sought to reinject the UN into the postwar rehabilitation of Iraq. It was in this new capacity of his that I was scheduled to see him again in his office in Baghdad next week.

Those who killed Sergio de Mello and his UN colleagues are murderers. The obscenity of this act is underscored by the fact that this was the United Nations. These are the peacemakers. These are the dispensers of practical help to the poor, the distressed and the helpless of Iraq. The World Health Organisation, the World Food Program, UNICEF—who could possibly regard these as in any sense legitimate targets, whoever they are and whichever organisation they represent? How could they be even faintly seen as a military target? This and all such attacks are the very definition of obscenity.

Terrorism is the enemy of all humanity. It knows no geography; it is no respecter of persons. And we saw the same obscenity on display again last night in Jerusalem. There were 20 innocent pilgrims at the Western Wall, praying, as many of us who have visited Jerusalem have done before. Now they all lay dead in the most obscene of fashions, with three children among them as well as scores of horrendously wounded. We think of them and their families now in a country that has known much tragedy. Terrorism must be eliminated, root and branch, whether it is instigated by al-Qaeda, Jemaah Islamiah, Laksa Jihad, Hamas, Islamic Jihad, Hezbollah or the so-called al-Aqsa Martyrs. They are the enemies of all humanity, and the common resolve of all humanity is to leave no stone unturned, no resource unexplored or unexploited, in dealing with and eliminating terrorism in both its manifestation and its cause.

As others have said in this debate, when we think of those who died in the last 24 hours we are not just thinking about institutions and peoples and countries; we are thinking about real individuals—fathers, mothers, children. We mourn their loss. We mourn the loss of those who have died in this terrorist outrage in Jerusalem. We mourn also the impact that it will have on what is already a difficult path of the road map to peace. We mourn the loss of those who died in Baghdad. We mourn the loss of Sergio de Mello—a friend of Australia and a friend of the world.

talk.start.para: —It is obvious that the sentiments expressed are embraced by all members of the House. I invite members to signify their assent by rising in their places.

interjection.para: Question agreed to, honourable members standing in their places.

talk.start.para: —I thank the House.
—My question is to the Minister for Employment Services. With respect to Job Network mark 3, does the minister recall telling parliament on 18 June:

quote.para: ... we are confident that on 1 July ... it will work.

question.para: In light of the minister's announcement on 10 July that $30 million in emergency payments would be made to providers just to ensure that they kept their doors open, isn't it the case that, far from working, the system is teetering on the verge of collapse? If the minister remains confident that the system is working well, will he now rule out making any further emergency payments to providers, changes to the fee structure or outcome payments over the remaining life of ESC3? Minister, isn't it the case that your department is already negotiating with the National Employment Services Association over the amount of additional funding needed by Job Network providers just to shore up their viability?

talk.start.para: —I remind the member for Grayndler that the use of the word `your' is, of course, inappropriate.

—No, member for Grayndler, the premise of the question is absolutely incorrect. The IT system that you are referring to is conducting about 3.5 million transactions a day in an average time of about half of second. The $30 million payment that the member for Grayndler refers to is not a bailout in any way, shape or form. As has been widely reported in the press, for the first time in this nation's history over 700,000 unemployed Australians have had a letter sent to them with a time, a date and a place to attend an interview where they can have their resume recorded and put on an automated database so they can be matched with jobs. The unfortunate reality is that many of those job seekers have not turned up to those interviews.

answer.para: Rather than be draconian, the government paid Job Network members extra funds to make additional phone calls to unemployed people so that they would receive not only a letter informing them of the time, date and place of their appointment but also a minimum of two contact points from the Job Net-work member. This was to encourage people to turn up for what is, after all, assistance paid for by the taxpayer. I ask the member for Grayndler and those sitting opposite who ridicule this: do you believe that Job Network members should be doing something they are not paid for? We are asking them to make additional contacts with job seekers in order to assist them. This government stands by Job Network. It is not in imminent collapse. In fact, there is currently a NESA conference being held, which I am aware that the member opposite will be addressing tomorrow, as I will be on Friday. I look forward to a robust Job Network that continues to drive unemployment down in this country.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Would the Prime Minister advise the House of the outcomes of his recent visits to China and New Zealand for the annual meeting of leaders of the Pacific Islands Forum?

—I thank the member for Flinders for his question. The recent meeting of the Pacific Island Forum was certainly far and away the best, most productive and most engaged meeting of that body that I have attended as Prime Minister. A new urgency and sense of relevance has been, I think, injected into that body. The very successful and united cooperative intervention in the Solomon Islands is seen by the smaller countries in the forum as being evidence that the body can work, that help is at hand and that different countries of different sizes can play a very constructive role.

answer.para: The forum went a considerable distance towards endorsing the Australian government's proposals for what I have described as pooled regional governance. In particular, it adopted a regional police training initiative and has also agreed to Australian proposals to fund scoping studies in relation to both transport and aviation services, with a view to establishing whether or not they can be better extended or entrenched on a regional basis. The regional policing initiative will see 900 police from the region trained in an expanded regional police training centre based in Fiji. Honest, reliable, well-trained, efficient police are fundamental to the maintenance of basic law and order, and it should be remembered that it was the near collapse of the Royal Solomon Islands Police Force that was the trigger, as it were, for the request coming to Australia and other countries for the Solomon Islands intervention.

We have also agreed to the establishment of an eminent persons group to examine reform of the forum secretariat. In that connection, I am delighted to say that, for the first time in the history of the forum, an Australian has been elected to the position of secretary-general. He is Mr Greg Urwin, who is well known to many on both sides of the House. He is a former high commissioner in the region, he is married to a citizen of Samoa and he has had years and years of experience in the region. He will come to this position not in any way as a delegate or representative of Australia but, rather, as somebody who believes very passionately in the common interests of the countries of the Pacific.
I announced at the forum an Australian initiative on HIV-AIDS, worth $12½ million, and that is in addition to the $60 million program we currently provide for Papua New Guinea.

Another issue was raised which I know is of interest to many in this House, and that is some of the rules that affect rugby players of various countries from the region. As a result of the representations made by the smaller countries, the forum secretariat will take up, with the ARU and the New Zealand Rugby Union, some of the nationality and representation rules that they believe unfairly work against players originating from Fiji, Samoa and Tonga. I had the opportunity of raising this matter directly, after the rather unfortunate rugby match at Eden Park on Saturday night, with the Chief Executive of the Australian Rugby Union, and I think we will have a very constructive understanding and response from the Australian Rugby Union on this issue.

My visit to China, for a period of about 36 hours, enabled me to meet for the first time the new Chinese leadership. It is very clear that the determination of the former Chinese leadership to maintain a close relationship with Australia has been transferred to the new leadership. On every issue, there was a seeking of common ground. The President of China, Mr Hu Jintao, has agreed to visit Australia later this year. It will be among his very first bilateral visits since becoming president, and it underlines yet again the very high priority placed on the very close working relationship between the leadership of the Australian government and the leadership of China. I also had the opportunity of meeting the new premier, the new Chairman of the National People's Congress and also former president Jiang Zemin, who is now the Chairman of the Central Military Commission.

I can report to the House that relations between Australia and the People's Republic of China are in excellent shape. We remain two nations with vastly different histories and vastly different cultural backgrounds but led by governments determined to find common ground, determined to focus on points of agreement, determined to work together—particularly in relation to matters such as North Korea—to achieve effective outcomes.

I conclude by complimenting the government of China on the very constructive role it has played in bringing about the six-power talks on North Korea that will take place in Beijing next week. I believe that the role played by China has been very much in line with its commitment to be a constructive international citizen in the region. It is something that Australia has urged, and it is something that all members of the House should welcome.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. I refer the minister to his statement to the House yesterday, when he said:

quote.para: When they were fined, I wrote to the minister saying that I thought a warning should be appropriate. I did not press the matter any further.

question.para: Didn't the minister press the matter by writing two further letters to the South Australian police minister, one dated 11 November 2002 and another dated 16 January 2003? Why was the minister seeking a special deal for his son, and why did the minister mislead the House about it?

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member opposite knows very well that, if he is alleging that the House has been misled, it can only be done by way of a substantive motion. The question should be ruled out of order.
—I thank the member for Mackellar.

—I do not need the assistance of the member for Batman. As the member for Mackellar will be well aware, what is normally seen as out of order is the accusation of deliberately misleading the House. I allow the question to stand, and I recognise the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I made a statement to the House this morning which addressed that issue. I do not need to add further to it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training, representing the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister advise the House of the Australian government's efforts to improve the lives of Australian children living with juvenile diabetes?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Moore for his question; he gave a lifetime of service to health as a medical practitioner before coming into federal parliament. Today is a day where we recognise a disease which is affecting at least one million Australians, and possibly many more—particularly those with type 2 diabetes who are living with it but who do not yet realise that they have it. In particular today, we focus on some 100,000 Australians, mainly young people, who are suffering from type 1 diabetes, or insulin dependent diabetes. Today, 100 young people, their carers and families have come to the federal parliament. On behalf of all of us in this parliament, we welcome you and thank you for your advocacy and your concern for a better understanding and focus upon type 1, insulin dependent, diabetes.

answer.para: Every three hours of the day, an Australian dies from the complications of insulin dependent diabetes—from diseases which affect the brain, the heart, the kidney, the eye and from a variety of other disorders throughout the body. Apart from the members for Pearce and Lyons, there would be few of us in this parliament who could really understand what it is like to suffer from, and live with, diabetes. The Commonwealth, in working with medical authorities and state and territory governments, is doing three things: firstly, focusing on research; secondly, focusing on the management of diabetes; and, thirdly, promoting an awareness throughout the rest of the community—for those of us who are not directly affected by diabetes—to understand the importance of diabetes and the importance of supporting people, including children and their families, who live with this disease.

This year the Commonwealth government will commit $20 million specifically for research into diabetes. It will include the National Health and Medical Research Council working with the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. The Diabetes Vaccine Development Centre will be supported by the Commonwealth government, as will program specific research initiatives into type 1, insulin dependent, diabetes. This year the government has committed $2.3 million for the National Diabetes Strategy, to which all of the state and territories have signed up. That will focus in particular on making sure that the doctors and the nurses of this country provide the best and most up-to-date care to young people who have diabetes and their families. The government has also supported the national diabetes register. For the first time, we can now track though their lives the long-term progress of people in this country who suffer from diabetes and the impact that diabetes has on their health.

The other important initiative which the Commonwealth has undertaken is to establish in Australia the Cochran collaboration. This is based in practices where doctors and specialists work with people with diabetes to make sure that we have treatment which is based on good evidence, to make sure that Australia's doctors are treating people effectively and appropriately. In July, Australia's Minister for Health and Ageing, Senator Kay Patterson, announced $800,000 for community projects, which are in part a buddy system, so that older children in particular can support younger children who are learning to live with their diabetes.

Finally, the Commonwealth government is doing everything it possibly can to ensure that Australia's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is on a long-term, sound footing for the future. While this parliament respects the legitimacy of the people who disagree with it, this parliament did support and does support stem cell research. That will play an important role in making sure that we understand not only the basis of the disease but how we might best prevent it well into the future.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question again is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. I refer the minister to his statement in the House yesterday, when he said that, following his initial letter of 25 September 2002:

quote.para: At no time did I do anything that was to influence the outcome other than to ask that it be considered as a warning.

question.para: Didn't the minister write to the South Australia police minister on 16 January 2003, asking for court costs to be waived and for the matter to be relisted for hearing before a magistrate? Why was the minister seeking a special deal for his son? Why did the minister mislead this House about it?

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —In my statement to the House this morning, I made the point that the additional letters I wrote related simply to a matter of natural justice and were not intended by me in any other way than to make that point. The money referred to there was an extra charge of $100 that I believe should have been the matter of summons, and there were no summons and no notice issued regarding my son's opportunity to attend in that court.
—I warn the member for McMillan! I call the member for Barker.

interjection.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Standing order 55 applies to all members. The member for Barker has been recognised. He will be heard in silence.

—My question is to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer advise the House of results of the indices of economic activity released by Westpac and the Melbourne Institute this morning? How do Australia's economic prospects compare with those of other countries?

—I thank the honourable member for Barker for his question. I can inform him that the Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey was released this morning and it showed that the annualised growth rate of the leading index of economic activity was 5.5 per cent in June, well above the long-term trend of 3.3 per cent. Westpac said that the index for June points to solid growth recovery in the Australian economy in the first half of 2004. That is a leading index which is designed to try and get some fix on prospects in some time to come.

answer.para: The Australian economy through the course of 2003 has been under pressure from global downturn and of course the worst drought in Australia's recorded history. That has weakened exports and that has detracted from growth. It is welcome that the leading indicators point to the fact that growth will be picking up in 2004.

How does that compare to international forecasts? As TheEconomist records in its most recent edition, Australia is expected to lead the world in 2004 after leading the world in 2003. In TheEconomist poll of forecasters the August average has Australia forecast to grow at 2.8 per cent in 2003, leading all of the developed countries, and to grow at 3.5 per cent in 2004, again leading all of the developed countries. In 2004 we expect—indeed, we hope—that the US economy will begin its recovery.

One of the reasons why Australia has led the world, notwithstanding the drought and notwithstanding the global downturn, is the amount of reform that has been accomplished in this economy. As the OECD said:

quote.para: Dogged pursuit of structural reform across a very broad front and prudent economic policies firmly set in a medium-term framework, have combined to make Australia one of the best performing economies in the OECD and also notably resilient to shocks, both internal and external.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House what the government is doing to boost Australian jobs through its negotiations with the World Trade Organisation? I would also be interested to know what the government's response is to the recently released paper on agriculture by the European Union and the United States.

—I thank the member for Mallee for his question. The member for Mallee knows only too well the importance—particularly in his electorate—of exports going out of Australia in terms of creating jobs in the local community. In Mallee, the dried fruit industry, the citrus industry, the wheat industry and the wool industry have been affected by the ravages of drought in recent times. They have been ably represented in terms of their case being argued.

answer.para: During the period that we have been in office we have seen over a million new jobs created in the economy. It is a well-known fact that one in five jobs in our economy relies for its existence on exporting out of this country—selling something we grow or produce to the rest of the world. Arguably, in our time in office 200,000 new jobs have been generated in exporting industries in Australia. They have been created as a result of the strong economic performance that the Treasurer just spoke about and the strong trade performance of our export efforts.

The government's No. 1 trade policy objective still remains to be a successful outcome in the WTO in the current Doha round of negotiations, in particular with regard to those agricultural industries that are represented in his electorate by the member for Mallee. Agriculture negotiations are still, and always will remain, a tough challenge. Last week in Geneva the US and the EU negotiators produced a paper that may be a road map to progress the negotiations at the Cancun meeting coming up in three weeks time. We welcome the moves that have been made by the US and the EU but they do not go far enough and Australia and the Cairns Group are not satisfied with some of the suggestions in that paper for reform.

For example, it does not deliver enough, in our view, with regard to market access for agriculture. The EU is still not agreeing to eliminate export subsidies. It proposes the abolition of single desk arrangements—so-called STEs—which we believe is totally unacceptable. So in three weeks time the Australian negotiating team will go to Cancun advocating a very strong position as far as Australia's agricultural producers are concerned. Farmers in Australia have been waiting a long time for reform in agricultural trade globally. We will not be agreeing to any outcome in the multilateral negotiations that does not substantially improve the trading circumstances for Australia's farmers.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. I refer the minister to his statement in the House at 9.20 a.m. this morning, which was repeated just a few minutes ago, when he said:

quote.para: The additional letters I wrote related simply to a matter of natural justice and were not intended by me to do anything other than to make that point.

question.para: Isn't it a fact that the minister's letter on 16 January 2003 involved more than the general notion of natural justice and that it specifically asked for costs to be waived against Michael Tuckey—a direct financial benefit for his son—and that it asked for the matter to be relisted for hearing before a magistrate? Why was the minister seeking a special deal for his son and why has the minister yet again misled this House?

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I answered that explicitly in the previous answer.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister condone—
—Order! Member for Forrest, there are forms of the House that do not involve shouting across the chamber. The Leader of the Opposition has the call.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister condone his Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government using his office to make improper representations on three occasions to the South Australian Minister for Police to have traffic charges against his son dropped and court costs waived? Is the Prime Minister aware that the South Australian police minister informed Minister Tuckey in writing that his proposed course of action was improper and unlawful? Prime Minister, isn't this a gross abuse by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, using his office to benefit a member of his family? Will you sack your minister as a consequence?

—In the time that I have been back in Australia, I have not examined all of the material on this issue, and I am continuing to do so. When I have completed that examination, I will finalise my response.
—The member for Melbourne!
—Ready for the sacking.

—I am not being assisted by the Deputy Prime Minister. The Leader of the Opposition is aware of the obligations he has. He would not expect me to tolerate that level of interjecting from the Prime Minister to opposition members, and I do not intend to tolerate it from the Leader of the Opposition to government members. The Prime Minister has the call.

—Having had the opportunity of discussing this matter with the minister, I want to say at the outset that I thought the minister was quite foolish and wrong to use his ministerial letterhead to make these representations. Having thought about the matter and having consulted a number of people whose views I respect, I think the point has to be made that it is open to any citizen to seek representations to be made on their behalf in relation to even the imposition of a fine. We frequently as members of parliament get representations in relation to the conduct of people over whom we have absolutely no control.
—I frequently get people writing to me saying that they think the Commissioner of Taxation charges too much. I duly send the representations on to the Treasurer—

—I send them on to the Treasurer, the Treasurer duly deals with them and they write back again and say, `I haven't got the right response from the Treasurer.' Let us establish at the beginning that there is nothing inherently wrong in a citizen having representations made in relation to what was, at the time the first representation was made, as I understand it, the issuing of what is quaintly called an expiation notice—in other words, an on-the-spot fine, not a court imposed fine. As I understand it, when the first letter was written by the minister that is all that had been issued.

answer.para: But I do think, as I indicated to the minister privately—and I have no reluctance in saying it publicly—that he was very foolish indeed to have written this on his ministerial letterhead. In fact, I take the opportunity while I am on my feet to suggest that if any other ministers are in that sort of situation they should recommend that the person in question approach somebody else to have the representation made on their behalf. I think the most interesting thing about this whole issue—

talk.start.para: —Member for Blaxland—for the fourth time!

—is that, as the Leader of the Opposition said, it is true that the police minister indicated that it would be improper and illegal for him to interfere in the court process. But he did not, when he got the representation, write back and say to the minister, `It is wrong and outrageous of you to make representations to me.' He did not say that, nor indeed—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Just sack him.
—Does the Leader of the Opposition have a point of order?
—I understood the Prime Minister had spat the dummy and sat down. I am asking another question.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister has the call.
—I was just waiting for the noise to subside. The minister has not broken the law in what he has done. The question that arises is whether the totality of his conduct—
—The member for Brisbane is warned!

—represents a failure of proper ministerial standards. On the information that I have thus far seen I am not persuaded that it does and, in those circumstances, I do not intend to accede to the Leader of the Opposition's request.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister advise the House what action the government is taking to ensure workers have access to a simplified national framework for unfair dismissal claims? What obstacles are there to achieving this objective?

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Eden-Monaro for his question. I regret to inform the House that last week the Senate rejected the termination of employment bill which the government had put before it. This bill had two objectives: firstly, to improve the operation of the federal unfair dismissal law system and, secondly—and very importantly—to extend federal coverage to some 85 per cent of the Australian work force. This bill would have been a major step forward, a major step towards the goal of a more unified national system of workplace relations. A more unified national system of workplace relations has been a long-term goal of people on both sides of this House. For instance, the important union official Bill Shorten, National Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, argued last year:

quote.para: Variations in state laws are time-consuming and frustrating for employees.

answer.para: The former shadow minister, the member for Barton said last year:

quote.para: Labor supports the idea of a more coherent national industrial relations system.

answer.para: The member for Werriwa—I know he would not like to be passed over—said a couple of years back that the New South Wales government should give up its workplace relations powers to the Commonwealth. The Leader of the Opposition himself, when he was president of the ACTU, said:

quote.para: There is a substantial view within the ACTU—

answer.para: to which he made his 28th annual pilgrimage yesterday—

motion.para: that there should be a movement towards the development of a national industrial relations system.

answer.para: I would ask that members opposite consult their principles when this bill is reintroduced into this parliament in three months time. Even the current shadow minister, the member for Rankin, said last year:

quote.para: By opposing for the sake of opposing, Labor will have let Australia down badly.

answer.para: I would like to think that this statement of his made last year—and not his more recent statements—reflects his true approach. The member for Rankin and his colleagues will have an opportunity to be true to their principles when this bill is reintroduced into the House in three months time.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I ask: does the Prime Minister accept that representations made by his Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government for a special deal for his son to have charges dropped and costs against him waived was improper and unlawful? Prime Minister, do you condone your ministers using their office to pursue improper and unlawful requests?
—Specifically in relation to the minister, I refer to the previous answer and I have nothing to add. Generally, no.

—My question is addressed the Minister for Small Business and Tourism. Would the minister advise the House of the successful small businesses in the 2003 Telstra-Australian government small business awards?

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Farrer for her advocacy for small businesses in her electorate and for representing one of the award winners from the Telstra and Australian government small business awards, which were held in Melbourne last week. The winner from the member for Farrer's electorate was Descend Underwater Training Centre, which is a great small business. It won the microbusiness award for a business with fewer than five full-time employees. This business trains scuba divers working in irrigation, water supply, hydro power generation and offshore oil industries. It is a great story because this little business is based in Albury, which of course is a regional centre, yet it undertakes work throughout the country. One of the sadder tasks the award winner talked about was how they work closely with the police in searching for bodies in dams and a range of other places. It is a reminder of how important these small businesses are to help many communities through fairly difficult circumstances.

answer.para: One of the other award winners was Rural Directions from South Australia, which is an agribusiness that offers consulting, grain marketing, and research and development services. The winner of the Panasonic Australian business award was Microforte from the ACT, which has been engaged by Bill Gates to work on a new game for Xbox. This is a great step forward for the ACT, which has become one of the leading centres for IT in Australia. From Tasmania—and this will probably please the member for Lyons—Telstra Country Wide's regional incentive award went to Tas-Saff, which is a commercial saffron grower.

Most significantly, the national award winner this year was Footwear Industries from Western Australia. They stood up on the stage—this great bunch of hardworking Australians—and said, `Some people said that the textile, clothing and footwear industry was dead, but let us tell you that it has never been more alive.' This business, established in 1995, designs and manufactures industrial safety footwear under the premium brand `Steel Blue' and the budget brand `Howler'. Footwear Industries thanked the federal government for its support and noted that it now sells more than 350,000 pairs of safety boots in Australia and around the world. This is a clear indication not only of how small business is important to the Australian economy and to regional economies but, significantly, that it is a growing exporter.

All of the measures that we put in place—such as lowering company tax from 36 per cent to 30 per cent, abolishing FID, reducing fuel excise, abolishing wholesale sales tax, abolishing provisional tax and removing capital gains for those people who are retiring on the proceeds of the sale of their small business—are about helping small business to grow. Everything we are doing is about helping small businesses, particularly in regional Australia, to go on to win national awards such as these. The Australian government is proud to support national awards because they recognise excellence in small business.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, now that you have had the chance to see the correspondence between the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government and the South Australian police minister—and having heard your minister's statements to this House that he did not press the matter further, that he did not ask for it to be changed and that he did not seek to influence the outcome of his son's case—do you acknowledge that this is a clear case of your minister not only misusing his office but repeatedly misleading this House? Prime Minister, why won't you sack your minister?
—Two questions ago I gave an answer and I do not intend to add to it.

debateinfo.title: MINISTER FOR REGIONAL SERVICES, TERRITORIES AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move the following motion:

speech.para: That this House censures the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government for:
(1) repeatedly misleading the House and breach-ing the Ministerial Code of Conduct;
(2) improperly intervening in a South Australian police and legal matter concerning his son, Mr Michael Tuckey, and attempting to gain financial and legal benefits for his son;
(3) improper use of his ministerial resources, in-cluding his ministerial letterhead; and
(4) misleading the South Australian Police Minister and this House about the true nature of his representations to Mr Conlon.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?
—He is moving a suspension.
—No. I am seeking leave.

—Order! The member for Werriwa! I determine what the status of the motion is, and I just need to indicate to the Leader of the House that the member for Werriwa's request was to seek leave to move the motion he outlined. Is leave granted?
—No.

interjection.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Werriwa moving forthwith—That this House censures the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government for:
(1) repeatedly misleading the House and breach-ing the Ministerial Code of Conduct;
(2) improperly intervening in a South Australian police and legal matter concerning his son, Mr Michael Tuckey, and attempting to gain financial and legal benefits for his son;
(3) improper use of his ministerial resources, including his ministerial letterhead; and
(4) misleading the South Australian Police Minister and this House about the true nature of his representations to Mr Conlon.

The Prime Minister in these debates is fond of comparing the House to the Waverley police station and the Waverley local court. I reckon any policeman watching question time and the performance of the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government today would be thinking just one thing. Any policeman worth his salt would be saying and thinking just one thing: `Wilson, you're gone; you're nicked.'

This is a minister who has repeatedly misled the House about his extraordinary intervention on behalf of his son, and the best the Prime Minister can say is that he has the matter under consideration and will have further investigation. If he wants to go down to the Waverley police station, he needs to bring in the crime scene investigation. He needs to bring in the CSI and get the investigation going to the heart of the reason why the minister for regional services needs to be sacked; if he will not resign, he should be sacked.

Also, Mr Speaker, let us get one thing straight at the very beginning: this is not a simple, straightforward innocent matter. This is not the minister for regional services calling up the South Australian minister for child care and saying, `I've got a little problem in getting my grandson into a child-care centre in Adelaide.' This is not the minister for regional services calling up the South Australian health minister and saying, `There's someone who's not getting good treatment in a hospital.' This is not the minister ringing up the South Australian education minister trying to get something sorted out in a South Australian school. This is Minister Tuckey writing, lobbying, intervening and starting to heavy the South Australian police minister for intervention in the South Australian police and legal system. This is about the legal system, the police and the courts.

And what did Minister Tuckey want from the South Australian police minister? He wanted the fine waived; he wanted the matter reduced to a warning and to be dismissed. When that did not work, he then wanted the court costs to be waived. When that did not work, he requested that the matter be relisted for hearing before a magistrate. Then, when the minister for regional services was advised by the South Australian Minister for Police that it was improper and, in fact, unlawful to seek this intervention, what did Wilson do? The minister for regional services went in harder and subsequently misled this House and disgraced the office that he holds.

Let me give the sequence to the House. Last year his son Michael Tuckey was pinged for not having a truck logbook in South Australia. It is an important issue of road safety and all people in public life should take that seriously. The son approached the minister for regional services—and at that point the minister for regional services should have said, `Son, go see your local state member of parliament. It is a state government matter; go see your local state member of parliament and see what appropriate action can be taken.' We even heard the Prime Minister earlier on saying that would have been the right and proper thing for the minister to do. The Prime Minister knows, as does the South Australian police minister, that this was an improper way of doing it; this was an improper and unlawful way of conducting himself as a minister of the Crown.

So Minister Tuckey intervenes and writes to the police minister on 25 September 2002, using his letterhead, asking for the matter to be dropped. Minister Tuckey writes again on 11 November, having a second bite at the cherry. Then Minister Conlon writes back on 20 November, saying that it is improper and unlawful to intervene. Warned that it is improper and unlawful, what does Minister Tuckey do? He writes again for the third time on 16 January, pressing ahead with his representations and his efforts to get a special deal for his son. That is the sequence of events at this CSI, this crime scene investigation, and here are the misleads by the minister for regional services. In this House yesterday the minister said:

quote.para: When they were fined, I wrote to the minister saying that I thought a warning should be appropriate. I did not press the matter any further.

talk.start.para: —He says that is right. The minister is living in a state of delusion. He is saying that, after his initial letter in September last year, he did not press the matter further. Why then did the minister write another two letters? On 11 November and 16 January this year he pressed the matter further with another two letters, one on his ministerial letterhead and one out of his electorate office. He did press the matter further, and basically out of his own mouth just then he has confessed to misleading the House of Representatives. That is the first mislead. The second mislead is when the minister told the House yesterday:

quote.para: I did not ask that it be changed.

interjection.para: The minister did. On 16 January he asked for the matter to be changed. That is the second mislead. Then there is the third mislead. The minister told the House yesterday:

quote.para: At no time did I do anything that was to influence the outcome other than to ask that it be considered as a warning.

interjection.para: That is what the minister told the House yesterday—he did not seek to influence the outcome. If so, what was he doing on 16 January writing to police minister Conlon in South Australia as follows:

quote.para: My constituent naturally wishes to settle this matter but objects strongly to the imposition of Court costs whilst he was entitled to the expectation that no further action would proceed prior to your reply to my letter.
The matter of costs is clearly in your jurisdiction as Plaintiff—

interjection.para: that is what he is saying to the minister—

quote.para: and I consider in the circumstances they should be waived or the matter re-listed for hearing to at least allow for a written submission to the Magistrate.

interjection.para: This is a minister living in a state of delusion. He told the House yesterday he did not seek to influence the outcome, yet in his letter to Minister Conlon on 16 January he asked for the court courts to be waived against his son and then asked for the matter to be relisted for hearing before a magistrate. What can the House expect to believe? If asking for the matter to be relisted for hearing before a magistrate is not trying to influence the outcome, what is? It is a clear mislead—the third mislead before the House.
Then there is a fourth mislead by the minister for regional services. At the conclusion of one of his answers yesterday he said:

quote.para: I wrote back to the minister and said I thought that was pretty poor form. That is all that has ever been done.

interjection.para: But we know that he was talking about more than poor form on 16 January this year. He was asking for the costs to be waived. He was asking for the matter to be relisted at a hearing before a magistrate, and there was plenty more that he wanted done. So that is a fourth mislead before the House. Then of course there is what the minister said this morning. The minister this morning came into the House to try to clarify the matter. He was in a 10-foot deep hole, so he decided to dig himself in another 10 feet. That is what the minister did this morning when he said:

quote.para: The additional letters I wrote related simply to a matter of natural justice and were not intended by me to do anything other than to make that point.

interjection.para: He was making many more points than natural justice. He was asking specifically for costs to be waived and the matter to be relisted for hearing before a magistrate. That is a fifth mislead.

The House is entitled to ask itself: how many misleads do we need for this minister to go? How many misleads? If it is not good enough for the Prime Minister to have one mislead, two misleads, three misleads, four misleads and now the fifth mislead by the minister for regional services, what do we need in this parliamentary democracy of ours—in this debating chamber, this House of Representatives—for this Prime Minister to sack a minister? If five misleads are not enough, what do we need? Six, seven, eight, nine, 10 and it goes on forever? We have five clear misleadings of the House of Representatives, and somehow it is not good enough for the Prime Minister, Mr Howard.

talk.start.para: —No standards.
—No standards, because it is this guide on ministerial conduct that has been junked.
—Because he has misled!

—We have five misleads by the minister for regional services and, as the Leader of the Opposition points out, the reason the Prime Minister will not sack this minister is that, if he sets a precedent by sacking people for misleading the House, he will be in even deeper trouble himself over Manildra. That is the bigger truth of it. If he acts against the minister for regional services, then he has to act against himself. He has handcuffed himself to Wilson Tuckey. He has forgotten all about that Four Corners show in 1989. They are now handcuffed together in misleading the House of Representatives. If Wilson goes down, the Prime Minister has to go down with him. That is why the Prime Minister will not act. His lame excuse is that he has the matter under consideration and investigation. If you want the crime scene investigation, Prime Minister, open the Hansard, have a read of it and sack this minister right now.
—The member for Oxley is warned! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
