—The member for Fowler is warned! I am on my feet. The member for Prospect is not far behind her. The member for Werriwa was heard in silence. Unless the same courtesy is extended to the Leader of the House and whoever else may be participating, I will deal immediately with those who interrupt.
—You would think by the behaviour of members opposite that the offence of the minister for regional services—
—The member for Oxley will excuse himself from the House!

para.inline: The member for Oxley then left the Chamber.

talk.start.para: —was the equal of the outrages that have taken place over the last 24 hours in the Middle East. Yes, the minister has offended against ordinary standards that we expect in this place. The minister has offended, but it is not a hanging offence. The government is taking this matter seriously.
—I warn the member for Blaxland! I warn the member for Parramatta!

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. To link the tragic events in the Middle East over the last 24 hours to the motivation of the opposition in moving this motion against the minister for regional services is absolutely offensive to every member on this side of the House.
—If it suits the convenience of the House, I am happy to withdraw anything that offends the member for Werriwa.
—The member for Werriwa will resume his seat or I will deal with him. The matter has been dealt with. The Leader of the House has the call.
—The member for Lingiari is warned!

—The point I want to make is that this government is taking this matter seriously, but we are also taking it with a proper sense of proportion. As the Prime Minister has pointed out, the minister for regional services has acted in a way which is wrong and which is foolish, but his offence is—
—The member for Reid is warned!

—intemperance, not impropriety. The minister for regional services sent three letters to the South Australian minister. The first letter was a letter seeking ministerial intervention in an infringement notice that had been given to his son. The question is: if one of our constituents came to us and said, `An infringement notice has been issued to me in circumstances that I think are unfair,' would we be entitled to make representations on the constituent's behalf? I think the answer is probably yes. It may not be wise; it may not necessarily be acted upon—most likely it would not be acted upon—but the fact is that, if some stranger came into our offices and said to us, `Member of parliament, we think that we have been unfairly and improperly treated; would you please make representations on our behalf,' I think most members would at least consider it. And the fact is that there is nothing intrinsically wrong with making representations on behalf of another Australian in a matter where that Australian believes that he or she has been inappropriately dealt with by a governmental authority. If the member for O'Connor had made this representation—
—The member for Swan is warned!

—on behalf of another Australian, it would have been okay. I do not think there was any problem with him making that representation on behalf of his son, because in the very first line of the letter that he sent to the South Australian police minister, he said, `I must tell you that this is a matter that concerns my son.'
—The member for Ballarat is warned!

—What could be more open and up front than that? I have to say—let me say publicly what I have said privately to the minister—I thought his subsequent letters were intemperate. They were over the top. They were uncalled for. They should not have been sent. They should certainly not have been sent on ministerial letterhead. But the fact is, intemperance is not a crime.
—It's unlawful.

—Let me make this point: it is not unlawful for representations to be made. It may well have been unlawful for the minister to have acted upon those representations, but it was not unlawful at all for the representations to be made.
—The member for Melbourne clearly wants to leave the chamber. I warn him.

—If it is unlawful for representations to be made—if that is wrong—what about all the representations that members opposite are constantly making to ministers in this government on a whole range of matters?
—The member for Lalor is warned!

—What about matters that are being handled by the Australian tax office and may well one day be subject to litigation? There are dozens if not hundreds of representations made by members of parliament on both sides of this place to independent officers and to ministers about matters that might one day be subject to litigation. Let me repeat: there is nothing at all unlawful or improper in a minister making representations in the way he did on behalf of a constituent; and, if that is okay, there is nothing wrong with doing the same thing on behalf of a family member, provided that he declared it up front, at the beginning—which he did. It is not unknown for members of parliament to make representations to ministers in respect of traffic infringements. It is not unknown for this to happen. I suspect if we were to go through the files of police ministers of both political persuasions—
—You sound like Pauline Hanson's lawyer.
—The member for Hunter is warned!

—in all of the six states we would find plenty of examples of members of parliament making representations about traffic infringement notices. It is not improper. It is not a hanging offence. It may be unwise. It may be injudicious. They are certainly representations that are often ignored by the person to whom they are made, but there is nothing intrinsically wrong with them.

speech.para: As the Prime Minister has said, the minister was wrong—the minister has been foolish. All of the minister's colleagues think that he should not have done what he did. Certainly, all of us think that he was wrong to write the two subsequent letters and he was wrong to adopt the tone that he did. The minister has embarrassed his colleagues, but he has not lost our support, because this is not a hanging offence. It is a mistake. It is an embarrassment. It should not have happened. But this minister is a good minister. He is a very good constituency representative. He is a man who quite rightly fights for the things he believes in. If, from time to time, this minister goes over the top for a cause in which he believes, that is his nature. That is the nature of the man; that is the way this fine Australian operates. This is a government that believes in calling things by their true names. What the minister has done in this case is wrong, it is foolish, it is intemperate, it is over the top, but it is nothing for which he deserves to be sacked.

talk.start.para: —If the Prime Minister had any integrity in this matter, he would come into the House and sack this minister now. The minister was sitting there gagged and alone. For the benefit of this House, let me state quite clearly what is the crux of the issue. The crux of the issue here is this: the minister used his ministerial office to attempt to influence the South Australian police minister to engage in improper and unlawful conduct. That is the crux of the issue that we are debating here today.

speech.para: When I first raised this issue in question time, the minister gave three answers. He said, `I did not press this matter any further.' We now know that he did. He said, `I did not ask that the substance be changed.' We now know that he did. He stated that this was a constituent inquiry. We know that it was not. I asked those first questions, and when the minister replied he misled this House. On that basis and on that basis alone, he should have been sacked from the ministry. But today he came into the House to offer his feeble excuse for what he had done. He said:

quote.para: Any representations that I make on behalf of others, wherever they reside, I have always treated as a constituent matter, to differentiate it from official business.

speech.para: But he did not treat it merely as a constituent matter, even if indeed his son was his constituent—and we know he was not. He wrote the letters—and signed them—on his official ministerial letterhead. There was nothing about a constituent matter in what the minister wrote. Today at 9.20 a.m. he said that his actions:

quote.para: ... were not intended by me to do anything other than to make that point.

speech.para: From the questions that we have asked we now know that the minister did have another point, which he denied this morning and which is clear in his letters. He wanted the costs waived and he wanted this matter reopened, presumably to get the fine dropped.
The telling letter is letter No. 2, which the minister wrote on 11 November 2002 to the Hon. Patrick Conlon, the Minister for Police in South Australia. In it the minister said:

quote.para: The fact that your officers have chosen to have the matter dealt with in court in this process, which must be unique to South Australia, clearly leaves neither you or I the opportunity for an administrative intervention, and my constituent can only presumably appeal to your justice system if he can afford the cost.

speech.para: The key words here are `administrative intervention', because the minister was about the fix. He was about the fix in the second letter he wrote on his official letterhead supposedly on behalf of a constituent—who as it turned out was not his constituent but his son. He went on to claim that his son was his constituent, and I say to you, Mr Speaker, and I say to every member of this House: how many times can you mislead this House and still escape the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct?

Prime Minister, you are in the House today. The evidence is clear that there are no less than five—and possibly six or more—misleads. Does your ministerial code of conduct mean anything? Do you have the courage to uphold your ministerial code of conduct and sack the minister? I ask you, Prime Minister, to do the right thing by this parliament. Do not come into this House with some weasel words—a demonstration of obvious weakness—and let this minister off the hook. In the process, you debase the very institution that we are pledged here to make work and whose standards we are pledged to uphold. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The question is that the motion be agreed to. All those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the noes have it.
—The ayes have it, clearly.

interjection.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Is a division required?
—Yes, of course.
—Well, I did not hear many calls, Leader of the Opposition.
—You should have called it on the voices.
—I point out to the Leader of the Opposition, as any reference to the tape will indicate, that when I asked if the ayes had it, there were not a number of voices saying aye.
—Of course there were!

—The Leader of the Opposition will not reflect on the chair at any time and least of all when I am in the middle of a statement to the House. The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that reflection.

—Mr Speaker, at this point I will withdraw it. I will wait to hear what you say. I believe what you commenced to say was not an accurate reflection of what the tape will show, because there were many voices on this side that called aye, and only one voice that called no. My suggestion was that on the voices you should have called the division. But I will withdraw in deference to you, and you can continue your point.

—Let me indicate to the House that it is the custom for the chair to call for ayes or noes and then to call for a division. The reason I indicated that I thought the ayes had it and proceeded not to call for a division was that there had been no such instruction. I have now called for a division. The bells will be rung.
—Mr Speaker, you just said then that you called that the ayes had it, when in fact you called that the noes had it.
—Yes, I did.
—There was one no, and that was Minister Abbott.
—I do not intend to engage in a conversation about this.
—You go and listen to the tapes!
—The member for Lyons will be dealt with at the conclusion of question time.

interjection.para: Question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Latham's) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—The treatment of the chair by the member for Lyons is quite unacceptable and I name him.

interjection.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (4.14 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the Member for Lyons be suspended from the service of the House.

interjection.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Lyons is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours under standing order 305.

para.inline: The member for Lyons then left the chamber.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I understand that the South Australian Minister for Police, the Hon. Patrick Conlon, wrote to you in February 2003 seeking your views on a series of approaches made to him by the member for O'Connor. Can you confirm whether this occurred? Could you advise the House of what action you took in response to Mr Conlon's letter—in particular whether you brought the matter to Minister Tuckey's attention or to the attention of the Prime Minister—and when that occurred? Will you provide the House with copies of correspondence in relation to this matter?

—I thank the member for Corio for his question. Let me respond to the House by indicating that the Minister for Police in South Australia, Mr Conlon, did write to me—I must admit that it was April or thereabouts—and did ask for an opinion from me. I responded to the minister with my opinion. There is no correspondence, verbal or written, between my office and the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government's office or the Prime Minister's office. The letter is in my office. It has always been in my office. It has not left my office. I think the House would best be facilitated if I were to agree that the member for Corio should come and view the letter and then I am happy to table it if that seems like an appropriate action to take.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, under standing order 152, I have a question for you. Would you consider and advise the House whether it is a breach of privilege for a member's letter to a state minister to be released to the press in an attempt to embarrass that member, so putting at risk the privacy of individuals and creating a climate where members are restricted in performing their duties as members of parliament because they are unable to rely on the professionalism and discretion of state ministers, as has been the case with the release by the South Australian police minister of letters from the member for O'Connor?
—I do not believe that there is any action that has been taken by the member for O'Connor, or the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, which breaches privilege.
—No, Mr Speaker, that was not the—
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker—
—The member for Sturt will resume his seat for a moment. I will hear the point of order.

—The point of order is that the member for Sturt has raised a matter of privilege on the assumption that the letters were released to the media. In fact, the letters were tabled in the House with the permission of the government.
—The member for Werriwa will resume his seat. He has no point of order. I heard him out, but it is not a point of order. If I have misunderstood the member for Sturt, I will hear him again.

—Mr Speaker, with due respect, my question was not about the actions of the member for O'Connor but about the actions of the South Australian police minister and whether he has restricted our behaviour as members of parliament.
—I have indicated to the member for Sturt that I do not believe that there is any case for any action to be taken on the part of the Speaker's office in the matter he alludes to.
—I would have thought that the member for Batman would not want to create a vacancy in the House either right now, from his own short-term perspective.

debate.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (4.25 p.m.)—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek your assistance pursuant to standing order 150 concerning outstanding questions. All three of my outstanding questions involve the Treasurer, who is otherwise described as the Minister representing the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. The three questions are: No. 636, which first appeared on the Notice Paper on 19 August 2002; No. 937, which appeared on the Notice Paper on 19 September 2002; and No. 1434, which appeared on the Notice Paper on 11 February 2003. This is the second time I have had to raise these matters and I would seek your assistance on the reasons for the delay.
—I will follow up the matter raised by the member for Hasluck as standing order 150 provides.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member for Dawson claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The member for Dawson may proceed.
—In the House last night, the member for Batman, speaking in the Telstra debate, spoke of:

quote.para: ... the carpet outside the doors of the offices of the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services have been worn out by the lobbying done by the financial community, demanding the full sale of Telstra.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: Perhaps the member for Dawson would like to talk about whether or not undue influence was brought on her with respect to the issue of ethanol.

speech.para: This was a slur on my integrity. Despite repeated requests from me and the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, who is at the table, the member for Batman refused to withdraw. I do not react to undue influence. I have had no undue influence on me.

talk.start.para: —The member for Dawson has indicated where she was misrepresented.
—I categorically reject the member for Batman's assertions.
—The member for Dawson will resume her seat.

subdebateinfo.title: Parliamentary Departments: Proposed Department of Parliamentary Services

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, under standing order 152, my question is addressed to you.
—Standing order 152?
—I beg your pardon. I was not questioning what you were saying. I did not hear whether it was 150 or 152, and that is why I sought clarification.

—Mr Speaker, on Thursday last week you introduced a motion into this House regarding the abolition of three parliamentary departments and the creation of a new super Department of Parliamentary Services.

question.para: As you know, I first became aware of your notice of motion when the daily program was delivered at 8.45 last Thursday, and your motion was not foreshadowed in the draft daily program, nor was my office provided with a copy of your notice of motion. I have now ascertained that the members for Calare, New England and Kennedy were also left out of the loop on this important issue. In other words, the four members on the crossbenches, who between them represent more than 330,000 Australians, were excluded from the debate. In view of this turn of events, Mr Speaker, I would be grateful if you could outline what steps, if any, you have put in place to ensure that all members are provided with timely information on matters to be brought before this House.

talk.start.para: —Let me respond to the member for Cunningham because he raises a serious matter, though I do have to take courteous issue with him over the term `excluded from the debate', given that there were subsequent efforts made to accommodate him. Furthermore, he, along with each of the other Independent members, was notified late last year of the intent to make these changes. I believe he may have been elected just prior to or just after that, but it needs to be said in fairness to my office and the Clerk's office that there was an effort to engage all members in what was proposed, not to exclude them.

answer.para: The member for Cunningham is, however, right to point out that, in the effort made by my office to consult the whips about the matter that was being discussed, the Independent members were inadvertently excluded—but excluded only from the notice of the 9 o'clock motion, not of the intent to in fact reduce the number of departments. My office has apologised to the member for Cunningham and I have instructed my office to reorder our own mailing list to ensure that it embraces not only the whips but all of the Independent members.

I must restate that while I regret what happened there was no way in which the Independent members were left outside the loop of the actions proposed. They were however frustrated in the opportunity to participate in a debate of which there was little notice. So I subsequently recognised the member for Cunningham and I must say—all credit to the opposition whip, the government whip and members who were participating in the adjournment debate—that an opportunity was given for the member for Cunningham to play a role through other members reducing their time.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the report entitled Report 395: Review of the draft Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—This report presents the committee's review of an exposure draft of the Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill. The review commenced following a proposal from the Minister for Finance and Administration. The committee has had an ongoing interest in the Commonwealth's financial framework, having recommended in 1995 that the government introduce accrual budgeting. The committee most recently reviewed the accrual budget documentation in 2002. The committee believes that the review of the draft bill will identify at an early stage any changes that are needed and will expedite passage of the bill when it is introduced in parliament.

speech.para: The bill is very long. It proposes amendments to 108 acts and the repeal of 28 acts. Some of the amendments introduced by the bill cover technical matters, such as the nature of and framework for special accounts, which record amounts in the consolidated revenue fund designated for specific purposes. The committee has concluded that the bill will make an important contribution to improving the financial framework by aligning references in many acts to financial management with the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, by updating provisions to reflect good practice and by clarifying other provisions.

However, the committee has recommended some changes to the draft bill with a view to further improving the financial framework legislation. These include the inclusion of enhanced information in determinations of the finance minister, made under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, to establish a special account and a change of name from `special account' to `designated purpose account'. The committee also considered whether reporting in the Commonwealth will be improved by the bill. In relation to special accounts, the committee has noted improvements in reporting to parliament for 2003-04. However, it will keep a watching brief on actual improvements to ensure that greater transparency and accountability to parliament is achieved.

The committee is of the firm belief that the Commonwealth Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill is important to underpin the efficient and effective management of the Commonwealth's resources and for promoting good practice. The bill, with the changes recommended by the committee, will bring this framework up to date. Consequently, the bill should be introduced into parliament as soon as is feasible.

In conclusion, I would like to express the committee's appreciation to those people who contributed to the inquiry by preparing submissions and giving evidence at the public hearing. I thank the Department of Finance and Administration and the Australian National Audit Office. They made important and useful contributions to the inquiry by making available their technical expertise to the committee. I also wish to thank the members of the sectional committee involved for their time and dedication in conducting this inquiry. Finally, I thank the secretariat staff: the acting secretary to the committee, Mr James Catchpole; inquiry secretary, Dr John Carter; research staff, Mr Gavin Ford and Ms Suzanne Hinchcliffe; and administrative staff, Ms Maria Pappas. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I want to begin my contribution by thanking the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit secretariat staff and all of the sectional committee members as well as a number of other staff, including Jane McGill from Senator Conroy's office, who were involved in the research for and preparation of the report. As the member for La Trobe said, it is a very long and complex piece of legislation and we did have some very long and interesting meetings discussing the legislation and what should be included in the report. The member for La Trobe covered the recommendations. I do not want to go over that ground again. I do want to draw the attention of the parliament to chapter 6 of this report. The committee did not make formal recommendations in that chapter but it includes some of the areas where the most interesting debate took place.

speech.para: Chapter 6 refers to the committee's consideration of whether the final budget outcome should be audited. It also looks at whether the GFS accounting standards should be published. These are areas where we had a great deal of discussion. The final budget outcome is no longer audited by the Auditor-General, despite a recommendation of the audit committee. Audit report No. 388 suggested that the final budget outcome should be audited by the ANAO. The ANAO has indicated that it is willing to audit the final budget outcome but, of course, it says that that is a policy issue for the government to decide. It is a policy issue; it is something that a great number of people on this side of the House would support. Indeed, Labor has given the commitment that, on returning to government, it would audit the final budget outcome. The other issue relating to the auditing of the final budget outcome is timing. The government's main criticism of the idea of auditing the final budget outcome is that this would push out the reporting dates. It is worth noting that New Zealand manages to do this and to do it on time and, until the legislation was changed in 1997, we also managed to do it.

In relation to the setting down of the GFS accounting standards under which the budget is prepared, a number of the issues that were raised at the time of the last budget—including the overstatement of the value of Telstra by $7 billion and the understatement of the superannuation liabilities of the Commonwealth—show why it is very important that the standards under which the budget is prepared are clear and available to everyone to read. It is certainly something that the committee gave a great deal of consideration to. The committee have suggested that it is important that the rules be published, and we say in 6.12:

quote.para: This requirement should, in the future, be reinstated through an amendment to the Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill—

speech.para: that is, auditing the budget bottom line. The report continues:

quote.para: In order for the Auditor-General to perform an audit the harmonised accounting rules under which the budget is prepared in Australia need to be published as does any subsequent amendment to these rules.

speech.para: There were a number of other very interesting recommendations in this report. I hope that the government will take note of them. We certainly spent enough time and energy working out what should go into it. I commend the report to the parliament.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fifth, sixth and seventh reports of the committee for 2003 relating to the redevelopment of the Australian Institute of Sport, Bruce, ACT; the provision of facilities for the co-location and re-equipping of 1st Aviation Regiment at Robertson Barracks, Darwin; and the RAAF Base Tindal perimeter security fence, Katherine, Northern Territory.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the House. I will first discuss the committee's fifth report of 2003, entitled Redevelopment of the Australian Institute of Sport, Bruce, Australian Capital Territory. The purpose of these proposed works is to provide facilities at Bruce capable of supporting elite athlete training and, more generally, to enable the Australian Sports Commission to fulfil its statutory role in developing Australian sport. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $65.4 million. As the Commonwealth agency responsible for the development of participation in sport at both the elite and the community levels, the Australian Sports Commission seeks to maintain and develop its reputation and capabilities as a world leader in sports development; as a national centre of excellence in elite sports development, training and education; as a national leader in the development of Australian sport; and in the delivery and expansion of sports training and development services.

speech.para: The proposed refurbishment of the Australian Institute of Sport will also enable the Sports Commission to deliver the federal government's 10-year plan for Australian sport: Backing Australia's Sporting Ability—A More Active Australia, which was announced in April 2001. The work is necessitated chiefly by the fact that many of the facilities at Bruce are around 20 years old and are no longer adequate for their purpose. Many training facilities are outdated and no longer provide athletes with a competitive advantage in international competition. Much of the office and residential accommodation is substandard, cannot accommodate current technologies and work practices and, in some cases, does not meet occupational health and safety requirements. The ad hoc nature of past development and refurbishment also means that facilities require rationalisation to increase amenity and efficiency.

Works required to meet the Sports Commission's objectives comprise new residential, dining and education facilities for athletes; a new AIS service hub comprising a range of new testing and training facilities; the upgrade of technology and the airconditioning of training halls and the AIS Arena; extension of the gymnastics hall; a new combat sports facility; an aquatic testing and training facility; improvements to the existing pool complex; an upgrade of trunk engineering and support infrastructure as required; and any necessary demolition. Members of the committee inspected the site of the proposed works and noted particularly the necessity of upgrading the athletes' dining and residential facilities. While there were no major concerns raised in relation to the Sports Commission's proposal, the committee was interested to hear how any delay or alteration to the construction of the new Gungahlin Drive may affect the project.

The committee was informed that the road alignment agreed upon by the ACT government and the National Capital Authority was also the alignment preferred by the Australian Institute of Sport as it will minimise noise and air pollution impacts on the campus. The Australian Sports Commission stated that it would be concerned should the route of Gungahlin Drive be altered. The committee also wished to know if the Sports Commission anticipated any impact upon project costs and timing to result from increased competitiveness in the Canberra construction sector following the recent bushfires. The Sports Commission replied that it believed local industry would be able to meet the demands of the project and added that the bulk of construction works would not commence for some 18 months, when more normal industry conditions may be expected to prevail.

I now move to the committee's sixth report for 2003, entitled Provision of facilities for the collocation and re-equipping of the 1st Aviation Regiment at Robertson Barracks, Darwin, NT. The report addresses a range of new facilities necessary to support the relocation to Robertson Barracks of the 1st Aviation Regiment and the equipping of the regiment for the introduction into service of the new Tiger reconnaissance helicopters. The cost of the proposed works is estimated at $75 million. The defence policy white paper—Defence 2000—confirmed the need to improve the firepower, protection and mobility of Australia's ground forces. To meet this requirement, Defence intends that two squadrons of armed reconnaissance helicopters should be introduced into service by 2004-05.

The armed reconnaissance aircraft will be a significant new capability for Defence. Twenty-two Tiger helicopters are to be procured under the armed reconnaissance helicopter project, 17 of which will be operated by the 1st Aviation Regiment. The restructuring and co-location of the regiment is necessary to optimise the combat power of this capability. At present the 1st Aviation Regiment is spread across several Australian military bases, with its headquarters, surveillance and technical support squadrons based at Oakey in Queensland, one reconnaissance squadron and an operational support squadron at RAAF Base Darwin and a second reconnaissance squadron at Lavarack Barracks in Queensland. Under the proposed new arrangements the regiment will be organised into five squadrons, all of which will be accommodated at Robertson Barracks.

The decision to base the armed reconnaissance aircraft at Robertson Barracks also provides operational synergies with the 1st Brigade's ready deployment formation, located at RAAF Base Darwin. This unit has the high-mobility capability most consistent with the 1st Aviation Regiment's intended capability. Works required to meet the defence objective include 1st Aviation Regiment headquarters facilities; a logistics precinct; an aircraft repair and maintenance workshop; a vehicles and stores repair and maintenance workshop; hangars and shelters for aircraft; training facilities, including a flight simulator; associated engineering services; and living-in accommodation for 110 personnel.

It is anticipated both by Defence and by the Northern Territory Department of Business, Industry and Resource Development that the works will be of immediate benefit to the local economy. It is Defence's intention to adopt a contracting methodology that will maximise opportunities for local small to medium enterprises to become involved in the project. It is estimated that some 150 personnel will be employed on site during the two-year construction phase of the works, with further job opportunities being generated off-site from the manufacture and supply of materials and equipment. Some issues relating to the defence proposal were raised by the Northern Territory Regional Airspace Users Advisory Committee and Darwin International Airport.

Specific concerns held by these bodies included air safety implications of the defence proposal, the potential for Tiger helicopters operating from Robertson Barracks to disrupt civil aviation operations at Darwin airport and the ongoing validity of defence arrangements in relation to the proposed helicopter flight path. Both written and verbal evidence received by the committee demonstrated that Defence is aware of the issues surrounding air traffic management and is working to address them. At the public hearing, Defence stated that the results of a safety case investigation into airspace management at Robertson Barracks had just become available to the effect that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority approved the defence proposal. Written confirmation of this approval was subsequently forwarded to the committee, to the Northern Territory Regional Airspace Users Advisory Committee and to Darwin International Airport.

Defence stated further that it had made a policy commitment that, excepting emergency or conflict situations, civil aircraft in the Darwin area would be given priority at all times. Defence assured the committee that Tiger helicopters would use Robertson Barracks as a departure and arrival point only. It is proposed that the aircraft will follow a specified flight corridor to undertake operations well away from residential and environmentally sensitive areas. Both Defence and officers of the Northern Territory government stated that the future development of the land below the proposed flight corridor for residential use was unlikely.

In view of the approval of the aviation safety case and Defence's commitment to the resolution of any future air traffic management issues, the committee recommends that the work proposed for the collocation and re-equipping of the 1st Aviation Regiment and Robertson Barracks proceed at a cost of $75 million. I wish to thank the people who assisted the committee during the inspection and public hearing. They certainly made matters a lot easier.

The third and final report to which I must refer is entitled RAAF base Tindal perimeter security fence, Katherine, NT—as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, being a member of that committee. The objective of the project is to enhance security at RAAF Base Tindal by means of an alarmed perimeter security fence some 13.9 kilometres in length. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $9.25 million. The defence submission identifies three principal elements which constitute the need for the proposed perimeter security fence—namely, the protection of defence property and capability, the prevention of injury claims, and the inadequacy of the current security arrangements.

As the home base of 75th Squadron, a tactical fighter squadron equipped with FA18 Hornet aircraft, RAAF Base Tindal plays a key role in maintaining Australia's air combat capability. Loss or damage of base property and aircraft through theft or sabotage could impair the base's ability to fulfil its role. Protection of the base and the aircraft is therefore essential. As the base perimeter is not adequately controlled and signposted, there is also concern that injury to persons entering the area may give rise to damages claims against Defence.

Security at RAAF Base Tindal currently consists of a passive, or non-alarmed, fence which is patrolled by defence personnel and guarded at key points during times of increased security. The existing fence does not comply with the present defence security policy, is poorly sited and is inadequate as a deterrent to, and an indicator of, intrusion. Works associated with the construction of the new perimeter fence will include a weldmesh security fence equipped with intruder detection systems and security cameras; a standard cattle fence outside the security fence to prevent activation of the alarm by livestock; a sealed, all-weather access road inside the fence; a maintenance track/firebreak outside the fence; a computerised control system located inside the base; and civil works, including culverts and drainage channels.

Prior to the public hearing, Defence informed the committee of four major changes that had arisen to the construction plan for the new fence. I just noticed that the member for Lingiari is now in the chamber. Clearly this is a matter that has a great impact upon him and his constituents. The changes include amendment of the fence alignment to reduce the overall length from 17.7 kilometres to 13.9 kilometres and to provide improved access to Katherine's civil air terminal, the use of weldmesh instead of chain mesh, the installation of an intruder detection system with security cameras in place of taut wire technology, and sealing of the proposed all-weather road. Defence believes that these alterations to the original proposal will improve the through-life costs and performance of the fence.

At the public hearing, Defence explained that the fence would be designed to a British standard, which is more stringent than the comparable Australian standard and would also comply with the relevant sections of a raft of national and departmental codes, standards and regulations. In response to a request from committee members, Defence confirmed in writing the currency of all applicable policy guidance documents.

At the hearing, the committee noted that changes to the original fence alignment had resolved potential difficulties associated with public access to the Tindal civil terminal. The Mayor of Katherine, who was present at the hearing, indicated his support for the proposal. In considering the culvert design proposed by Defence, committee members expressed concern that, without rigorous maintenance, waterborne debris may block the steel security screens and undermine the fence structure during times of high water. Defence witnesses concurred and assured the committee that the issue would be addressed under the proposed maintenance plan.

In view of the harsh climatic conditions prevailing in the Katherine region, the committee was interested to know the expected design life of the fence and its components. Following the hearing, Defence supplied a document indicating a life expectancy of between 10 and 15 years for the detection technology and cameras, 20 years for the all-weather road, and up to 50 years for the culverts, poles and plinths. At the request of the committee, Defence also supplied a detailed cost breakdown of the impact of the proposed design amendments upon the total project budget. Having reviewed this information, the committee recommends that the works proposed for the construction of the RAAF Base Tindal perimeter security fence proceed at the estimated cost of $9.25 million.

Once again, I would like to thank all those involved in the inspections and hearings conducted at Tindal and in Darwin and in the reporting process. I also record the committee's special thanks to the secretariat, which assisted us in tabling these reports today.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I commend the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works for the work they have done in Darwin and Katherine in the Northern Territory, especially in relation to Tindal. I am very pleased that the committee were able to bring themselves to support this very important work. The base at Tindal is state-of-the-art. It is the newest of our Air Force bases. It houses the FA18 squadron which went to the Middle East. It is a very important component of the infrastructure for Katherine and the Northern Territory. Works of this nature are very important. The size of the Tindal base, its proximity to Katherine, the number of people who work on the base as employees of the Department of Defence as Air Force personnel and as civilians make it very important to the local economy.

speech.para: In passing, I note that this work was announced with much fanfare by the government in last year's budget and nothing happened. They announced it again this year, so they are trying to get a double hit out of it. We exposed that to the Katherine community—as you would expect—because as a result of the announcement in last year's budget their expectations had been built up to believe that this would have happened in the last 12 months, instead of in the current 12-month period. But, nevertheless, it is most welcome work and it will be seen as important work for the Katherine community.

This work is extremely important for the upgrading of the Defence installation at Tindal. As the deputy chair of the Public Works Committee has properly pointed out, the very rational and important reasons given for this upgrade by the defence department need to be applauded. I thank the committee for its recommendation that this work should commence.
