talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: The proposed government amendments to the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 were foreshadowed in the Main Committee of this House, successfully passed in the upper house and have now returned to this House for the final stage of the debate.

The amendments give effect to what was always an intention of the Air Services Act 1995, to allow Airservices Australia to pursue commercial opportunities that make the most of the infrastructure and expertise that Airservices Australia has developed. They amend the definitions of services and facilities in the Air Services Act 1995 to ensure that Airservices Australia can take advantage of commercial opportunities as they arise from time to time and, as part of this, allow Airservices Australia to use spare capacity to maintain or improve the technical skills of its employees.

It is, however, important to note that the main intentions in the Air Services Act 1995 have not been compromised. While it is all very well to allow Airservices Australia to take advantage of commercial opportunities both here and overseas, in fact it is a compliment to Airservices Australia that the government recognises its position as a world leader in the field and capable of competing in a world market.

The amendments make clear that Airservices Australia must continue to have the provision of services and facilities in relation to Australian administered airspace as its priority. The Australian government has international obligations for providing air navigation services, and Airservices Australia is still the means by which they will be delivered. More importantly, the commitment of the government to air safety will in no way be compromised by Airservices Australia being given greater commercial freedom. Any functions carried out by Airservices Australia will always be subject to the requirement under the Air Services Act 1995 that safety of air navigation be Airservices Australia's first consideration.

The government has also made it clear that there is no intention or scope in these amendments to change any other aspect of either Airservices Australia's governance or the domestic environment in which Airservices Australia provides its facilities and services. It is, as I have already said, a testimony to the high-quality expertise and proficiency that Airservices Australia has developed that the government has such confidence in its ability to compete in a global market. I therefore seek the agreement of the House to the proposed amendments to the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 for these new provisions in the Air Services Act 1995.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the opposition to clearly indicate that we support the government's amendments to this important bill. As I indicated to the House in my speech in the second reading debate on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 2003, the amendments enhance the capacity of Airservices Australia to pursue work in related fields in Australia and we hope, importantly, to aggressively pursue export dollar opportunities overseas.

speech.para: I think it is fair to say that these changes were encouraged by the opposition to help Airservices to tap their potential. I consider that there is significant untapped potential with respect to the operation of Airservices at this point in time. There is now the challenge to Airservices to take up the opportunities provided by this bill and the amendments thereto. Those potential challenges include significant national income and high skill and employment opportunities which have been forgone in days gone by because there was a barrier to such opportunities being pursued on the export front.

For far too long the Howard government have had Airservices focused on an inward basis, on watching their back against the fear of phoney competition. They have had Airservices focused on improving efficiency by cutting costs and functions. When we talk about functions we ought to think about what types of functions are at the centre of the debate this afternoon. The government stand condemned for the phoney competition that they have been promoting in recent years, while they have walked away from the challenge and the opportunity to pursue the amendments before the House this afternoon. These functions are fundamental to air safety in Australia. We have had an attack on Airservices' capacity to provide these functions for the travelling public in Australia.

We are talking about air traffic services, aeronautical information services, aeronautical radio navigation services, aeronautical telecommunications services and, last but not least, rescue and firefighting services. Over recent years we have had a government that has been prepared to put at risk the provision of those services through a phoney competition war effectively for which the government stands condemned.

I am going to raise another aspect of this debate this afternoon with respect to the future of Airservices Australia's terminal control units. I am looking for an answer this afternoon from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration as to whether or not the proposed closure of the Sydney, Adelaide and associated TCUs is still on the agenda. I think it is about time the travelling public and the workers in those centres were told about their future. It is not about employment alone; it is also about safety in the air.

As I said, this phoney war has unfortunately put at risk the travelling public. We are talking about fundamental safety functions, and the government's negative, regressive approach with respect to the provision of Airservices' functions in Australia is a disgrace. Labor not only defends the need to provide those services in Australia but also advocates efficiency improvements of air services by encouraging Airservices Australia to grow both internationally and domestically and, in doing so, to pursue work opportunities both at home and abroad.

Airservices Australia has a highly specialised and skilled staff and cutting edge technology. As shadow minister, I am exceptionally proud of the functions provided by the employees of Airservices Australia. They have put in place a system that is a world leader. That is something that we ought to be proud of in Australia. We ought to aggressively pursue export earning opportunities on the international front, which in turn has the capacity to lead to the skilling of more Australians, enabling them to take up highly skilled employment opportunities in a range of centres around Australia.

These amendments are about repositioning Airservices Australia for further record rates of achievement. If these amendments are carried, the management of Airservices Australia, the workers employed by Airservices Australia and the travelling public who depend on the functions provided by Airservices Australia can be released from the phoney, narrow competition rhetoric of the Howard government. (Extension of time granted) It is time that these people and this organisation are allowed to get on with what they do best. The opposition believes that these amendments position Airservices Australia to build and grow opportunities for Australia. But it is not enough. There are some other outstanding issues that must also be attended to.

That takes me to Airservices Australia's terminal control units. I bring to the House's attention this afternoon the fact that the minister is pursuing the closure of terminal control units in Sydney, Perth and Adelaide. There is an agenda to close important air traffic control functions and move them and the staff to Melbourne and Brisbane. The Howard government had the same thing in mind for Cairns, but that proposal was withdrawn—not on the basis of any technical advice or consideration but purportedly because of the jobs impact on the region. What about the potential impact on the jobs front if the terminal control unit is withdrawn from Adelaide in the state of South Australia, where employment is always a challenge because of the difficulties that that state has confronted for a number of years?

If it is good enough to make a political decision with respect to the terminal control unit in Cairns because it is at the heart of the marginal coalition seat of Leichhardt—a decision made on the run by the Prime Minister—then I have a very strong view that the time has come for the Howard government to also rule out here and now, this afternoon, the closure of the terminal control units in Sydney, Perth and Adelaide. Why Leichhardt? Because Cairns is in the middle of that marginal coalition seat held by a parliamentary secretary. Why not make the same decision for Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane? The workers in those centres and the travelling public want to know this afternoon what the government's position is with respect to the terminal control units in those centres. It is about jobs and it is about safety in the air.

I believe there is more to this issue than jobs and efficiency. Civil Aviation Authority representatives, in a recent consideration of this matter in an independent report prepared for Airservices Australia, have demonstrated how other efficiencies can be achieved without the inherent safety risks of the minister's proposal. It is very hard, more importantly, to actually find anyone who is lobbying to close the terminal control units other than the minister and the lackeys around him. But this proposal still lives in the minister's office—a direction effectively imposed on Airservices Australia's management.

I urge the minister to actually spend a little bit of time visiting the terminal control units to gain a first-hand understanding, as I have done, of what a valuable job these people do. I urge the minister to actually have a talk to the air traffic control experts who do this job, who protect every one of us every time we get in a plane and travel around Australia. After doing that, any fair-minded person would come to the conclusion that a responsible minister with his eye on the job who actually cares about his ministerial responsibilities would—rather than create a phoney cost-cutting war endangering the travelling public and risking jobs in those key centres—rule out the closure of the terminal control units in Adelaide, Sydney and Perth, just as was done in Cairns. Although perhaps in Cairns it was done for the wrong reason; perhaps there was a political motivation.

But if it is good enough for Cairns then it is good enough for Adelaide, Sydney and Perth, as a number of members on this side of the House have been campaigning for an extended period. Some of those on the other side of the House have also been campaigning with respect to some of these issues. Sentiments have been expressed, for example, by the member for Mackellar in a vigorous way following a presentation of this proposal to members not that long ago.

This in turn takes me to other issues relating to Airservices' operations and their potential operations at Sydney, with the presentation in recent weeks of a Sydney airport master plan. (Extension of time granted) It is incumbent on me, therefore, because of the danger to the future terminal control unit at Sydney, to also make some comments on the Sydney airport master plan this afternoon. This is the first master plan for Sydney airport under the legislation initiated by the Labor government in the mid-1990s. Therefore it is the first time a long-range view of the airport's ambitions have been released for public discussion and consideration.

The master plan takes a 20-year horizon on proposed airport operations and development in the airport precinct and anticipates the implications for the surrounding community and infrastructure. The opposition welcomes the fact that the plan includes our policy to retain the cap, curfew, access for regional airlines and noise sharing measures. The master plan also provides for the intensification of air activities at Sydney airport. That then raises serious questions about the continuation of the noise amelioration program. That in turn raises questions about how the revenue will be raised to further assist in insulating public buildings such as churches and schools and also private dwellings.

It is incumbent on the minister to indicate today whether or not as part of the development of the master plan it is the intention of the government to continue the noise amelioration program, which will become more urgent if this plan is implemented, and also to give an indication as to whether that effectively means that the noise levy which currently applies at Sydney airport—which is about $3.58 per ticket today—will continue to be in operation. The facts show that, to date, about $390 million has been spent on the noise amelioration program and only about $290 million has been recovered from the collection of that levy.

Not only is there outstanding money that has been spent on the program; there is also an expectation from those involved in the consideration of the master plan that the program will continue. They want a clear indication from the government, as part of its consideration of the master plan, as to whether or not it will continue to make funds available to guarantee that, with the development of Sydney airport, those public buildings and homes that are affected by the growth of Sydney airport will receive the same consideration with respect to noise insulation. There should be no approval of the master plan without a very definite statement from the government—sooner rather than later—with respect to the noise insulation program. So far as I am concerned, those issues are not negotiable.

Labor also welcomes the fact that the plan includes its policy with respect to trying to do something about sharing the noise. However, the plan does not envisage a second airport during the planning period. This is based on the assumption by the airport operators that the projected growth will be acceptable to the Sydney community. That is unacceptable to the opposition. The opposition believes a second airport is needed and that the type of second airport and its location must be determined with all the facts and views on the table. This is not only about the future of Sydney airport—it is not just an airport issue—but also about the environment and whether or not the area around Sydney airport will, in the future, be regarded by people as desirable to live in. It must be taken seriously by the government.

What we require is a second airport as part of an integrated transport approach that involves all tiers of government—local, state and federal. Determining a site by government must be part of an open, transparent process and not pre-determined—because this is what the master plan is about—by a private sector company that desires to maintain a monopolistic position. The opposition does not accept that this growth will be acceptable to Sydneysiders, with the master plan envisaging the number of passengers using Sydney airport to exceed the number of passengers who used Heathrow airport in 2001.

Where do we go from here? There is a 90-day time frame for the community and local and state governments to digest the impact of the airport plans. (Extension of time granted) So I say to the minister this afternoon that it is my firm view as the shadow transport minister that, before the minister agrees to the master plan, the government must bring forward its own review of Sydney's airport needs. The government simply cannot wait until 2005, as planned by the minister. The Sydney airport master plan has changed all that.

I also suggest that the proposed sale of Bankstown, Hoxton Park and Camden be put on ice. We now have the master plan proposal for Sydney airport, which goes to the horizons for the operation of that airport for 20 years. I believe that before those three GA airports in Sydney are sold—Bankstown, Hoxton Park and Camden—similar master plan proposals must be prepared and considered, if they are to be sold at all in the future. The position of the opposition is that they should never be sold. There is a capacity for government to continue to work out how these airports operate and have some influence on them with respect to their impact on local communities.

I also have some very serious worries about the development of the master plan to date and the government's reaction. Before the Howard government ticks off the private sector plan for Sydney airport, I think it is incumbent on the government to do its own independent assessment about sustainability and about the impact on the Sydney community. It is not the responsibility of the airport owners to say how this will impact on the insulation program and levy and how many houses and buildings will need insulation under the Sydney Airport Corporation plan. But it is definitely the responsibility of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services that information be gathered to test the veracity and integrity of the master plan. That has to be part of the process of consultation. There is a 90-day consultation period with the community. On my figuring that means that the master plan in draft form will land on the desk of the minister on 31 December this year. The Airports Act intends that the consideration of this master plan be done in an honest way. The minister then has 90 days to indicate whether he accepts or rejects the Sydney airport master plan.

What worries me are the statements made in recent days by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. They have effectively already made up their minds; they have effectively already embraced the draft master plan's intentions and method of operation. There have been a range of comments made in the public arena by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to that effect. On the basis of the draft master plan, which is out for public consultation and discussion, they have effectively embraced the view of its general manager, Mr Max Moore-Wilton—a close friend of the Prime Minister. Basically, they have accepted, on the basis of the information provided by the master plan, that there is no requirement for there ever to be a second airport built in Sydney. I regard that as totally unacceptable in terms of how a minister should regard his responsibility under the Airports Act. I take the view that under the act you are required to consider the report in a proper way. That means, in essence, that when it lands on your desk on 31 December you are required—

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—You are therefore required to await the draft master plan before effectively ticking it off in the public arena. I say this because the comments of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services in recent weeks raise serious questions about the integrity of the process currently under way and whether or not they are approaching the final consideration of this master plan with clean hands. That raises serious questions about the legality of the processes and whether or not—based on the public comments to date indicating their acceptance of the presumptions laid out in the draft master plan—the consideration by the minister might be challenged in the courts. (Extension of time granted) I raise these issues this afternoon, and I will continue to make comments on very important issues going to the operation of Sydney airport and the importance of Airservices Australia.

—I will not be gagged by you or anybody else. As I said, these are very important issues going to safety in the air, the operation of airports around Australia and the legislative framework dealing with the operation of these airports. I simply make the point today that we are watching the development of the Sydney airport master plan very closely. There are serious questions about whether the process has been corrupted and prejudiced by comments made to date by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. This could lead to legal challenges with respect to the final determination of the issues by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

speech.para: These are important issues. The development of the Sydney airport master plan ought to be a proper process undertaken at arm's length from the government. We should not forget that the report is prepared to embrace the Macquarie Bank's ambitions and to `max out' Sydney airport. We do not accept the proposals embodied in the master plan. It is about time we had some integrity with respect to these processes. This brings me to other important employment issues and the question of Ansett workers.

talk.start.para: —Oh God.

—Australian workers who were employed by Ansett Airlines—some of them live in the member opposite's seat of North Sydney—and their families have had a gutful of the legal wrangling, delays and politicking over the collapse of their jobs, careers and opportunities. This is the 100th anniversary of air services—and the member for North Sydney thinks the plight of Ansett workers is a joke.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Batman just made an allegation against me that is plainly not true. I do care deeply about Ansett workers. I ask him to withdraw his allegation against me or move a substantive motion.
(Hon. B.C. Scott)—I have heard the member for North Sydney—
—I was responding to his interjection. It was not offensive and I am not withdrawing it.
—I ask you to facilitate the House.
—I am asking you what was offensive about it. He made an interjection and I responded.
—I didn't make an interjection.
—When I mentioned Ansett workers, you sighed and said, `Oh God' or something like that.

—Order! Member for Batman, your allegation was, as I heard it—although I was concentrating on some other matters to come before the House later—that the member for North Sydney did not care about Ansett workers. Member for Batman, will you withdraw?
—If the member for North Sydney takes offence, I will withdraw it to facilitate the House. I know that he is a very sensitive little flower.
—What do you mean `little'?
—The emphasis was on `flower'.
—The member for Batman will not abuse the privileges that he has.

— This week we have learned that the superannuation court case will now go to another level in the legal process. The Minister for Small Business and Tourism might sigh. He sighs because it is going through legal challenges. This is about the entitlements of workers and the impact on their families. The minister might sigh because it is not a big issue to him. While the court processes must run their course, it is time the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Minister for Small Business and Tourism showed some empathy and acknowledged the plight of these workers and their families.

speech.para: These families are no different from families affected by drought or salinity, and we have seen how the government reacts when those challenges confront the Australian community. I believe that Ansett workers should be treated in the same sympathetic way as farmers who are confronted by drought or as industry is confronted by the issues of salinity, as you would appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott. After a concerted campaign by the opposition, the minister finally kicked off the Ansett ticket tax. But we got to a position where it was being collected under false pretences; it was purported to be for the benefit of the very workers and their families to whom I am referring today. (Extension of time granted) The Ansett ticket tax continued beyond its expected time, but the workers are not getting a cent of that levy. I see this approach by the Howard government as disgraceful, divisive and irresponsible. We are talking about air services and the provision of activities around Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is nothing in these amendments that discusses the Ansett—
—What is your point of order?

—It is about relevance. Nothing in these amendments has anything to do with the Ansett levy, and yet the member for Batman is waxing on and misleading the House about what is being done with the Ansett levy. I ask you to bring him back to the matter before the House.

—I will rule on the point of order. I have heard the member for North Sydney. From both sides of the House from time to time a wide ranging debate occurs as a result of legislation. This is a debate on the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003, and I know that from time to time both sides of the House are given latitude.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker; I agree with your ruling. I will not take offence because I want to facilitate the debate by referring to some comments made by the minister in his point of order. The government itself has acknowledged that it made a profit out of the Ansett workers' ticket tax. We even have the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Minister for Small Business and Tourism now having a brawl about the surplus and how it is to be spent. I actually believe that some of it should be spent on airport security.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that you draw to the attention of the House the point where in the amendments there is any reference whatsoever to the Ansett levy. There is no reference whatsoever and, given that we are in committee, I ask that you bring the member for Batman back to the amendments before the House, because this is totally unrelated to the amendments before the House.
—I hear the honourable member for North Sydney. The member for Batman would facilitate the debate if he could keep his comments confined to the amendments to the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 2003.

—The honourable minister is proving his ignorance with respect to the operation of the airline industry in Australia. The issue of air services is very serious. It concerns the provision of functions such as rescue and firefighting services, aeronautical skill and communications services, aeronautical radio and navigation services, aeronautical information services and air traffic services—very important functions. They go to the operation of Sydney airport, the safety of the travelling public and the need to make sure that we protect icons such as Qantas—and unfortunately acknowledge the passing of what was also an icon, Ansett. Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, you would understand the importance of these issues as a frequently travelled person.

speech.para: In conclusion, I say that all I want is some public accountability from the Howard government about the Ansett ticket tax levy proceeds. I know that on the other side of the House there is a brawl going on with respect to how those proceeds should be spent. I simply say that, in terms of the airline industry in Australia—I know that the member for Braddon considers this to be a very serious issue and he intended raising it this afternoon—some of those proceeds ought to be spent on the industry and its security, such as the government facilitating the provision of screening services at Burnie and Devonport airports; I do not want to steal the thunder of the member for Braddon. It is time that Ansett workers and their families are shown some compassion by the federal government, that the government comes clean on the collection of the levy and that there is some public accountability with respect to the surplus. It is also time that those workers are given a full and proper explanation of the superannuation case and how it impacts on the Ansett ticket tax levy proceeds and the federal government's profits from the tax.

This has been a long and important debate, and I thank the House for the opportunity and its generosity. As at the outset of my remarks I said I would do, I have ranged across a number of important issues this afternoon which are central to the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003—and perhaps the Minister for Small Business and Tourism does not appreciate how complex and far reaching this bill is. The amendments are fully supported by the opposition. It was the opposition that actually campaigned for these amendments, and the minister has again shown his ignorance. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism

talk.start.para: —I just want to clarify for the House some matters raised by the member for Batman. The matter which needs to be addressed specifically relates to the master plan for Sydney airport, the long-term operating plan and, of course, the government's commitment to a second airport at Badgerys Creek.
—Does that stand?

—I will come to that in a moment, so just relax. Because my seat in North Sydney is more affected by aircraft noise than almost any other seat in Sydney, I am obviously very concerned about the matter and will continue to monitor closely a number of issues relating to Sydney airport.

speech.para: I make these points: the first is that there is a draft master plan for Sydney airport which has been released by Sydney airport. As I understand it, it was considered at the last meeting of the Sydney Airport Community Forum, which my representative attended. I am deeply disappointed that a number of members of the Labor Party have chosen to remove themselves from the Sydney Airport Community Forum, which has been, since 1996, the master consultative forum for representatives of the Sydney community affected by aircraft noise. In that regard, the member for Batman might want to display leadership in relation to Sydney airport. God forbid that he should display real leadership, because to date he has only got his leader into trouble in relation to the second airport in Sydney—but let us give him another chance. `Second Chance Martin' we call him. We want to give him a second chance.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing orders provide that members have to be addressed through the chair by the name of their seat. If he wants to start this, he has a few nicknames too.

—I will correct it: `Second Chance Batman'. In that regard, I think it is important that the member for Batman encourage the member for Grayndler, the member for Watson and a few of his other colleagues to start attending the Sydney Airport Community Forum, where very important issues such as the master plan are being considered. I have had a chance to have a brief look at the draft master plan and, whilst it makes projections for massive increases not just in the volume of passengers but also in the volume of air traffic, I note that in one of the graphs Sydney airport claims that in 2023 the airport will be operating from 6.30 a.m. to 11.30 p.m. at 80 movements per hour and that that is unsustainable. I recognise that, and it is completely inconsistent with the long-term operating plan which this government created, which this government is implementing and which ensures that aircraft noise is fairly shared around Sydney. I will fight like hell to ensure that there is no diminution of the long-term operating plan and a return to the bad old days of Labor's Bennelong funnel, which is obviously now the North Sydney funnel, given that all those areas affected are directly over the suburbs in my electorate.

speech.para: The second point in relation to Sydney airport is that this government is committed to a second airport in Sydney. Existing government policy is to commit to a second airport in Sydney at Badgerys Creek, with a review in 2005. That is the policy that we have had for the last two elections. That is the commitment that we have made, and that is our existing policy. It is a commitment to a second airport in the Sydney basin at Badgerys Creek, with a review of the need for it in 2005. That is the policy that we have had since the 1996 election, and it is entirely consistent with the fact that we legislated the cap of 80 movements per hour at Sydney airport, that we legislated the curfew at Sydney airport and that, through legislation, we ensured that regional aircraft will be able to access Sydney airport. (Extension of time granted) We have guaranteed a minimum number of slots at Sydney airport to regional airlines so that they will under no circumstances be pushed out to another airport.

The fundamental point is that the length of viability of Sydney airport will be determined by a number of factors: the curfew, the cap, regional access and the projected volume of aircraft—not necessarily the volume of passengers. Within that framework, the long-term operating plan also needs to be able to continue within the broad framework of the targets that have been set for the fair sharing of aircraft noise around Sydney. That is entirely consistent with what the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and all our members have said. While some members of the government may have different views about the matter in terms of representing their electorates, which is perfectly understandable and totally consistent—and I respect them for defending the interests of their electorates—our policy has not changed.

We are bemused that the Labor Party were the ones that turned the sod of dirt at Badgerys Creek. The Labor Party were the party in government that determined that Badgerys Creek should be the second airport for Sydney. They are the ones who did it. We have followed that path, but we put off the building of a second airport at Badgerys Creek because there was no need for it in the foreseeable future, which is entirely consistent with everything we have said—and now the member for Batman has chosen to make the issue something else. The Labor Party bought the land at Badgerys Creek, designated Badgerys Creek a 24-hour international airport and turned, on numerous occasions, the dirt at Badgerys Creek to begin construction of the second international airport. Now the member for Batman and the member for Hotham are saying, `We are no longer committed to it, and we are going to have a second international airport somewhere in the Sydney basin.' As the Deputy Prime Minister has so eloquently put it, we are waiting to find out just where they are going to put a second international airport in the Sydney basin if it is not at Badgerys Creek.

talk.start.para: —That is exactly what the Labor Party have said: they are going to put a second international airport somewhere in the Sydney basin, but not at Badgerys Creek. I suggest they go back to one of the people whom they regard highly in the Labor Party as one of the elder statesmen of Australian politics—Edward Gough Whitlam—and ask him about that public meeting in the early seventies where he declared that there was going to be an airport at Goldstein and subsequently lost a by-election. We are intrigued to find out about that, and we look forward to finding out where the member for Batman and his colleagues will put the second airport. We will also be interested to hear the views of the member for Lowe, if the member for Lowe has a view about where the second airport for Sydney should be.

—Just to set the record straight, firstly, what the Labor Party have said is that Sydney needs an integrated transport plan. Secondly, as part of that decision, we have clearly ruled out Badgerys Creek as a second airport site. Thirdly, we have indicated that Sydney needs a second airport. The Labor Party have not said that Sydney needs a second international airport in the Sydney basin. What we now require from the government is a clear statement of their intentions. We have had the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services effectively say over the last three weeks that, on the basis of the Sydney airport master plan, Sydney does not need a second airport. There is a clear divide: the opposition say that Sydney needs a second airport. We have now had the Minister for Small Business and Tourism say that not only will Sydney have Sydney airport but also Badgerys Creek is still alive as a real option in the minds of the government.
—That is what he said.

—That is what he said, and it is on the public record. For the Howard government, Badgerys Creek is their preferred second airport site—black and white. I challenge the House now to get to the bottom of the real position of the Howard government. We had the Minister for Small Business and Tourism say today that, as far as he is concerned, the policy is Sydney airport plus Badgerys Creek. We have heard the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services say in the last couple of weeks, `Sydney will never, ever need a second airport.' We have had the member for Lindsay, a member of the executive as the Prime Minister's parliamentary secretary, saying on numerous occasions over the last couple of years and again in the last couple of weeks that Badgerys Creek will never be built by the Howard government. All I am asking for is a final, honest, conclusive statement from the Howard government. I believe the people in Sydney are entitled to some integrity and some honesty with regard to the issue of Sydney's future requirements not only on the airport front but also for an integrated transport plan.

speech.para: In 1996 the then opposition promised to build a second airport, at Badgerys Creek, upon election. The time has come for them to come clean. Tell the people of Sydney once and for all where they stand. We have had enough of the Howard government's dog whistle approach on a range of issues. They say one thing in one arena and then suggest quietly a different position in another arena. I grew up in Western Sydney and, from day one, basically had instilled in me a fundamental approach to life: tell the truth. We are elected to not only develop decent policies but also tell the truth. The debate about Sydney airport is no longer about whether Sydney needs a second airport; it is about honesty and integrity in government, which is what the electors rightfully expect from their elected representatives. All they are asking for in the lead-up to the next election is a definitive statement with regard to Sydney. Labor's position is clear: Sydney needs a second airport and an integrated transport plan; an airport at Badgerys Creek will not be built by a Labor government. The Minister for Small Business and Tourism has said today, yet again, that the policy position in the minds of the Howard government is that an airport at Badgerys Creek will be built. Come clean, tell the truth and stop lying to the people of Sydney.

talk.start.para: —Tell him to withdraw that.
(Hon. B.C. Scott)—The member for Batman will withdraw the reflection on the minister about lying.
—It was a reflection on the government.
—It was on the minister.
—I ask you to withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will withdraw it. There was no reflection on the minister; there was a reflection on the government.
—I have called on the member for Batman to withdraw it.
—I withdraw the unintended belief in the minister's mind that it was a reflection on him. It was a reflection on the Howard government and its position in Canberra.
—And you withdraw it.
—I have withdrawn the reflection on the minister.
—And the government.
—No, I do not have to.
—The member for Batman would facilitate the House by withdrawing the reflection on the minister and the government.

—I withdraw the reflection on the minister. Although I am not required to facilitate the operation of the House, I will withdraw the reflection on the Howard government. They are very dainty little flowers at the moment.

—Before I call the member for Braddon, I advise the House that, during the committee stage, we are debating the Senate amendments. Badgerys Creek is not mentioned in the Senate amendments. I have allowed the debate and the reply. I now call the member for Braddon and remind him that the question before the House is that the amendments be agreed to.

—In his opening address on the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 the shadow minister, the member for Batman, said that we support these amendments. We support them because they are related to air navigation safety. The safety of air navigation is absolutely crucial in Australia and internationally. I was very pleased, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you allowed the debate to range somewhat: at least half an hour of the debate centred on Sydney airport and its master plan. I point out that I do not come from an area that uses Sydney airport. I come from an area that has two regional airports—Burnie and Devonport—that are very much related to the safety of air navigation. These airports are categorised not as No. 1 but Nos 4 and 5 in terms of security.

speech.para: One of the interesting things I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration, who is at the table, to recognise is that, while he is able to talk about Sydney, its master plan and its security, regional airports do not have any security. That seems to be the hardest thing to get through to the government. I know that I have the support of my colleagues in this place when I say that we should be looking at increasing security at our regional airports. In fact, I am absolutely staggered that we have members in regional seats who never raise the issue of security at their airports. I cannot believe that they are not cognisant of the fact that they do not even have basic screening facilities.

It was very interesting that only the other weekend the Prime Minister visited my electorate. He did not ask permission but just turned up. Out of the 110,000 people who live in that area, the Prime Minister was the only person who had security when he left our airport, and I thought that was a bit rich. What was extraordinary was that when the Prime Minister arrived at our airport a gentleman went out to offer him the red carpet and the security guys jumped him. They said, `You are not getting near our Prime Minister.' But if you live in my area and you want to leave by our aircraft, there is no security for screening people or carry-on luggage—and that is extraordinary.

That is almost dinosaur-like security in this age where we are reminded by the Prime Minister every day that we have terror on our doorstep. It is elasticised terror, to the point of people becoming paranoid about what is going to happen to them. The only thing we have been offered in terms of the safety of our air navigation has been a fridge magnet.

talk.start.para: —And I am sure you have a fridge magnet, and I would appreciate it if you would just listen to what I have to say about it. As I have mentioned before, I have written to the relevant minister three or four times on this issue—
(Hon. B.C. Scott)—Order! The minister will cease interjecting across the table.

—and have not received one jot of ink on the page in response to my questions. That is the type of contempt that this minister, who is responsible for this legislation, this amendment, has for people who want to know what is going to happen in regional Australia to their security—three or four letters, and no response whatsoever. I do not think we got the address wrong.

speech.para: That is the type of contempt that regional Australia is held in by this minister. He is supposed to be responsible for air security and air safety, and we have none at all. I am absolutely staggered that some of his own colleagues, particularly in the National Party, have not raised this issue with him. I believe there is now another inquiry looking at this issue, and one of the terms of reference is to look at the cost impost if security is put into regional airports in Australia. It is not a cost impost; it is an investment in the security of regional Australians. I think the government's stance on this issue is an absolute disgrace.

talk.start.para: —I cannot let go by the invitation made by the member for North Sydney to respond to his contribution when I came into the chamber and observed this debate. Let us put this in perspective because the member for North Sydney understands the seriousness of the impact of aircraft noise and the environmental risks of planes flying over their houses better than most. He was a former chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum and he will remember his famous roadshows where he lost control of the meetings. I have raised this with him on a number of occasions, so he understands it quite clearly. I want to start with this shoddy little document—
—Order! The minister will desist.
—You cannot trust Labor. Tell him to table it. I give him leave to table it.
—I will be happy to table a copy of it.

—Member for Lowe, I said prior to the last speaker, the member for Braddon, that I had allowed the debate to digress from the amendments before the House. I did not intend to let it go beyond that. The relevant question before the House concerns the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 and the Senate's amendments. I ask you to come back to the matter before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, what I have said is very relevant because the issues we are talking about are in reference to the amendments—corporate air traffic services, aeronautical information service, aeronautical radio navigation service and aeronautical telecommunication service, and rescue and fire. It is germane to Sydney airport and to a second airport. I have been verballed here—
—I have ruled that it be germane to air traffic and the amendments before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you might ask the minister to stop interjecting and listen, because he has invited me to respond. Obviously he did not pay any attention to private member's business on Monday when I moved to take the politics out of this very divisive issue, once and for all, by establishing a joint select committee of both chambers of parliament to identify a potential—
—You opposed Badgerys Creek.
—Minister, the member for Lowe has the call.
—Yes, I do oppose Badgerys Creek because, Minister, that will put two major airports in the Sydney basin. But you, like the member for Lindsay, have played very dishonest politics—
—The member for Lowe will address his comments through the chair.

—I am happy to, Mr Deputy Speaker, because the minister knows about this subject only too well, as a former chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum. The government have got themselves in a bind here, because they have the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister making it quite clear on national television and in this House that they do not see that there is going to be a need for a second airport. So what does that mean? I return to this shoddy little leaflet, and I am happy to table a copy of it.
—The member for Lowe will not display the leaflet. He may seek leave to table it.
—Seek leave to table it!
—When I have finished with it, Minister. Just give me a chance and I will give you as many copies as you want.
—Minister, you will not prompt the speaker.

—In 1996 the coalition's aviation policy document titled Soaring into tomorrow, which Minister Hockey would understand quite well, made it quite plain that Sydney airport would not be sold until Sydney's aircraft noise problems were solved. This document—
—I have been quite patient with the member for Lowe. I ask him to come back to the amendments before the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am responding to the invitation of the minister. There has been a wide ranging debate, and this is germane to the debate.
—I allowed the member for Batman to respond, and I gave both sides of the House latitude. I call on the member for Lowe to come back to the question before the House.

—This is a very serious bill and a very serious issue. What we are going to experience in Sydney under the coalition government is no second airport and an expansion by SACL, through the Sydney airport master plan, of air traffic movements to over 400,000 in the next 20 years—a trebling of passengers. This is obviously being done for the interests—(Time expired)

motion.para: That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: —I ask the member for Chifley to withdraw those offensive remarks. They are unparliamentary.
—I withdraw.

debateinfo.title: TELSTRA (TRANSITION TO FULL PRIVATE OWNERSHIP) BILL 2003

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I rise to discuss a bill which has been on the government's agenda for a very long time, the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. This has been the Prime Minister's priority since the coalition took government in 1996. The full sale of Telstra is just another example of the Howard government mentality of `sell first, ask questions later'. However, the full sale of Telstra will hurt many Australians a great deal more than the government cares to admit. Labor opposes the sale of Telstra for this reason.

speech.para: Telstra is important to Australians and Australia. In this place we think it is so important that the bill has been sent to the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee for inquiry. I encourage people who want to have their say to put in a submission to the committee secretariat by 17 September 2003. The web site, if people want to look at it and get the terms of reference and information on how to contact the secretariat, is www.aph.gov.au/senate_environment.

Australia needs a telecommunications infrastructure it can rely on. For decades, telephone technology has been the main way that Australians communicate with each other. The ability for businesses to communicate reliably has been a cornerstone of our economy. Families remaining connected across the continent has been vital to the Australian way of life. Taking Telstra out of public hands takes away the reliability of service that Australians need.

I am not saying anything that most Australians have not already learned for themselves. Since the partial privatisation of Telstra, services have slipped and reliability has fallen. I would challenge any member of the government to have the nerve to say that Telstra issues are not common amongst the constituent representations they get in their electorate offices. The simple truth is that Telstra's quality of service is already reaching unacceptable lows. A full sale of Telstra would only accelerate the process.

Much of the attention in this debate has been given to the rural and regional communities in our nation—and rightly so. Private businesses exist to make a profit, and servicing the remote corners of Australia does not make a profit. Publicly owned organisations have an obligation of equitable service; corporations do not. The Howard government will be selling out regional and rural Australia by selling Telstra.
One of my colleagues, the member for Corio, has raised this issue in his community. In his media release on 13 August he said:

quote.para: Most Australians understand what the words “up to scratch” mean. Unfortunately it seems the Prime Minister does not.
In speaking about Telstra's service in regional Australia this morning on Sky television Mr. Howard said that “...we have got things more or less up to scratch in the bush as I've promised...”

speech.para: West Australians will feel this more than people in any other state. In a letter dated 12 August 2003 and sent to me and many of my colleagues, the President of the Western Australian Farmers Federation, Colin Nicholl, says:

quote.para: ... I believe that it is appropriate that I contact you on behalf of WAFarmers members and their rural communities to advise that despite the messages you may be hearing in relation to improvements in bush telecommunications in eastern Australia, the situation is far from satisfactory in Western Australia.

speech.para: The letter goes on to say:

quote.para: The WA State Government has recently released the results of its telecommunications review which reinforces the position of WAFarmers.

The review found that almost 60% of businesses and more than 46% of households connected to the Internet in the WA wheat belt were dissatisfied with the speed of their connection. Findings in relation to standard and mobile telephone services were consistent with this low level of satisfaction.

In rural Western Australia, past instances of the privatisation of Government service providers have equated to increased costs for lower service standards and declining quality of infrastructure and maintenance. The greatest example of this process is the privatisation of Westrail's rail freight service.
WAFarmers firmly believes that should the full privatisation of Telstra proceed, rural Western Australians will be faced with the same outcomes.

speech.para: I have great sympathy, as I have said, for the rural sector, and I support the words of the president, Colin Nicholl. It has been my experience when I have been out in the bush in Western Australia that telephone services are patchy and spasmodic and mobile services are very patchy.

This is an approach, however, that the Howard government loves to take: forget the West, forget Western Australian farmers—their families, their businesses, their livelihoods and their local communities. The Western Australian government has heeded the call of the bush. As pointed out by Colin Nicholl, the commission report shows:

quote.para: ... almost 60% of businesses and more than 45% of households connected to the Internet in the WA wheat belt were dissatisfied with the speed of their Internet connection.

speech.para: I was under the impression that Prime Minister Howard had personally taken care of the bush's Internet. This information by the Western Australian Farmers Federation seems to fly in the face of such a claim. If Telstra is taken out of public control, the remote parts of Australia will only grow more remote.

However, the damage will not stop there. The electorate of Stirling is a well-est-ab-lished area and contains some of Perth's oldest suburbs—suburbs that have become inner city. Yet even these suburbs cannot expect a reliable service from a Telstra that is only partly privatised. I would like to bring to the attention of the House the experience of two of my Stirling constituents, Jocelyn and Donald Oldmea-dow. About 85 and 90 years old respectively, this couple has been negatively affected by a corporate Telstra. The Oldmeadows' phone line malfunctioned and they were left without any telephone service. This included incoming calls and access to bare essentials such as 000 and other emergency numbers. Telstra sent out a technician to repair the fault. He explained that a wire connecting the Oldmeadow residence to the phone network was eroded and would need replacing. Subsequent to this, the same technician advised the Oldmeadows that the problem had been resolved. Sure enough, the Oldmeadows' phone connection was re-established for, according to Dr Oldmeadow, `a couple of hours'.

By the end of the day, the phone connection had again failed. The Oldmeadows' son, Fenton, contacted Telstra regarding the situation. After this the Oldmeadows were left for approximately three days without a home phone service. An 85- and 90-year-old couple were left without access to their family, friends and emergency services. The Oldmeadows were forced to buy a prepaid mobile phone, have calls diverted to it and pay for such a service. The Oldmeadows, like so many Australians, were let down badly by Telstra's corporate culture. This culture has been created by the partial sale of Telstra and this culture will only increase if the remainder is sold. Just as the Oldmeadows did, it will be regular Australians who will end up having to pay for Telstra's poor service out of their own pockets. Prime Minister Howard, this is just not good enough.

Telstra is a giant; it is a massive organisation and worth $30 billion to the Australian people. If the government hands over such a massive organisation to private business, the average Australian will be left out in the cold. One of my constituents, Lin Murphy, knows this truth all too well. Miss Murphy was cheated into a Telstra debt of over $600 by an acquaintance of hers. Consequently, Miss Murphy has lost her Telstra service with the exception of incoming and any emergency calls. Miss Murphy does not dispute that she owes Telstra money. She appreciates that Telstra was not responsible for the mishap and that it is a matter being pursued with the police. However, what Miss Murphy does want from Telstra is a fair go. Miss Murphy is on a disability pension and cannot possibly afford any lump sum repayment of this debt. Despite the fact that she has offered to pay the money back in small instalments, Telstra refuses to reconnect her phone. This is regardless of the fact that Telstra has sold on the debt to a private business and in real terms is not owed money for this account. There is Telstra's corporate mentality and it has left Miss Murphy pretty well without a phone. I imagine she is one of thousands of battlers who are very much cut off from their social networks and their families and friends by this kind of corporate behaviour and because of Telstra's profit-driven attitude. If the Howard government privatises such a vital service, standards can only get worse.

Prime Minister Howard assures the Australian people that Telstra will not be sold until Australians are guaranteed an ongoing level of service. Like most Australians, I find this extremely hard to believe. The plain fact is that Telstra is spending less and earning more. Capital expenses are down, yet profits keep going up. It looks to me, and to many of my constituents, that Telstra is spending less on upgrading Australian networks and is instead soaking up the profits. Fewer people work for Telstra, yet the number of people using Telstra is increasing. There are fewer service staff, fewer technicians and less accountability for ordinary home users. The dollar value of Telstra is being fattened up by the Howard government and the households of Australia have to pick up the slack.

The Howard government would have us believe that ordinary Australians would receive the bulk of the profits from a full Telstra sale. I wonder how many people who bought the original offering of Telstra 2 shares would agree with that statement. Australians need more than a cheap buck from their phone provider; they need a dependable organisation that they can base their businesses and lives on. Prime Minister Howard, do not rob Australia of this service. Telstra is not just a phone company; Telstra is the centre of Australian infrastructure. With few exceptions, every phone company in Australia still pays Telstra for the right to use the Australian phone network. Selling Telstra sells the foundation stone of Aust-ralian communication. The government claims that selling Telstra creates an ultra competitive phone market. This is not the case. Selling Telstra unleashes a corporation on the Australian market that has immediate market dominance over all other competitors. This government wants to give a free pass to the biggest fish in a very small pond.

Partial privatisation has already shown the Australian people some of the consequences. Telstra's appalling performance overseas leads to fewer profits for Australian taxpayers and shareholders alike and a downgrading of service that affects every corner of this nation. Labor opposes such irresponsible policy and always will. I do not need to tell most ordinary people that the first Telstra sale has proven to be a mistake, but this message needs repeating as the circumstances surrounding the sales are changing. We are now in the digital age. Australia is a fledgling nation as far as the roll-out of broadband technology goes. When the Internet reached the mainstream in the mid-1990s, we were on the top of the pile; we were on a par with Western Europe and the United States. For a nation of our sparsity and size, the Australian Internet was, at that time, a huge achievement. Contrast this to today's Internet environment. Australia lags behind almost all OECD nations, Europe and most of Asia. Telstra has been unwilling to put the dollars and planning into establishing a credible broadband network for this country. Despite saturation style broadband advertising on television, Telstra's ADSL policy limits its availability to approximately 40 per cent of Australians. This is the estimation of industry sources. Telstra claims 70 per cent of availability. However, many people have said, `Who really knows?'

Telstra's corporate culture has led to a data bottleneck that makes Australia look stupid and inefficient. We were once known as the clever country because we had creativity and support for knowledge industries in Australia. I strongly believe that that creative spirit still exists, but what difference does it make if we do not have the capability to communicate and share these ideas? I challenge Prime Minister Howard to ask Australian businesses the same question. Throughout my electorate, Telstra policies are preventing businesses of all sizes from performing to potential. Home businesses that exist on a pair gain line are a prime example. Telstra's answer to this is transposition—a re-routing of copper to the affected areas if an alternative supply exists.

By definition, areas that have been pair gained have very little copper. Consequently, transposition means absolutely nothing to most Australians on pair gains. How will the full privatisation of Telstra fix this? Will a purely corporate entity grow a conscience and decide that the cost of removing every pair gain line in Australia is worth the potentially small numbers of people who opt for ADSL? Prime Minister, if you know of a corporation with such heart, can you please give me their telephone number? I will be happy to share it with Stirling constituents, small businesses and community organisations.

Would a fully privatised Telstra pay for the mistakes that the semi-privatised entity has already made? For example, would Telstra pay a firm in Stirling—Sustainability—to break the five-year lease that they signed on advice from Telstra that the premises was ADSL ready? Would a fully privatised Telstra forgo the money it makes from owning broadband infrastructure and continue to let broadband resellers have a fair go in the marketplace? Like most Australians, I doubt this very much and, like the growing list of people who contact me and tell me they cannot get ADSL because of Telstra policy, I do not particularly want to find out. Australia's broadband situation is not terminal yet, and only a properly run government controlled Telstra can save it.

Selling Telstra at any point would be dangerous, but selling Telstra now would sell future generations of Australians down the river. Education stands to enjoy huge benefits in the digital age. For the first time those in remote Australia can feasibly enjoy an education with real-time feedback—a teacher they can see and hear on a computer screen. There is no profitability in building an infrastructure to meet these needs. By selling the rest of Telstra, the Howard government wants to make a cheap buck on the backs of our children, our university and TAFE students and our regional populations. I will not stand for this, and Labor will not stand for this. We on this side of the House realise the importance of ensuring that core Australian infrastructure remains in public hands.

The international experience of similar privatisation has been horrifying. Do we want a telephone system that is controlled by the market and completely out of public control? Australia is a remote place in a remote corner of the world. For Telstra to make enduring profits while maintaining a decent service would require a significant fee increase for the average Australian, and, Prime Minister, the average Australian deserves far better. I do not believe that the short-term profit this bill would generate is worth the long-term costs. These costs go beyond the economic; they hurt our very way of life. The ability to talk to one another cheaply and reliably is worth fighting for, and Labor will not stop fighting for it.

I have one last example I would like to bring to the attention of the House, which I believe best illustrates the importance of Telstra to our country and the fundamental need for it to stay in Australian ownership. I refer to the residents of Lyndale Street in Gwelup. Nineteen residents in this street have collectively sent a letter to Telstra with regard to the poor service they have endured over the past 12 months. These problems go beyond the merely accidental. Persistent line drop-outs, line noise and the impossibility of line upgrades have plagued the residents for at least a year. Telstra's inability to fix these faults can best be epitomised by one pregnant resident on the street who recently purchased a mobile phone for fear of not being able to contact loved ones if she went into labour. This is just not good enough.

There is a lesson to be learnt by the Howard government. Telstra supports communities, and when Telstra fails, so do these communities. The people of Lyndale Street, and of Australia, pay their taxes and line rentals in the expectation of receiving service that is accessible, equitable, reliable and reasonably priced. Prime Minister Howard, sell Telstra and these expectations will cease to exist. As you are very good at picking up policy ideas from Labor, I would suggest that perhaps you could look at Labor's policy ideas on this issue. We will require Telstra to intensify its focus on its core responsibilities to the Australian community and reduce its emphasis on foreign ventures and media investments. Telstra will be asked to intensify its focus on the provision of affordable and accessible broadband services available for all Australians, and the competition regime will be strengthened by requiring much stricter internal separation of Telstra's wholesale and retail activities.

The minister for communications will be removed from the process of ACCC scrutiny and regulation of accounting separation within Telstra to ensure the process is genuinely independent and rigorous. Also, consumers will be given stronger protection from sharp practices by telecommunications companies, and the price control regime will be made fairer. Labor believes in public ownership of Telstra because telecommunications services are essential services. It is not too late to change your mind, Prime Minister. I bring the voice of my Stirling residents, small businesses and community organisations into this House to say: `Think. Do not do it. It's never too late to be mature and say that you made a mistake and have changed your mind.' Withdraw this bill from the House and leave things as they are.

talk.start.para: —In this debate on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 I find it quite interesting that the member for Stirling was very critical of Telstra and its poor service, because that poor service is occurring when Telstra is still very much government controlled. We are now expected to believe that, when it becomes privately controlled and owned, it will get significantly worse. That is the standard line, and that indicates the capacity of the Labor Party in clearly demonstrating what they see as a very clear political opportunity. I do not suppose I really have to remind the House that this was the government's position in 1993, in 1996, in 1998 and in 2001. I have actually been to four elections where the sun would not rise tomorrow if Telstra became privatised. It is all wearing a little thin. I also remind the member for Stirling that is was the member for Brand, the then minister for finance in the Hawke government, who actually corporatised Telecom to become Telstra. There was much complaint from the previous speaker about this corporate mentality—this cruel and heartless beast that wreaks havoc upon their poor consumers.

speech.para: Either the Australian community will accept this ideological push—and so far it has not accepted it for four successive elections, and it looks like it will be a fifth election—or suddenly the Australian community will say that public ownership is the only way to go. I do not have anything against public ownership if it is providing a reasonable service, and certainly Australia Post fits into that category. No doubt there will be a scare campaign at the next election that the `terrible' Liberals want to privatise Australia Post. There would not be anything further from the truth, but that will not stop people trying to run the scare campaign. We can put this ideology to one side after what will now be coming up to five elections, and we can look at what really makes a difference in providing telecommunications in Australia.

I have been around long enough to remember a party line, eight-gauge fencing wire on pine posts, and a time when the first shower of rain or the first twig that fell off a tree would stop the phone or barely allow it to function. I have seen huge improvements and incredible increases in performance in the telecommunications industry in Australia; and, of course, that is an international phenomenon.

But as far as the ownership issue goes, the thing that really makes the difference is the resources that a government is prepared to put into it. This government, since 1996, has put in something like $1 billion, and now there is another $180 million on the table to continue the good work of the last seven years. So it is not about ownership. If it were only about ownership, why wouldn't we buy back Woolworths, Coles and a whole lot of things and put them into public ownership, and the world would be a happier and better place? That is the nonsense of the opposition argument. It is about the amount of resources and the commitment to those areas in Australia which require an equivalent service to that in the urban community.

That is not to say that the urban community is without its issues as well. You do not have to go very far out of some of our capital cities to see the difficulties that you might have with the mobile phone service. Those of us who live in regional Australia should not presume that the mobile phone service technology is absolutely foolproof; it is not. But the fact is that this government has put something like $1 billion or more into the infrastructure right around the country, particularly in regional Australia, which has brought our services up to a standard which I do not think many Australians would have thought possible 10 and 20 years ago. Whether it is the Internet, whether it is the mobile phone service, whether it is subsidisation of the satellite phone service or whether it is the broadband service—which we intend to have a closer look at over the next few months under the chairmanship of the member for Hinkler—we will address any outstanding issues that the community have particular concerns about.

I could go on and on. I could talk about the local call service that replaced the timed call rate in the remote areas of Australia. At a cost of $150 million, that was a great innovation and was greatly appreciated by communities. There has been a lot happening with communications over the last five or six years, thanks to the decisions of this government, this Prime Minister and this minister for communications, Richard Alston, who has been an outstanding leader. He has been listening, understanding and working with the overall community throughout Australia, particularly the regional community, where the Labor Party seem to think that they have a chance to scare people into believing that a privately owned Telstra will create a poorer set of circumstances. We all know that is nonsense, because we have the universal service obligation, we have the customer service guarantee and we have the willingness of the government to put the capital in to make sure that the service provided is reasonably equivalent to the service provided in most urban areas. No doubt the catchcry in this ideological red herring will include the issue of the multinationals coming to get us. We have got that one covered too. We say that at least two-thirds of Telstra has to be owned by the Australian community, and that is legislated for.

In the last couple of minutes that I have, I would like to talk a little bit about Telstra Country Wide. There is something about which I did agree slightly with the member for Stirling—for different reasons, I think—and that is that Telstra have had, up until recent times, a union-dominated philosophy. It was very much subjected to very strong unions and a particular culture which did not always think in terms of what was best for the consumer, particularly for the regional consumer. That is where the member for Stirling struck a slight chord with me.

The sort of leadership that Telstra Country Wide are showing and the availability that they offer to regional communities has seen a fundamental change in philosophy, a fundamental change in attitude and an absolute focus on service as we have never seen it before. It does not mean that we have perfection. I would not say that every enterprise—including the best companies in Australia, whether they be a public or private enterprise—always offers perfection. That is naive nonsense. The difference in culture and approach of Telstra Country Wide has brought to many regional consumers a greater faith and confidence. That is a very different story to when I started in this job as a federal MP over 10 years ago.

To conclude on the international setting, everybody would agree that we need a competitive, effective and efficient communications system to operate the commercial, social and economic objectives of this country. There is no argument with that. I would subscribe to the view that Australia can hold its head high about the dynamism that it brings to the telecommunications model of ownership and competition in this country. The privatisation of Telstra will aid and abet the development of Australia in a very effective way.

With a strong government and the willingness to put in the hard yards, the resources and the proper legislative framework, the privatisation of Telstra will serve this country well. It will free up Telstra Country Wide to ensure that it continues to give, and to improve on, the very good service to regional Australia that it is offering currently.

talk.start.para: —I have great pleasure in rising in the House to oppose the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. I do so because, ever since entering this parliament in 1993, I have consistently opposed the sale of Telstra. That is a position that I have put before the electors of Corio, a seat in the Geelong area. It is a position that I have put to my electors on serval occasions since then at elections, and on each occasion they have endorsed the position that I have taken.

speech.para: The Australian people do not want Telstra sold. You can go to the many public opinion polls that have been taken and published or you can go to the surveys conducted by members of parliament, which have already been referred to in the context of this debate, and you will find that all of them show overwhelming support for the retention of Telstra in public hands. It is not a lukewarm support; it is an overwhelming support for the reten-tion of majority ownership of Telstra in public hands.

There is a central fact in this debate that seems to escape members opposite. The coalition members opposite want to sell the shares that their constituents already own. I want the House to reflect on that particular point, because it has not appeared in any of the speeches that I have read of the coalition members opposite when they get up here to justify the policy position that is being expressed in this bill. They are very reluctant to speak about the fact that inherent in this legislation is a desire and a program to sell the shares that ordinary Australians already own.

If we go behind the 50.1 per cent of majority public ownership, we find that those shares belong to me and my children. They belong to the electors of Corio. They belong to the people of Victoria. Indeed, they belong to all Australians. Each Australian at this point in time, as we debate this bill, has a share in Telstra. This government wants to sell that share either to other Australians who are able to afford to buy those shares or to foreign interests.

What the coalition government wants to do is sell the shares that the electors of Corio already own. The government is allocating 35 per cent of those shares to be sold to the bankers of New York and the financial gnomes in Zurich. That is the reality that cannot be denied in this debate by any member opposite. I challenge the members opposite to refute the assertion that every Australian owns a share at this point in time in Telstra. But when you are done with this bill only some of them will own the shares in Telstra.

It is important to reflect on this great Australian enterprise and its earning capacity. In 2002 this enterprise reaped a profit to the government of $1.48 billion. If Telstra had been in full public ownership, that figure would have been almost double that amount—around $3 billion. The government intends to get $11.3 billion over the forward estimates from the sale of Telstra, which goes to roughly $45 billion. You do not have to be a genius to work the sums out. The government gets $45 billion for Telstra. Telstra is currently earning about $3 billion so, over some 15 years, at current profit rates, what the government gets in the forward estimates from the sale of Telstra is roughly equivalent to the amount that it would receive in profit. Beyond that period, the Australian people will be in a loss situation if their enterprise is sold.

Schools, hospitals, roads and other services will be financed from the profit of Telstra. We know that that profit will increase with growth in Australia's population and with the growth in the use of communications technologies. But, even on the current figures, after about 15 years the Australian people will be in a loss situation, and they will be in it forever. If Telstra remains in public hands then for the next 100 years their children, their grandchildren and their great-grandchildren are going to share in that Telstra dividend.

What you are selling here in the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 is the future of Australians, and you are quite happy to do it. You are quite happy to sell the shares that every Australian already owns and in face of the overwhelming evidence that they do not want this enterprise sold.

talk.start.para: —What about the shares Australians owned in the Commonwealth Bank?

—The honourable member raises a point. I do not think he is very serious in raising it. We are dealing here with a vital piece of telecommunications infrastructure. Every Australian ought to have access to that on an equitable basis, whether they live in the city or in rural and regional Australia.

speech.para: One after the other, members opposite have come into this House telling the Australian people that Telstra's services have really improved and that everything is basically hunky-dory and ready for the sale.
