I say to members opposite that you have just mounted an argument for public ownership. This great improvement in service that you put before this House has been achieved while Telstra has been in majority public ownership. On the basis of your logic, we can assume that services would continue to improve over time if that position were maintained. There is an inherent illogicality in your argument. You are arguing that Telstra's services to rural and regional Australians and to people in urban areas have improved so much, yet you want to deny the fact that that improvement has been achieved while Telstra has been in majority public ownership and that Telstra could continue with its program of improvement of services if it were retained in majority public ownership.

We on this side of the House have some misgivings about the levels of service. They are legitimate misgivings because we know that, as a prelude to the privatisation of Telstra, the government has embarked on a deliberate campaign of disinvestment in the network to prop up the share price. We have seen massive reductions in investment and cuts in staff numbers. It has all been designed to put Telstra in a favourable financial position vis-a-vis the private share price so that Telstra can be sold.

Many constituents in my electorate, which is based in Geelong, have contacted me with their concerns about certain aspects of Telstra's service. In making these points I want to state that workers in Telstra are indeed hardworking people. They do their level best with the resources that are available to them to keep this network intact and operating and to deliver the best services they can to their customers. The problem here lies with the government and the management of Telstra, who have starved the enterprise of the necessary investment to provide those services.

Geelong is Victoria's premier provincial city, located a one-hour drive from Melbourne. We are not dealing with the back of Bourke, outback Queensland or the Northern Territory; we are dealing with a highly urbanised area. Recently, I travelled to Melbourne airport to fly to Canberra. Like many members, I take advantage of the hour that I have in the car to work. The mobile phone is a very important tool in that it is my contact with constituents, businesses and people associated with my shadow ministerial responsibility.

The Comcar driver will attest to the fact—because there was some colourful language in the car—that as we drove up Thomson Road, Norlane, an urban area in Geelong, my mobile phone cut out. The service was restored a little bit further on but, when I got to Little River on the road to Melbourne, my mobile phone cut out again. If Telstra cannot provide an effective service between Melbourne and Geelong, how are rural and regional Australians going to cope? The Australian people do not believe government members opposite.

I will recount to members an email that I got recently from a constituent. The email is dated Saturday, 16 August. The constituent asked that they not be named in the debate, but has given me permission to use the material they sent to me. The constituent lives in a suburb in Geelong and, as they say, it is:

quote.para: ... hardly the back of beyond and Telstra's current exchange is not powerful enough to get to us with the broadband facility. Apparently the rubber band can't stretch that far!

speech.para: The email continues:

quote.para: As you well know, we live in the second most populous city in Victoria, a city with a booming economy and much, much more to offer.

speech.para: Further:

quote.para: Geelong is in dire need of the facilities to provide all of us with broadband.

speech.para: This constituent has been trying to sign up to Telstra's ADSL facility. That is the one that they advertise as if it is universally available—but, of course, as my constituent is saying, it is not. My constituent is very concerned at the attitude of some Telstra staff when they have attempted to get that service. Comments like `ring us back in 20 years' and `you live out in the sticks' have led my constituent to conclude that they are treated well by Telstra on some occasions but on others Telstra are dismissive and they consider Geelong as `Hicksville'—that is the word of my constituent. I relay that because here is a person in an urban constituency who cannot get access to an ADSL facility that they need, they want and they desire.

In the time remaining to me, let me comment on the employment consequences already experienced due to the government's policy. We have seen since 1996 some 39,000 full-time jobs lost. That is an extraordinary number. On Friday, 1 August I met with members of the CEPU—Branch President John Ellery and union representative Jimmy Kane. We sought to publicise in the Geelong community the fact that this government wanted to flog off one of Australia's premier economic assets to, among other people, foreign interests. There with us was Greg Postuma, who lost his job in the year 2000. Greg has been unemployed ever since. He has found it extremely difficult to find work in the regional economy. Like so many others who have been restructured out in middle life, Greg Postuma has really found it hard.

When members opposite argue their case for further job losses in Telstra they do it from a position where, at this point in time, they will not lose their jobs. But I can guarantee you that at the next election many of you will, because you have betrayed the people of rural and regional Australia. National Party members and Country Liberals, including the member for Corangamite, have betrayed rural and regional Australia. But there are some honourable members in this House, besides those belonging to the Labor Party. I mention here the honourable member for New England, who conducted a survey in his electorate which indicated that 97 per cent of his constituents do not want the sale. The member for Calare, an Independent member, did a survey which showed that 96 per cent of people did not want Telstra sold. The member for Kennedy also conducted a survey, which indicated that 98 per cent of his constituents who returned the survey form did not want Telstra sold. Member after member in the coalition has poured water on these particular surveys by these honourable members—but they are honest surveys by members who are being honest with their electors.

In conclusion, the privatisation drive has already seen adverse impacts on employment and investment levels. The independent inquiries that are being proposed in this legislation are the shams that we know that the government is able to construct. Of course, at the end of the day, it will be the low-income people and the pensioners of this country who will pay the price. We know things like the discount concession scheme for pensioners will immediately be on the chopping block if Telstra is sold. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003. I do not pretend to have listened to all of the speeches of those opposite, but from what I have heard I have gleaned that those opposite have put forward a combination of feigned concern about telecommunications services along with the predictable left wing rhetoric that we often get from those on the other side. Perhaps it is time for a dose of reality, a dose of the facts—and I would like to quickly outline those facts. Under Labor there was very little competition in telecommunications. Under Labor there were very few consumer safeguards. Under Labor there was no concern for regional Australia—evidenced by their hasty decision to scrap the analogue mobile service, which much of regional and rural Australia relied on. Now, supposedly, we have had a great change of heart and those opposite do care about these things. I think this point ought to be made: if Labor had been in office for the last seven years we would not be having this debate now because they would have already sold Telstra. It would already have gone under Labor, and what would we have to show for it? Nothing. The money would have been spent—as it was with every other privatisation that they effected, and I will come to that point later.

speech.para: There are three key issues here. The first is this: since 1997, when Telstra was opened to full competition under the coalition government, there have been significant improvements for consumers. Those improvements have resulted from competition under the regulatory watch of the government, not from government ownership. We have a much greater choice of provider. There were three phone companies in 1997 and there are 89 phone companies now. There are now 963 registered service providers. There are now 136 ISPs offering residential broadband services and 161 offering business services. In the five years from 1996 to 2001, the cost of telephone services fell, on average, by 24.8 per cent across this country. So we now have cheaper telephone services. There has been a rapid growth in mobile phone services, with 65 per cent of people now having mobile phones. Most of the country now has dial-up Internet for the cost of a local call. There is a satellite service available to 100 per cent of the population. ADSL is available to 70 per cent of homes and a cable modem service is now available to 35 per cent of homes.

Overall, according to an independent report commissioned by the ACA, consumers have benefited by somewhere between $595 and $878 per year from the improved competition. Small business has saved an estimated $900 million a year. The economy is estimated by this independent inquiry commissioned by the ACA to be some $10 billion larger, with 100,000 extra jobs created in the telecommunications industry. It is important to note that these many improvements for consumers, businesses and the economy have come not because of the government ownership of Telstra—there were no improvements during those 13 dark years of Labor, or very few—but because of competition and because of technology. Protections have been built in through government regulation, not through government ownership. Simply compare the quality of service and the lower prices we have now under partial deregulation and greater competition with what it was like under 100 per cent government ownership under the Labor government. Back then service was abysmal and prices were higher.

In the future we will see further improvements if Telstra is allowed to compete fully and freely on the open market—and this is the central issue. This is why the government is proposing the further sale of Telstra—to allow Telstra to continue to compete in an increasingly global telecommunications industry. In a climate where technology is changing so rapidly and in a context of increasing interaction between telecommunications carriers both here and overseas, it is imperative that Telstra is able to raise capital and have the flexibility to compete.

If Telstra has to depend on government funds, how in the world is it going to get the capital it needs to be able to compete, set up new services, invest and expand—particularly, the question has to be asked, if we had a Labor government running deficits year after year after year averaging $10 billion, $14 billion or $15 billion a year? Where out of government coffers, out of the taxpayers' pockets, would the money come from to enable Telstra to invest in updating or expanding its equipment? Under government ownership Telstra would be hogtied—it would not be able to effectively compete either here or internationally.

If Telstra is going to remain viable, if Telstra is going to have access to the capital that it needs, if Telstra is going to compete flexibly with other telecommunications competitors both here and overseas then it needs to be freed from the shackles of government ownership and freed from its dependency on funding that governments will never be able to deliver. Telstra needs the freedom and the capital to be able to compete. If Telstra does not get this, it will suffer steadily declining competitiveness and a reduced ability to provide the services that customers require. Its shareholders will experience a steady diminishing of the value of their shares and the government's revenue stream from Telstra will continue to decline as well.

The point simply is this: for Telstra's ongoing viability, for the sake of Australian consumers—be they residential or business—and for the health of the telecommunications industry in this country, it is absolutely imperative that the restrictions of government ownership are lifted so that Telstra can compete freely and fully on an open market. I know that members opposite, deep in their hearts—if they had the freedom to say it—believe the same thing.

The second point that needs to be made is that the further sale of Telstra will enable this government to continue its very effective program of debt reduction, a program that has reduced government debt from the $98 billion we inherited when we came into office to a current level of around $36 billion. The effect of this is that less and less of taxpayers' money is being flushed down the drain on annual interest payments on that debt. When we came into office $8 billion a year—$8,000 million a year—of taxpayers' money was going to servicing the debt racked up by Labor. This government's effective debt reduction has reduced that $8 billion annual impost to around $4 billion. The further sale of Telstra will effectively mean a further reduction in that interest servicing cost.

I acknowledge that some people are concerned about the sale of Telstra. That is quite clear. Why wouldn't they be with Labor's exaggerated and ridiculous claims about what might or might not happen with a privatised Telstra? The point is this: consumer safeguards, in the way that they have been put in place under this government in recent years, will be there and will continue regardless of who owns Telstra. Those consumer service safeguards are not a product of government ownership; they were not there when Telstra was 100 per cent owned under the former government. They are there because of government legislation and government regulation.

I will take a quick run through the list of some of these safeguards. There is the customer service guarantee that requires all telephone companies to meet specified time frames to connect fixed line services, to repair reported faults and to keep appointments et cetera. There is the universal service obligation, which guarantees all Australians access to basic telephone services. There are many other safeguards: there is the guarantee regarding interim telephone services, the guarantee regarding priority assistance—that Telstra has to provide a priority assistance service for people who have life-threatening medical conditions, the guarantee that all Australian consumers—except for those in extended zones—have a legislated right to untimed local calls. There are price controls under part 9 of the Telecommunications Act 1999. There is a low-income customer package to protect low-income customers. There is the National Relay Service to ensure that there are services for people who are deaf or who have a hearing or speech impairment. There is the existence of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman; the network reliability framework; the digital data service obligation, which guarantees all Australians access to Internet data speeds upon request of at least 64 kilobytes per second through Telstra's ISDN service; and the Internet Assistance Program. On and on I could go.

The point is that these safeguards are there not because of government ownership but because of government legislation and regulation. They will continue, regardless of whether Telstra is owned publicly or privately. For the Labor Party, the opposition, to pretend otherwise is dishonest and an absolute nonsense—and they know it. The point is that, over the past seven years under this government, customers have had better service, and have guarantees of better service built in by legislation, than they ever dreamt of having when Telstra was 100 per cent owned under the former government.
The other point that really needs to be made is this: Labor will sell Telstra anyway, regardless of what they say now.

talk.start.para: —That is false.

—Give Labor half a chance and they will sell Telstra. The member opposite is trying to say that is false. Was it false in your promise in the prospectus of the Commonwealth Bank, just to quote one example? Labor will sell Telstra, regardless of what they say. We have seen the record. Labor have a track record. They say one thing in opposition and do the opposite in government. They say one thing in opposition and do something totally different in government.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The opposition's position on this—
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—That is no point of order. What is the point of order? There is no point of order.
—We are being verballed.
—Read the standing orders if you are going to take a point of order.
—The member for Lowe will be expelled from the House if he continues to argue.

—The member opposite is obviously very sensitive about Labor's record. Let me just remind him of that record. For instance, when Labor were in government during their last term what did they do? They sold the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, the Sydney-Moomba pipeline, Aerospace Technologies of Australia, the Commonwealth uranium stockpile, Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, Amdel, Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services, the defence services house corporation loan portfolio, the Defence Force home loan franchise and the Commonwealth housing loan assistance schemes. The list goes on and on. How can they expect us to believe that they would not sell Telstra?

speech.para: Let me make this point about the Commonwealth Bank. On 24 September 1993, as part of their prospectus—an official document to potential shareholders, people who wanted to buy into the Commonwealth Bank—what did Labor actually print and distribute to the Australian community? They stated in that prospectus:

quote.para: The government has no intentions whatever of further reducing its shareholding.

speech.para: Not just in Hansard but in black and white in the official Commonwealth Bank prospectus, Labor promised that they would not further reduce the Commonwealth government's holding in the Commonwealth Bank. What did they do and how long did it take them? Twenty months, less than two years later, they had put on the market the rest of the Commonwealth Bank. What Labor says about privatising or not privatising is not to be believed. What they do, their track record, is what people need to take notice of.

Going back to Telstra and their promise not to sell it, let us just look back over the record. In a strategy paper for its 1995-66 budget, marked `highly protected' but obtained under freedom of information laws, the Labor government actually drew up in 1995-96 a detailed proposal to sell 100 per cent of Telstra in five tranches. There it was, a proposal marked `secret', but that was Labor's plan. Further, there was the detailed proposal that Labor had consulted investment banks and had estimated that the sale would bring $20 billion. Furthermore, in 1998 the Business Review Weekly reported a secret meeting between the then Prime Minister Paul Keating, Kim Beazley and the BHP boss John Prescott in 1995; the Labor leader asking BHP whether it would be interested in buying Telstra—`Would BPH like to buy Telstra? Here's a deal; we've got a deal for you.' On it goes. Just two years ago the shadow communications and finance minister was caught talking to an investment bank about the prospect of splitting up Telstra and selling it. Mr Deputy Speaker, do not listen to what Labor say in opposition; look at what they do in government, and you know what will happen to Telstra under them. No amount of rhetoric, no amount of promises from Labor will change the fact that they will sell Telstra if they get into office.

There are only two differences between the opposition and the government on this whole issue of the sale of Telstra. It is not whether Telstra will be sold. It will be sold under either Labor or the coalition government. One difference is that the coalition is up-front in saying, `This is what we will do,' while Labor tries to pretend they will not. However, if they get half a chance, they will do it. So one difference is that we are being up-front and Labor is being disingenuous in what they are saying. The other difference is that, when we sell the remaining holding of Telstra, the money will be used to retire government debt. What will happen if Labor sells Telstra? Look at what happened when they sold the Commonwealth Bank. Look at what happened when they sold Qantas and a whole string of other government businesses. Did they use the money to retire debt? No, they spent it. It all disappeared. Not only did they spend that money, they also managed to run up about $70 billion worth of debt in their last five years. They were selling assets like mad on one hand, as though they were at a great fire sale, and they were running up debt on the other hand, spending like drunken sailors—and in no way is there anything to show for their sale of all of those government assets.

The point is this: the coalition government is saying up-front that it is our policy to privatise the remaining shareholding in Telstra. The opposition, regardless of what they say, will do the same thing. The only difference is that this government will use the money to retire debt, while those on the other side will spend the money and there will be nothing to show for it. It is about time that the opposition started to come clean with the Australian public. Again I say: do not listen to what they say in opposition, look at what they did when they were in government.

talk.start.para: —`On and on I could go,' said the member for Macquarie, and on and on he went, displaying all the yapping and barking that a small dog does. Perhaps he is the testosterone chihuahua of the Australian political spectrum. The member for Macquarie continued the debate on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2003 with no regard for the substance of the case he was put to make—that it is a good thing to sell Telstra and that it should move to full private ownership. Instead, he was reduced to saying that the Labor Party had that as its agenda. In other words, there is no merit in this proposal other than the defence that the opposition would do it too. As my friend and colleague at the table sought to do on a number of occasions, I say that it is a preposterous suggestion and one which the community will be able to judge.

speech.para: But there is an oddness about this debate. Although many speakers rise and use language of passion, I think there is an odd quietude or placidity about this debate. That is because we all know that this debate will take us nowhere during this parliament. There is no prospect of this legislation passing through the Senate—none whatsoever. So we are going through the motions that our various sides of this debate require us to do, and I will do the same to put the case that I strongly believe—that this institution should remain in public ownership. However, because there is this realisation that the parliament is not going to pass this legislation, we know that the real test will only emerge if the Prime Minister chooses to take this measure at a later date to the Australian people as a double dissolution measure. We will then see whether the member for Macquarie and many on the other side—especially the Nationals—will still have the same courage and flair in the advocacy of this proposal when it comes to a circumstance where their electoral fate will depend on being returned to this House as part of a government committed to a double dissolution sitting in which that bill would be introduced as a measure. I think that we might see some slight lack of courage, shall we say, on behalf of a number of members who have been quite happy to come here and speak, and to continue to speak, as if they would be quite comfortable doing so even as the wet cement were poured in.

This legislation purports to enable the government to sell the remaining majority shareholding of Telstra. Of course, as I have indicated, it does no such thing in practice. We know that this legislation is doomed to be defeated and that the government will in future have an opportunity to place it in a queue. It will take some time before it is ready, but the government will be able to place it in a queue of other legislation that has been twice rejected by the parliament and to decide whether it wishes to make this an issue which will determine its fate at the next election.

Labor opposed the partial privatisation of Telstra and is absolutely and completely opposed to the further privatisation of Telstra. There is no doubt that the realisation that this legislation is not going to pass this parliament has led to what I think is the most extraordinary and surprising outcome—that is, the National Party caving into pressure from the Prime Minister and the minister for communications, Howard and Alston respectively, and selling out their constituency. There is no doubt that the full privatisation of Telstra—were it to occur—would mean further diminution of Telstra services to rural and regional Australia. Again, why is there such an acceptance of that consequence? I suspect it is because they know that this legislation will not pass this House, and they have been prepared to roll over on this issue in the hope that it will not be a double dissolution election issue. If it is, then the point made by the member for Corio—that this will be an electoral test which will find many on the other side defeated—is likely to come true.

Telecommunications is an essential service for this country. The full privatisation of Telstra would in effect make it a huge private monopoly. There would be no effective means for a federal government to regulate its services. There would be no scrutiny of a fully privatised Telstra by any parliamentary inquiry or through the budget estimates processes that currently apply. We know that Telstra has been prepared for privatisation, and part of that has been the insistence on so-called greater efficiencies—that is, staff reductions and a reduction in capital investment. Capital investment in Telstra has dropped by $1.3 billion over the past four years. With Telstra's partial privatisation, we have seen more than a doubling of the cost of our phone line rental, and that is expected to rise to over $30 per month in the next 12 to 24 months.

Staffing levels have reduced dramatically. In 2002 Telstra employed 45,000 full-time equivalent persons. In 2003 this is predicted to fall to 42,000. That is a cut of 3,000 jobs. My own state of Tasmania can expect to lose in the order of 30 to 40 highly skilled jobs. Whilst that number might seem small to some from other states, losing 30 to 40 highly skilled jobs is something Tasmania can ill afford. And what would these job cuts mean? They would mean further blow-outs in maintenance lists and fault reduction times. Even at the present time, only the highest priority maintenance work is being undertaken.

The job cuts and the greater efficiencies that have been insisted upon have really been done for short-term reasons—to effect the highest possible share price. Of course, the collapse of the high-tech sector has caused Telstra shares to fall. They are presently trading at a level that I think makes it implausible for this government to seriously proceed with the sale, even if it were to get this legislation through, at least in the short term. But if they did they would be basically selling off a hugely valuable asset for a bargain basement price—that is, selling public goods for private gain. There is no doubt that a fully privatised Telstra would continue to put private gain at the forefront of its mind. A fully privatised Telstra would have to target the more profitable centres in Australia: the bigger cities.

The government are offering a $181 million package to fix up the list of improvements suggested by the Estens inquiry. That $181 million is really an insult, and it should be seen as such by the National Party. Anyone living in rural or regional Australia knows $181 million will go very little way towards fixing the problems they have experienced and, indeed, the problems identified by Estens. That is $45 million each year. Equate that with Telstra's annual capital expenditure of about $3 billion and you get to see how small the package really is. How can the five Tasmanian Liberal senators vote for this legislation and say they are representing the interests of their constituents? In one area alone of my state you can travel from New Norfolk, just north of Hobart, to Queenstown—some three hours drive in a car—and have no mobile reception. That is simply one example of the thousands available Australia wide.

What has been happening is very straightforward. Telstra has been reducing its work force, reducing its services and reducing in the long run the quality of the network, because it is not being properly serviced and maintained, particularly in the non-profitable areas—that is, regional Australia. Although there will be a short-term investment which will not be sufficient and which will certainly not be maintained, it may hold this together until the phone company has been sold. But the end result will be that it will be flogged off for private gain, and hang the Australian taxpayer. This is what a privatised Telstra would look like. And make no mistake—things will not get better. As I have said, there is an odd lack of passion in this debate because we all know that the starter's gun is not going to go off unless the Prime Minister calls a double dissolution election. So this is a very strange circumstance, with everyone lining up and making predictable speeches that they will circulate to their constituencies—and good on them.

But I will be very interested to see whether the government has the courage of its convictions, come the day this actually becomes a trigger, and whether or not, if that circumstance arises and the government does decide to pursue the double dissolution option, this piece of legislation is presented to the Governor-General as one of the bills scheduled for the double dissolution, because I actually would welcome that opportunity in my seat of Denison. And I am certain my glee would be shared and magnified by my colleague the member for Lyons, who is regrettably not with us today but who has the largest part of the state of Tasmania, the member for Bass, the member for Braddon and the member for Franklin, all of whom have large rural constituencies. I have the small area of Collinsvale. It has very bad reception, by the way. I think my farming community represents about 200 people, but the rest of my colleagues have substantial rural constituencies and I think they would be rather pleased to make the case for the retention of Telstra in public ownership.

I suspect it might be rather difficult for some members of the coalition in rural constituencies in Queensland, in the outback in rural New South Wales and in far parts of Western Australia to make the case that this is a good thing. So I think some of the bravado and yapping that we have heard from the angry chihuahuas on the other side who have been making their case may be tested if this is put to the people of Australia by their Prime Minister. And I have the suspicion that, behind the scenes, many of those who have been speaking so passionately in favour of the full sale of Telstra might be saying to the Prime Minister in private that he might be well advised not to put it on the agenda for a double dissolution election. I suspect courage will be found somewhat wanting when push comes to shove. If the Prime Minister does go `crazy brave' and put it on the agenda, expect no little concern from many on the coalition side and no small glee from those of us in the Labor opposition who will have the opportunity to have a Telstra election.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I wish to tell the House tonight about a wonderful young woman from my electorate of Hasluck. Her name is Tiffany Newman, she is 13 years old and she is an ambassador with the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. She wrote to me and visited me last month in my electorate office in Perth to talk to me about the project, Kids in the House. And of course, all of us have had the pleasure today of participating with the 100 kids in the House who have been visiting as representatives of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

speech.para: It is my great honour and privilege tonight to read to you the letter that Tiffany wrote to me, which I think encapsulates her story better than I ever could. She writes:

quote.para: I was 4 years old when I was first diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes. I don't remember a day in my life without needles or blood tests.
Every day I need to inject myself with insulin, test my blood sugars levels and I need to eat regularly to ensure that I don't have a HYPO.

A hypo is when the sugar that is usually in my blood has gone and there is no sugar in my blood for my body to use. This can be caused if I do extra activities, if snacks are delayed, when I go through a growth spurt or if I am stressing. When I am having a Hypo, I get very pale, shaky, aggressive and generally I get very short tempered.
Sometimes HYPOS can happen during the night and I can have a seizure. This has happened to me several times before and I need to be rushed to hospital.
In Australia there are around 100,000 people with Type 1 Diabetes. Each day 2 more people are diagnosed.
After having Diabetes for 20 years, most people will have serious health problems like Kidney Disease, Heart Disease, Eye Disease and Amputation.

speech.para: She continues:

quote.para: Type 1 Diabetes can occur at any age.
However it is more common to occur in children and adolescents.

speech.para: The letter goes on:

quote.para: The difference between Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes is that Type 1 is an auto immune disease that usually occurs in children, it is not caused by eating too much sugar or not doing enough exercise, it can not be prevented, it just happens without warning and it is difficult to manage.
Scientists know that with enough support, they will be able to find a cure, but research costs!
JDRF funds around 35% of all research into Type 1 Diabetes worldwide and invests around $200 million into research in Type 1 Diabetes each year.
Some breakthroughs that scientists have already had with Diabetes are the Islet Cell Transplantation and The Insulin Pump.

Islets are cells in the pancreas that produce insulin. Insulin is a hormone that lets people get energy from their food. No one can live without insulin. When you have Type 1 Diabetes your Islet cells have stopped working. Islet transplantation replaces the islets so you can make insulin again. You can then live without insulin injections and worrying about HYPOS or getting serious health problems from Diabetes.

Islet transplantation still isn't available for most people with Diabetes as there are problems finding enough islets and also with the drugs you need to stop your body from rejecting the islets. We need more research to solve these two problems before islet transplants will be safe for children and all people with Type 1 Diabetes.
The pump is another way of delivering the insulin to the body by a tube constantly attached to the body. The pump is about the size of a pager and must be worn throughout the day.

A few of my friends have the pump and say that it is easier to manage their Diabetes. However there is a huge cost involved, not only buying the pump but also in running it. It costs about $300 a month.
What I ask of you—

speech.para: she says to me—

quote.para: ... is to please support any promising possibilities that may come up to help researchers find a cure and please promise to remember me when making decisions regarding funding for further research.

speech.para: It is a compelling case from someone like Tiffany. She has left me a wonderful album of her and her story and tells me about her mum, Melanie; her father, Ian; and her sister, Nicole—and I have had the pleasure of meeting both Melanie and Nicole. I know how difficult it has been for them and I hope that before she turns 20 there is a cure for diabetes. In respect of her request that I promise to remember her, can I say: Tiffany, after meeting you, you are a delightful and talented young woman, and I will never forget you.

talk.start.para: —Can I say that all members associated with the activities today would endorse the sentiments expressed by the member for Hasluck.

—The successful implementation of the federal government's meningococcal C vaccination program was dependent on the cooperation of the Commonwealth and state governments, general practitioners and other immunisation providers, as well as the community as a whole. I am sorry to say that the New South Wales government has let us down. Bob Carr shows little interest. Today a year 9 student from a Central Coast high school was diagnosed with C-strain meningococcal disease—the more vicious strain of the disease. It is responsible for a third of meningococcal cases and the majority of deaths.

speech.para: This is the third year 9 student from Terrigal High School to be diagnosed with the vicious disease this week. Two of the children have just come out of comas; the third one went in today. If the New South Wales government had implemented the school based roll-out of the vaccination schedule and listened to the genuine concerns of Australians, to the federal Minister for Health and Ageing and the claims that I have made, these three 15-year-olds from the Central Coast would not be in hospital, as we speak.

The federal government has invested huge amounts of money on its meningococcal C vaccination program—$291 million over four years to protect those most at risk of this disease. Of this, $82 million was allocated for New South Wales, including more than $78 million for the meningococcal C vaccine and another $4 million to deliver the school based immunisation clinics. Yet the Bob Carr Labor government cannot be bothered to deliver the vaccines to schoolchildren—not even schoolchildren in the high-risk regions like the Central Coast.

In June I rose in parliament to urge the New South Wales health minister to speed up the school based roll-out of the vaccination program to ensure that as many young Australians as possible were protected against meningococcal C disease before the winter, the peak season for meningococcal disease. Similarly, the federal Minister for Health and Ageing issued a statement earlier this year urging the New South Wales government to implement the roll-out as soon as possible to protect the lives of children at risk. Unfortunately, the New South Wales government did not act. Victorian students were treated with the national vaccine on schedule earlier this year before the peak season for meningococcal began. In June 2003 around 400,000 doses of meningococcal C vaccine had already been distributed in that state.
In June this year the federal health minister highlighted the difference in performance between states, saying:

quote.para: “Victoria's rollout is a far cry from New South Wales where I understand there has been little evidence of action. This is of great concern given the annual peak meningococcal season starts in winter ...”

speech.para: Two months later, only a handful of schools on the Central Coast have students who have been vaccinated. The Central Coast Area Health Service says students in all schools will be vaccinated by the end of the year. The Central Coast Area Health Service was due to start vaccinations at Terrigal High School on 27 August. That is almost the end of the peak season. Now, after three cases of meningococcal disease from that high school, they have brought the vaccination start date forward to 24 August. That is absolutely ridiculous. The slow response in New South Wales to this life-threatening disease has sparked much concern from my constituents. In the last week I have received daily phone calls from residents concerned for the safety of their children. Oral antibiotics have since been given to all year 9 students at Terrigal High School to help prevent the disease developing further.

Meningococcal disease can strike without warning. It can be extremely difficult to diagnose, yet in its early stages it can be stop-ped. In the winters of 2001 and 2002 too many families on the Central Coast lost their children to this disease. The Central Coast has rates of meningococcal which are am-ongst the highest in Australia. The Central Coast accounts for three per cent of the population of New South Wales and has approximately 15 per cent of the state's meningococcal infections. Yet the New South Wales government cannot be prompt with their vaccinations. They do not take this issue seriously. My question to the New South Wales health minister is: how many more children must die in my electorate before you deem the situation serious enough to warrant immediate action? How many children must be savagely scarred or lose their limbs before you take notice? Central Coast area health authority efforts in dealing with meningococcal have also been limited in terms of the release of information about the disease, including infection rates and new cases. It is ironic that the New South Wales government have been complacent about the two factors of awareness and vaccination. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The desire to protect old-growth forests, to end their destruction through clear-felling and fire, is not a new phenomenon. It motivated the creation of many of our national parks and World Heritage areas. It was a foundation principle of the National Forest Policy Statement of 1992, which had an objective to:

quote.para: ... facilitate the industry's move from old-growth to regrowth and other managed native forests and plantations.

speech.para: It shared equal billing with resource security in the creation of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement of 1997. Following extensive statewide community forums, it was restated in the Tasmania Together benchmarks, Tasmania's document of a vision for the future.

Poll after poll shows the protection of old-growth forests is the majority wish of the Tasmanian community. Further proof is de-monstrated by the thousands of people who rallied at a clear-fell site in the Styx Valley, 90 kilometres west of Hobart, on 13 July. They voted with their feet to remove the bulldozers and chains from unique eucalypt, myrtle and sassafras forests in places like the Styx Valley, the Savage River corridor, the Great Western Tiers and the southern forests. The rally was hailed as the largest gathering in the wilderness since the Franklin 20 years ago.

Moving to end the deeply unpopular practice of clear-felling old-growth forests and to speed the transition to plantations has been an agreed political agenda for over a decade. But are we moving fast enough and in the right direction? It has always been clear that the federal framework established a benchmark for minimum standards. Its end point was meant to be a final transition out of old-growth. The National Forest Policy Statement proposed minimum national standards for the comprehensive, adequate and representative protection of forest types. Its evolution allowed compromises to be made, and that is one of the reasons why there are people today who believe that too many important and ecologically rich forests still fall inside the RFA boundaries.

The vast majority of my constituents in Denison want clear-felling to end. They do not want to see Eucalyptus regnans, the mighty swamp gums which are hundreds of years old and the tallest hardwood trees on earth, sent to the pulp and paper mills of Japan, where they become comics and toilet paper. No-one is advocating an end to forestry. No-one wishes to see economic hardship inflicted on those Tasmanian families and communities who rely on timber harvesting, transport and processing for their livelihoods. Clearly, significant economic and socioeconomic benefits have flowed, and continue to flow, from the forest industries. But the proportion of the industry that relies on clear-felling of old-growth forests is now miniscule, and times have changed. The President of Timber Workers for Forests, Graham Green, states that the industry has shed 4,000 jobs in the past decade, while dozens of small sawmills have been shut down. Mr Green claims:

quote.para: ...there may be as little as 12 years supply of special species timbers left.

speech.para: He goes on to say this threatens the loss of $35 million each year that the specialty timber industry generates. While forestry has given us economic wealth in the past, there is an increasing public perception that we are now selling our heritage short. Forestry Tasmania, the government body which manages the public forests, persistently runs at a loss to the taxpayer, while Gunns Ltd, the world's biggest regional wood chipping company, announces record profits.

Tasmanians feel they have lost the right to have a say in the future of old-growth forests. Forest practices operate largely outside the state planning scheme and the Tasmanian threatened species law. These practices are exempt from state freedom of information laws and key parts of the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. In contrast, the New South Wales Land and Environment Court gives individuals, communities and groups a vehicle for challenging forest practices. In Western Australia the Gallop government ended logging in the last great jarrah and kauri forests of the south.

Locally, Tasmania's tourist operators and businesses who depend on the state's clean, green image are nervous. Our island is in the news overseas for all the wrong reasons. Economically, in a world where wilderness is a dwindling and precious asset, ecotourism is one industry assured of growth. We are being accused of vandalism—ironically, by nations like Britain who have already lost all, or nearly all, of their original forests. For overseas visitors, the notion of forests untouched by an axe is magnetic. Everyone wants their children to be able to experience what it is to walk through a truly wild place, an ecosystem that breathes out pure oxygen for our needy planet.

To make sure they are not seen as a silent majority, concerned Tasmanians continue to write to their newspapers, march in their thousands and attend public meetings and parliamentary hearings. The forestry debate is complex and, in Tasmania particularly, fraught with emotion. The fact remains that the public is demanding a new approach—an end to clear-felling wild forests and a new beginning where these ancient trees can have a lasting value beyond the paltry price offered for them as woodchips. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last Friday, I drove to Bowral and met with a lovely, gentle, intelligent 12-year-old girl who was accompanied by her parents, Karen and Professor Alan Hayes. Today I renewed my acquaintance with that young lady. Her name is Sarah Hayes, and she is one of the many young people who took part in the Kids in the House program held at Parliament House today. She suffers from juvenile diabetes. Young Sarah came to visit me in my office before a program function today and she tested me for diabetes. I am pleased to say that I tested exceptionally well and I am very healthy in that regard. In addition to that, she gave me a little book, which I am going to treasure because it eloquently illustrates the sorts of problems that young children with juvenile diabetes face on a day-to-day basis. With the indulgence of the House, I will read from the book, which is entitled `A Day in My Life'. It is only a small document but it talks about her insulin. She says:

quote.para: I've had diabetes for about a year and eight months. So I have 4 injections a day. My day-time insulin is called Novo Rapid and I use a Novo Pen to administer my dose. My night-time insulin is brand new and I am on trial for it. It is called Glargine or Lantus. There is quite a bit known about it overseas but the Government still wants more information before they subsidise it. I use the Accu-Check finger pricker and it's great because it doesn't hurt. Even though these insulins work really well and don't hurt to the point where I am in tears, I hope I don't have to use them for the whole of my life. I just hope there's a cure in my lifetime.

speech.para: In the book she goes on to talk about her and her family:

quote.para: Even though I hate diabetes, it's a lot easier when you have the support of your family. Mum and Dad are sooooo good about it and they are always trying to understand how I feel which is a pretty hard task and I commend them on doing it so wonderfully. I can't imagine how hard it was for Mum and Dad giving me injections in the first few weeks, I'm incredibly proud of my parents and I know they're proud of me.

speech.para: And finally she talks about her school:

quote.para: I am a very lucky girl. I go to one of the nicest schools in the whole of Australia. Yes I go to Frensham. The founder of the school, Miss West was a pioneer for women who felt education was necessary for young girls. It is a boarding school and has a very caring atmosphere. It makes it a lot easier to be a child with diabetes surrounded by such compassionate people. I am one of the only diabetics in the school; I think that says it all. I go to a very charming and magnificent school and I think that a country as prosperous as Australia should make it one of there missions to make sure that no child will soon have to put up with diabetes especially when a cure is so close.

speech.para: Those words were picked up on by my parliamentary colleagues across the broad spectrum of politics today when each one of them attended that luncheon for these 100 lovely young Australians. I am certain that, like me, many of my parliamentary colleagues had a tear in their eye when they listened to the experiences of these young Australians, aged 13 years and younger, and the way they are handling this disease. I was especially a little bit emotional because this lovely 12-year-old, gentle Australian girl reminded me very much of my 13-year-old grandson, whom I lost last year.

I know the government, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing are aware of the juvenile diabetes problem in our community, but I hope that we can all better appreciate some of the pain and suffering that the young members of our community are going through, particularly with juvenile diabetes. These young children have explained that pain and suffering to us today in a very compassionate, intelligent and caring way. I know that each and every adult in that room today felt very emotional about what the children were saying about how they were coping with diabetes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have recently received answers to some questions on notice that I put to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources concerning the use of ethanol as a fuel replacement for petrol. The minister's answers make it quite clear that the government failed to make even the most elementary calculations about the prospect of using ethanol as a large-scale replacement for petrol fuel in Australia. Mr Speaker, as you are aware, the Howard government promised its benefactor, Mr Dick Honan, that it would force fuel distributors to add 10 per cent ethanol to all petrol sold in Australia. Thanks to the answers provided by the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, it is clear to me that this policy could never have been implemented, because it would have been completely impractical to produce the required amount of ethanol at a reasonable cost. This is one of the great things about putting questions on the Notice Paper and getting information, Mr Speaker.
—I have been doing my best.

—In response to question No. 2110, asking how much of the wheat crop would be required to produce sufficient ethanol to replace 10 per cent of the demand for vehicle fuel, you will be interested to know the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources replied:

quote.para: ... this would require 40.45% of the forecast 2003 wheat crop.

speech.para: In other words, nearly half of the wheat crop would be required to replace 10 per cent of the current consumption of vehicle fuel with ethanol. The government has promoted ethanol as a so-called green fuel while, as the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources in his answer to my question states:

quote.para: Ethanol generally only realises a greenhouse benefit where the feedstock is a waste product (eg low grade molasses, wood waste) ...

speech.para: In my view, the massive production program that would be required would be better used as a crop for food. Alan Ramsey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 August 2003 that the Prime Minister had given Mr Dick Honan the sum of $30.86 million in 16 months. According to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, had the government implemented its program to add 10 per cent ethanol to all fuel sold in Australia, as a benefit of the current production rate subsidy of 38.143c per litre Mr Honan would have been in receipt of $1.336 billion. Mr Speaker, an amount of taxpayers' money to the sum of $1,336 million is a lot of lolly and not a bad return on an investment of a few hundred thousand dollars donated to the Liberal-National coalition parties.

The Prime Minister has been threatening to suspend aid to our Pacific island neighbours if they do not clean out what the Prime Minister sees as corrupt practices in their governments. I ask: what sort of example is the Prime Minister himself setting with his slippery responses that I listened to last week in this House about meetings with a principal donor to his government, let alone with the hastily arranged financial barriers to his benefactor's commercial competitors and the payment of millions of dollars in subsidies to his friend's companies? I am saying that the Prime Minister needs to remove the taint of buying influence from his own government before he has the gall to lecture others about their failings.

We know the Prime Minister has been caught out not telling the parliament and the Australian people the full story about his dealings with Mr Honan and his destructive intervention in the industry. This has been to the serious disadvantage of Trafigura and has overwhelmingly benefited Mr Honan and the Manildra Group. The Prime Minster's personal involvement in this decision is clear and his failure to tell the Australian people the truth is obvious. Australians are entitled to no less than the full truth. The Australian people can have no confidence in the government's policies in relation to alternative fuels or the environment in general. The constituents I represent in my electorate of Lowe, and all Australians, deserve a lot better.

talk.start.para: —I rise to talk about the way in which the Queensland Labor government is perpetuating a lie, perpetuating a mistruth, and, as a consequence, Queensland public hospitals are languishing. The Beattie Labor government spent in excess of $50,000 running full-page advertisements, like the one I am holding, in a national broadsheet claiming that, as a result of the federal government's spending initiative on public hospitals, Queenslanders would be $160 million worse off. But it is a lie—an absolute blatant mistruth. The Beattie Labor government in Queensland is resorting to these kinds of tactics to try to spread fear and misinformation throughout the Queensland community.

speech.para: What are the actual facts? That is the important question. Despite $50,000 full-page advertisements and despite the Queensland Labor government wasting taxpayers' money on commercial radio advertisements on the Gold Coast and in other parts of Queensland, we find that since April of this year the Queensland Labor government has known about the health offer—the spending on public hospitals that the federal government put on the table in April of this year. Yet, in only the past several weeks—coincidentally—the Beattie Labor government has joined forces with the other state Labor governments to suddenly claim that there is not enough money for public hospitals. In fact, Peter Beattie claims that there is $160 million less for Queensland. It begs the question: how can there be $160 million less when the actual increase in funding from the federal government to the Queensland Labor government is 32 per cent? That is an additional $2.1 billion flowing to the Queensland Labor government from the Howard government for public hospitals, and Peter Beattie lies. Not only does he lie, but the Queensland Premier puts advertisements on the radio—

talk.start.para: —The member for Moncrieff will be aware that the accusation of an individual lying is outside the standing orders. Group accusations are undesirable enough. The member for Moncrieff will modify his language.

—Mr Speaker, I withdraw what I said about Peter Beattie lying. It would appear that the Queensland Labor government is spreading misinformation with full intent. It is very clear to me that there cannot be a cut in funding when there is an additional $2.1 billion being made available to the Queensland Labor government. As I said, they have had the opportunity since April to sign up to this agreement, but it has only been in the past several weeks that the Queensland Premier, together with all the other state Labor premiers, has claimed that this money is not enough. The question that needs to be asked is: how much money will the Queensland Labor government spend on public hospitals over the next five years? They will not disclose it. The Queensland Labor government will disclose how much they are prepared to spend in one year, but they will not disclose how much they are prepared to spend over the next five years.

speech.para: Contrast that situation with the Howard government. We are prepared to put on the table—and we have put on the table—how much money we will spend over the next five years. The fact is that the Queensland government is the first government in the whole of the country to be a principal beneficiary of the introduction of the goods and services tax. All the GST revenue flows to the various state governments. The Queensland government is $137 million better off. In response to this, I would highlight that the Premier has form on this issue. Premier Peter Beattie has previously claimed that Queensland would not be better off under the GST. I quote an article from the Courier Mail of 25 April 2003, which said:

quote.para: Premier Peter Beattie has been caught misleading Queenslanders over the state's share of GST revenue as he tries to avoid increasing the funding of public hospitals.
Mr Beattie yesterday claimed the government was unable to fund additional major spending on the hospitals because Queensland would not make a profit from GST revenue until 2006.
But state and federal finance figures show Queensland will soon become the first state to profit from the tax, reaping an estimated $135 million during the next financial year.

speech.para: They will have an additional $135 million. The Beattie Labor government know it. They are trying to spread misinformation. They are wasting taxpayers' money by taking out full-page newspaper and radio advertisements. In short, Queensland health care is sick because of the Queensland government's misinformation and the fact they will not sign up to the federal government's offer.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8 p.m. the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 8.10 p.m.

talker.name: Cameron, Ross, MP
Mr ROSS CAMERON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, thank you for that indulgence. I can assure that it will not require the full 10 minutes. I felt that, as a matter of the public record, I needed to correct a couple of statements made by the member for Lowe—a Labor member for whom I have the highest regard. However, on this occasion, his contribution to the House was not factually based in that he put the proposition that it was the government's policy to achieve 10 per cent production of ethanol in terms of the total fuel refined in Australia and that this would result in a benefit of over $1.3 billion a year to the Manildra company.

speech.para: It has never been the government's policy that we should have 10 per cent ethanol in our fuel. The contemplation of 10 per cent was a cap on the maximum amount of ethanol that could be contained in fuel from the bowser. In fact, the government has moved to put a limit of 10 per cent on any fuel sold. The government's policy on ethanol, which was announced by Warren Truss before the last election, was that we should aim for two per cent of fuel produced to be biofuel—ethanol being the principal, but I think biodiesel being an alternative. That means that we would take the current production of 80 million litres a year to 360 million litres a year.

So suggestions that this would require something like 40 per cent of the wheat crop are completely without foundation. I simply wanted to clarify the record and to say that the government's policy commitment was to two per cent biofuel production over the next 10 years and that that would represent an increase from 80 million litres to 360 million litres a year.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.52 a.m.

talk.start.para: — I remember listening, about 30 years ago, to a prominent high-life South Australian expressing his contempt at what he called third- and fourth-generation indolents who frittered, squandered and lost their high life or endowed inheritances through incompetence and sloth. In fact, he had a name for them: `drop-kicks'. When institutions like the AMP and the NRMA were demutualised, when the State Bank, Ansett, HIH and One.Tel went bust, when the South Australian TAB was sold—at a loss—and when power and water utilities were privatised, I remembered the `drop-kicks' and indolent generations story. Unfortunately, in recent days I have been reminded again of the very same indolent generation with the emergence of the sale of the Cheltenham Racecourse.

speech.para: There are three metropolitan tracks in Adelaide. I agree that only two are required. Morphettville, as the headquarters of the SAJC, controlled by the SAJC and an excellent course, particularly in autumn and spring, must be retained. Cheltenham Park, also controlled by the SAJC and one of the best winter and summer tracks in Australia, must also be retained. Therefore, with Morphettville and Cheltenham, all seasons and all weather are covered.

The third course is Victoria Park Racecourse. It is located on public parkland and is controlled by the Adelaide City Council. It is also the location of a car race and it has been used for equestrian events, and for these events Victoria Park is eminently suitable. To be an effective twin to Morphettville it would need to be an excellent course in winter and summer. The simple fact is that Victoria Park is a bog in winter and rock hard in summer, hardly an encouragement to risk valuable horseflesh. And as an aside, why would the SAJC give up control of 50 per cent of their core business to the Adelaide City Council?

It appears that the SAJC management, administration and committee suffer from a cargo cult mentality in believing that selling the business and assets will solve faulty business plans. It never works in business—just look at the woolly-headed, disastrous plans of AMP, HIH, One.Tel, Ansett, the State Bank of South Australia, the South Australian TAB and so on. If the SAJC is currently losing a million dollars a year, the solution is simple: cut expenditure by $2 million and use the $1 million surplus to fund a business plan that grows horseracing in South Australia and does not diminish it. That requires planned coherent purposes, coherent processes and coherent outcomes.

Only second-rate business people sell their core business and assets for just the money and no other gain. As I have mentioned, Australian business is littered with casualties who did the same. The SAJC have wrong priorities: they should be reminded to look after the basic bread-and-butter assets as this is the basis to secure the cream. Concerning yourself with the cream and ignoring 50 per cent of your core business will only lead to curdling and tears. It has ever been so. Mr Wyndam Hill-Smith must be turning in his grave at this gross and foolhardy behaviour.

I trust that my state government colleagues have both the necessary knowledge and the courage to reject this all too desperate and ill thought out plan. Keep Cheltenham Park Racecourse in the hands of the South Australian Jockey Club. This grand legacy, bequeathed to the current administration, the SAJC committee, should not be squandered away, for, if it is sold, there is nothing more certain. And that is not in the future interests of horseracing in South Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is with sadness that today I advise the House of the death of an untiring advocate for and leader of veterans and the aged in the goldfields of Western Australia. Bob Martain was one of those men who have served their country, and later their local community, in an unassuming manner working steadily in the background to represent the interests of both returned service personnel and the aged. In fact, in addition to shunning the limelight, Bob went as far as playing down his contributions. His children say they were unaware, until just recently, of how much their father had given to the community and the role he had played. The reality of Bob's dedication was made most evident just two weeks before his death when at a service in Perth he was awarded the RSL's prestigious meritorious award for service. This presentation on the day of Bob and Sally's 40th wedding anniversary was made by National President of the RSL Peter Phillips, and WA RSL President William Gaynor. The function was also attended by the federal Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Danna Vale. Apparently Bob was quite impressed with the minister and delighted to have his photograph taken with her. The significance of the meritorious award for service is more obvious with the knowledge that only 20 medals are awarded each year. Of this number, two medals are designated for Western Australia.

speech.para: Bob's passing on 26 July this year has also ended an era for the Boulder sub-branch of the RSL, which he led as president for an impressive 30 years. While many other branches are finding it difficult to maintain membership and to grow, the Boulder sub-branch has experienced a revival attributed largely to the efforts and dedication of Bob Martain.

As a person, Bob gave his time willingly to help others. In addition to being a life member and president of the Boulder RSL, he was a foundation member of the charitable trust fund, a foundation member of the Goldfields War Museum, Chairperson of the Goldfields Volunteer Task Force, a member of the Order of the Old Bastards, country vice-president of the state RSL executive committee and a commissioner for declarations.

Born in 1939 at Youanmi in the north-eastern goldfields, Bob gave nine years full-time service in the Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers Unit of the Army, including 12 months as a sergeant armourer based in Vietnam. It was these experiences which resulted in his extraordinary dedication to the RSL movement and its values.

Bob was a member of a close-knit family and is survived by his wife, Sally, by his children, Reggie, Debbie, Jodie and Kerrie, and by six grandchildren, to whom I offer my sympathies. In ending, I want to say that men such as Bob Martain are an example to us all. Their selfless acts are an inspiration to our leaders and make our communities richer places to live in. Veterans in our communities are ageing and this is evident at every subsequent Anzac or Rememberance Day function that we attend. Like many veterans, Bob did not speak of his experiences of war, and this is a consequence that families find difficult to live with and which we as a government need to recognise. Instead, Bob gave his life to helping others and to supporting the values and the work of the Returned and Services League. Veterans have served their nation and their communities well and for this they must not be forgotten.

subdebateinfo.title: Melbourne Ports Electorate: South Port Parks Parish Mission

talk.start.para: —Last Saturday I had the opportunity to attend the South Port Parks Parish Uniting Church Mission's 150th anniversary celebrations in South Melbourne. I want to pay tribute to the work—indeed, the ongoing work—the Uniting Church has done throughout South Melbourne and Port Melbourne over 150 years. It was a great achievement for Ian Breward to have presented to the 150 or so supporters of the South Port mission gathered there the wonderful history of the church's charitable and philanthropic activities throughout what is now my electorate. The Rev. Peter Greenwood, Mr Jeff Castles, Malcolm McIlvena and all the people there deserve great credit for the continuing work that the mission does on behalf of its disadvantaged, infants and other people who need their assistance.

—I apologise for being a little out of breath. I want to speak briefly today about the issue of juvenile diabetes. Members will be aware that representatives of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation and a large number of sufferers and their families were yesterday and are today present in the building to try to highlight the issue of juvenile diabetes in the community. Briefly, as a disease it is particularly pernicious in its impact. It affects young children and it is one of the most costly chronic diseases of childhood and one you never outgrow. Insulin does not cure it. While insulin allows a person to stay alive, it does not cure diabetes, nor does it prevent its eventual devastating effects.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! It being 10.00 a.m., in accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 2003

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003. International education is enormously valuable to Australia in social, economic and political terms. We are all increasingly aware of its position of growing importance as a $5 billion export industry—Australia's second largest service export—but we must not forget the many other benefits that it provides us with. The educational benefits of the different cultural perspectives that international students bring to the classroom cannot be overestimated. This contribution adds to the education of all students—those coming from overseas and those already here. That was certainly my personal experience when I was at the University of Sydney doing a bachelor of economics degree.

speech.para: We should not forget the longer-term benefits for Australia in terms of goodwill within our region. When international students return to their home countries with a greater understanding of Australia and positive memories of their time here, there are flow-on benefits to the nation as a whole from the personal linkages created between countries. Australia's international education industry is one of our great success stories. Built on a reputation for high-quality education, Australian universities have the second highest proportion of international students in the world and the third largest enrolments in absolute terms.

Just yesterday the Department of Education, Science and Training released new statistics that indicate that, once again, international student enrolments in our universities grew significantly this year. This year international student enrolments are up by over 24,000, to 170,000—17 per cent growth. This includes an increase of over 8,000 in the number of commencing students, to 63,000. This represents 15 per cent growth.

The Howard government's $5 billion cuts to operating grants have caused massive increases in class sizes, jeopardising their capacity to provide a quality education to their students. Universities have been forced to look to alternative sources of revenue to fill this hole, and fees from international students have been a major contributor to this cause. This has led to a situation in which there are more students but no more money, and therefore not enough teachers, not enough classrooms and not enough books. These pressures are entirely of the Howard government's making.

But to be a real triumph such impressive growth in international enrolments must be matched by equally impressive growth in Australian enrolments. That is not the case currently, and yesterday's figures reveal that Howard government policies have resulted in the number of commencing Australian undergraduates dropping for the second year in a row. This is not sustainable if we are to prosper in the global knowledge economy. However, Australia cannot rely upon past success in the international education market. Having worked hard for our reputation as a high-quality provider of education services, we must be vigilant in preventing those seeking to cash in on this reputation from undermining our position.

Labor has long held concerns about the potential for a few unscrupulous education institutions to undermine Australia's reputation as a provider of high-quality education. While the approach set out in this bill is not the one that we would have taken, it is an improvement on existing arrangements, and Labor will therefore be supporting the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003. This bill creates a fairer system of levying charges on education providers for registration on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students, making the charge relative to the size of an institution's enrolments. Additional revenue will be used to support the work of DEST in ensuring compliance under the ESOS Act.

I also want to note the comments in the explanatory memorandum that indicate that one impetus behind this bill was opposition questioning through the Senate estimates process. As I indicated, Labor is concerned about the actions of a minority of providers acting in unscrupulous ways and damaging our international reputation. It is pleasing to see the government acknowledging the work of the opposition in pursuing these issues. While progress has been made in recent years as a result of continued questioning through parliamentary committees, Labor remains concerned and we will continue to pursue these issues.

This bill forms part of the government's international education package announced in the budget. This package has been strongly criticised by parts of the education sector—in particular the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee. Labor has listened to these concerns and in Aim Higher: Learning, Training and Better Jobs for More Australians, our policy announced in July, we committed to work with the education sector to reallocate existing expenditure to programs which support international education and enhance exports. Labor will initiate discussions with the sector to determine how government can best support the efforts of the education sector in maintaining quality.

Labor's Aim Higher package also provides for other initiatives that will be invaluable in assuring the rest of the world of the high quality and standards in our universities. Labor will introduce expert academic panels to randomly sample student assessment to ensure high and consistent standards in the awarding of student marks. Labor will also ensure that international students studying at offshore campuses of Australian universities are provided with the same quality assurances as those studying in Australia, by providing the necessary funding for the Australian Universities Quality Agency to audit all campuses of Australian universities, including those overseas.

More fundamentally, Labor's Aim Higher package will not just improve quality assurance mechanisms; it will provide the necessary resources to address substantive issues of the resources available to deliver quality education and protect and enhance our international reputation. Labor will provide universities with an additional $2.3 billion, including: $347 million to fix the Howard government's failed system of overenrolments by funding all students at the full rate; $312 million to enhance quality by maintaining the value of operating grants, easing the pressure on class sizes and increasing the resources for libraries and laboratories; $150 million through the learning performance fund to assist and reward high-quality teaching; and $450 million through the `universities of the 21st century' fund to allow universities to become modern institutions of learning and to update their methods of teaching and learning.

This package provides an integrated approach to providing the necessary resources to universities to deliver a high-quality university system and a rigorous system of quality assurance so that students both here and overseas are confident that the education they receive from an Australian university is consistently high. In addition to supporting this bill, Labor remain concerned about the actions of some international education institutions and we will maintain our vigilance in pursuing unscrupulous providers through parliamentary committees. Labor will also continue to work with the education sector to ensure that government supports the success of our international education industry through both the resources needed to maintain a high-quality system and a regulatory framework that guarantees quality without imposing unnecessary regulatory burdens. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to support the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003 in the House. It is an important move in terms of the education services for overseas students, which is certainly an area which is growing as an export segment for Australia. Some 10 years ago it was not at the level it is today, but the forecast is for even further growth in this area.

speech.para: As chairman of the Trade Subcommittee, which is a subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I visited Eastern Europe.
