The subcommittee went to Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Slovenia and Croatia. My colleagues—the group being led by Senator Alan Ferguson—went on to Romania and Bulgaria. One of the things that were interesting was the opportunities for education services from those countries in particular, as there are from various places around the world. Australia is particularly attractive to those countries. We already receive some 1,500 students each year from Central Europe, but the forecast is that within the next couple of years it will grow quickly to 3,000 or 3,500. The Czech Republic is the biggest of those.

During our visits it was clear that the reasons why Australia is an attractive place to go were, firstly, the English language facility; secondly, the multicultural environment—which sometimes we take for granted in Australia—in that it provides a good environment and people coming from various parts of the world can feel at home and find their own ethnic group or language group within the country; thirdly, the fact that Australia's tourist environment is important; and, fourthly, the fact that students can work for up to 20 hours a week. Britain, which is finding that some of its student markets have slipped to Australia, has now changed its requirements. It is enabling students to work a similar number of hours in the UK, but we have got an advantage in that the perception is that we allow people to work. That has been quite helpful to enable them to afford to pay for themselves in Australia.

It is an emerging market for us, not only in Central Europe, which we visited. We are certainly making a recommendation in our report, which is, I think, being tabled in the next sitting period, that we should put more emphasis on and more resources into supporting this effort. It also applies in South-East Asia, South America and Scandinavia. It is widespread. We have been very successful. With regard to the standard of Australia's academic institutions, it is obviously important that they are recognised as being amongst the best in the world. Generally, in terms of Central Europe, the feedback was that the preference is the UK, the United States and Australia. Since September 11 there has been some caution in travelling to the States; nevertheless, they receive a large number of students and, of course, they have very fine institutions, as does the UK. It is particularly interesting that we are seen as competing in that segment.

This bill is important to continue to regulate the activities of students in Australia, in terms of registration charges and in terms of assistance to our universities. It is not only about our foreign relations and is not only about developing our tourist trade. The tourism industry sees it as an excellent way of developing tourism, and not necessarily for the short term, although these people travel extensively around Australia and there are enormous benefits. If you track the record of people who have come as students, they end up coming back to Australia at later stages, often with their wives and families, and become great ambassadors for the country. So it is important in tourism terms. In terms of foreign relations it is important that there are people who have lived in our country, who understand it and who can promote it within their own countries. Also, it is an important source of revenue because the universities have the ability to charge the overseas students what they see as being the appropriate market rate. That is to the benefit of all the other students who attend the universities, in that it leads to the improvement of facilities at those universities. I believe that students bringing their own dimensions from their own countries enrich the campuses in which they participate.

There are many good reasons why we should continue to support and encourage the education services market. I am very pleased to see the opposition is supporting this bill as well. Overseas student enrolments in educational institutions are of great benefit to Australia, both on a cultural and an economic level. As an industry, higher education is experiencing significant growth, as I have mentioned. Its value to the Australian economy has risen from $700 million in 1991 to over $5 billion today, and it continues to rise. The education system needs to be nurtured by government to ensure its continued success, and this is of course what this bill is about.

With the right policies and intellectual infrastructure in place, Australia will continue to be known as the clever country, capable of providing a quality and level of education unrivalled in our region. We are a small nation in world scale, accounting for only 1.2 per cent of world GDP and representing only 0.3 per cent of world population. We clearly punch above our weight. As a country, we rely heavily on our intellectual capabilities when competing with the rest of the world. We rely on our ability to produce a quality product, develop new technologies and attract large numbers of overseas students. International students represent over 14 per cent of students onshore and offshore for Australia. This is the second highest proportion in the world. In some university faculties, overseas student representation is over 50 per cent. With one particular college that I have a relationship with, the International School of Hotel Management and Tourism in Manly, some 65 per cent of its students are from overseas. Many of them are from Scandinavia. It is providing people for the tourism industry right around the world. It is doing a wonderful job.

Education services is now in fact Australia's third largest export services sector. This represents a very significant increase in recent years and represents a significant contribution to Australia's balance of payments. It generates more export dollars than the wool industry and almost as much as the wheat industry. Its value continues to rise on a yearly basis. It is interesting to note how some of the educational institutions were initially established. The college in Manly was established out of a growth of tourism educational facilities in Switzerland. Now the college is considering taking over the Swiss facility. So the Australian image and standards are seen as being very internationally competitive.

In a similar way, there has been the incredible growth in the tourism industry. If we look back to 1975, as the member for Gilmore, who is with me in the chamber, would know, we had half a million visitors. Now we have 4½ million. If it had not been for SARS and the events of September 11 and October 12, perhaps we would have gone past the five million level. We are seeing the same trend with international students. Following another record, there are now in excess of 190,000 international students studying in Australian universities, vocational education and training institutions, schools and English language training colleges. With the almost 400 per cent growth experienced in the past seven years, there is now a greater need for regulation. The whole area of education services really is a good news story on so many levels. The government too realises this piece of legislation is not only about education. As my colleague the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson, stated following the budget:

quote.para: International students provide the foundation for strong foreign and trade relations, as well as research and scientific exchanges and collaborations that are vital to our continued economic growth and development.

speech.para: It is the future leaders of our region coming to Australia and understanding the Australian way of life that is one of the absolute pluses of this bill. They will be able to make a positive affirmation of the nature of our country and all of the wonderful attributes that we in Australia recognise and value. Students will be provided with an opportunity to build a global network of friends, acquaintances and future business partners. This happens through modern emails. I understand, from knowing a whole number of students at the Manly college, that students do this all the time for years after they have been through the college, even though they are located in various parts of the world. Students will develop an understanding of globalisation through the development of international views and cross-cultural communication.

International students have become political and business leaders in our region. They hold Australia and Australians in high regard. One of the interesting things that I found during my time in the tourism industry was how many of the leaders in tourism and hotel chains and businesses in Malaysia had actually studied in Australia. I think it was also quite interesting that during the Olympic period when we were chasing up people, as the deputy leader would know, several of the people who had to vote on whether Sydney secured the games had actually been students in Australia. One of our strongest supporters, Dr Nat Intrapana from Thailand, organised a lot of the numbers—and we know what that means politically. He was a student in Australia for a number of years; he did a PhD here. He was enormously supportive of Australia. So there are various benefits to come from that means.

Students come from as near as Malaysia, Hong Kong and China and from as far afield as South America and Europe. This internationalisation is testimony to the outstanding reputation, level of service and quality of courses that this country offers, and this piece of legislation will maintain and enhance these benefits. To achieve its objectives, the Department of Education, Science and Training will receive $5.1 million to ensure the enforcement of measures assuring the quality and integrity of education providers in Australia that enrol overseas students. This will be proceeding over a four-year period and will be budget neutral so will not increase costs to the Commonwealth.

I think we would all agree that there is currently in place an inequitable fee structure for all providers registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students. The new fee structure will be put in place to redress this apparent imbalance. Announced in this year's budget, the new structure will be $300 per provider per annum, plus a $25 enrolment fee for each student. For approximately 550 providers, half of those registered, there will therefore be little or no change to the amount currently being paid. How enrolment is defined will not be affected. A course covering more than 26 weeks will constitute a whole course and one under 26 weeks a half course. These amendments will not be changing the way enrolments are calculated. This is also good news as it provides equality for providers and students alike. No-one will pay more than another and no-one will pay less than another. Any suggestion that it would impact more greatly on urban areas as opposed to regional areas, or vice-versa, is incorrect.

Like many industries, education services are no stranger to problems. The current ESOS Act has established key national elements for the regulation of the international education and training services industry. Acting in consultation with industries and state, territory and Commonwealth agencies, this government has taken a responsible step towards addressing the issues identified as problem areas. These include the uncertain financial protection for students' prepaid course fees, the emergence of a small minority of unscrupulous providers and inconsistent quality assurance. I am sure that the House will be very interested in all of those factors to ensure the quality we provide in education services.

Since the original act was introduced in 1991, it has become obvious to Senate inquiries that certain parts of the legislation needed to be reviewed. Some of the provisions, once tested, were found to be deficient. What it will protect against, though, are the rogue providers who offer students courses at reduced costs in order that they can gain entry into Australia. It is widely felt that these providers bring the industry into disrepute, and these changes will prevent such actions. The bill will provide for sanctions against noncompliant providers, with the strongest action being cancellation of registration for noncompliance.

The bill will ensure that education providers clearly understand what is expected of them in providing education for international students. Operators who see this as a way of circumventing Australia's visa requirements will be sadly disappointed. Members of the industry themselves, no doubt, appreciate the need to maintain a reputation in order to foster the industry's long-term growth. It has been suggested—and I quite agree—that a bad provider could have ramifications that extend to Australia not being a desired choice for education. That applies in the tourism industry as well, as the member for Gilmore would well know.

We must remember that education services is a competitive international commodity, so it is important to preserve Australia's interest in this field. The bill will ensure that our international reputation as a high-quality and reputable education provider is protected. We want international students to come to Australia and this bill will encourage them to do so. The bill before us will tighten up the requirements and ensure that those who choose Australia as their education provider over all our competitors can be assured of a level of quality from the underlying guarantees. Thanks to the coalition government, overseas students choosing the Australian experience in education will be doing so with the confidence that we run a quality and genuine industry. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003 is an enforcement bill linked to a bill that seeks to have greater equity in the way that fees are charged—essentially on a per student basis, rather than on a provider basis. Also, an enforcement mechanism is attached to that. Not enough money has been coming in because of what has been happening with some providers. The expectation is that, in evening up the charges between large and small providers and changing that to a per student basis, more money will come to the Commonwealth, and it will come more quickly because the essential basis of this is fairer and less burdensome to those who are smaller providers.

speech.para: The opposition are in favour of the measures within this bill because we have, in fact, in the past called for them. The shadow minister for education, in her discussions in the past with not only members of peak industry bodies but also service providers and as a result of what has come through committee work in this area, has become acutely aware of some significant problems within this area that need to be addressed. Labor have asked for this to be done and we are entirely supportive of what is happening within this fee structure.

We are also suggesting a series of changes to the way in which fee structures are applied domestically, within Australia. If you look at these changes in rebalancing larger and smaller providers to allow the smaller providers—those with the least money, least access and least ability to absorb changes and the costs of running educational institutions—a better go, one could make a comparison with students who are poorer and therefore least able to access the system and least able to afford the costs of university or other higher education but whose skills and abilities will be needed by the country. The government made some changes some years ago to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, where there was an equivalent rate across all students. That equivalent rate dealt with all: big or small, rich or poor. Everyone was paying for the same access to all disciplines. The government changed it for medicine and law, and for science and engineering courses. In doing so, they ratcheted up the costs relative to the increased cost of presenting those courses within universities.

I argue now, as Labor have argued recently, that we need to change the costs of those core structures, particularly in the areas of our greatest need—in nursing and in some of the scientific disciplines—where the costs may be higher but the community and national need is much greater. We need to have the flexibility to again look at the fee-charging scheme that we have. The government have been smart enough to realise that in this area, if you are going to get the right result, you need to rebalance on the basis of the size of the institution and its ability to pay, and that there is a national good at the end of that. I would also argue that we need to extend that to our arrangements in terms of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. Labor have already indicated that they are willing to do that, that there is a national good at the end of that and that what drives that is a question of the skills sets that we need to develop within Australia.

Where this has been done with overseas students, the sustainability of the colleges that are providing the training should be greater as a result of these measures. I would argue that the sustainability of our higher education system, particularly dealing with the sciences, where we have such a dearth, would be greater and would lead to a greater national good if there was a rejigging of the charge structure in that area and if the overweighted charges were brought back to the commonality of charges within the HECS area. That is one area of the bill which deals with the practicalities of how you get the smaller institutions in particular to survive, and to survive well.

In the period 1984-85, John Dawkins, as Minister for Employment, Education and Training, confronted a series of problems and brought in measures that gave Australia an enormous new market. That market was overseas students. Prior to 1984-85 and the measures that he put in place, relatively small numbers of people came in from overseas to study within Australia. Previously, we had the Colombo Plan providing overseas students, and a broad range of people came on assisted programs. What was provided was fee-for-service access to Australia's education system. That access was based, firstly, on willingness to pay and, secondly, on the recognition that, once people paid those fees, they should be given a quality education, which Australia could provide in much better fashion than all of the countries surrounding us in the region, as some of the features of an Australian education were not available there. Even where those countries in the region shared the same colonial background as us, their education systems did not have the strength, depth and width that ours did. They did not have the broad range of courses or the sets of skills that were inherent in Australian universities and educational colleges. They did not have the strength of teaching in English and total command of English that we could provide. We could provide the stream through which people could move to train in the commercial language which is now dominant on the planet.

What Mr Dawkins did in 1984-85 was adventurous, but it brought with it a whole series of problems that had to be dealt with later by the last Labor government. Some of those are the core difficulties being addressed here. If you provide an open service directed towards bringing people in from all over the world to use your educational facilities, the openness of your arrangements can in fact be used against you. In the period of the eighties and nineties, we saw unscrupulous providers operating to the detriment of the students coming into Australia and also to the detriment of Australian education and its reputation. Very strong measures had to be taken on the registration of those bodies and, in some cases, they were closed down, because they were doing great damage to our educational system and to the marketability of the education that we were providing.

The measures in this bill in relation to charges rebalance the situation of access to Australian education, for those students wishing to use it. It rebalances the situation for different providers and we are supportive of that. But it also rebalances the effective controls on these providers and these are needed to ensure that our image as a desired education destination is not damaged. The explanatory memorandum points this out, along with three other things: firstly, there is a fear of a decrease in student numbers; secondly, there is a possibility of sparking international relations issues with the source countries affected, and we are wary of that; and, thirdly, there is the possibility of further community pressure on the government to more tightly control the inflow and movements of overseas students to Australia. We had those significant problems before and those problems were addressed, but the measures in this bill attempt to tighten up in that area, because those problems are again nascent and increasing. It is better to crack down now and ensure the integrity of that system than to let it go the other way. A key area of focus is how you rebalance the payment system and ensure that a stronger system goes forward into the future. What is the fundamental reason for that? It is that the strength of the system will ensure that Australia maintains the income it is already getting and that it expands the platform for bringing in even greater numbers of students to benefit from what we can offer them.

However, we cannot be in a situation where we are the prey of rogue providers—where we are used simply as a mechanism to access our economy rather than our education system. The other major punitive part of this bill addresses the enforcement of the previous arrangements, which are contained in the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000. A series of problems have emerged and the peak providers and reputable people within the education industry have become significantly worried that the provisions in the act are not yet sufficiently enforceable, because people have been able to slide out and around them.

I will now talk about what the chief elements of this bill encompass. The first element is to ensure that only providers of those courses registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students may offer or provide courses to students on student visas, because if you allow people who are not so registered or controlled to do it you break down the integrity of what is provided. The second element is to ensure that international students in Australia receive the education and training for which they have paid. That is critical. If we are offering the service, they should be getting the service that has been paid for. In my electorate of Blaxland some years back we had extreme difficulties with that in the initial stages. When overseas students first came to Australia there were providers that did not operate within the law. Those providers were shut down because they were doing enormous damage to our reputation. They were also ripping off the students who were coming to take advantage of the courses that were being offered. So that strengthening is very important. Students should get value for money. They should know that if they come to Australia they will not have their pockets stripped out and they will not be sent back home with nothing. We must ensure that we give what we say we will give.

The third element that this bill attempts to achieve in this regard is to ensure that taxpayers are not required to recompense overseas students who have been let down by individual education and training providers. Some years ago we saw a series of collapses of education and training providers. We have seen a series of major collapses of major Australian companies in the insurance area and so on. Somebody has to pay in the end, and it is usually not the executives of the company; it is usually not those people who are otherwise associated with it. It is usually the shareholders of the company or the general citizens of the country at large. We have seen from the impact of the fall of HIH and other companies that there is always an end point where the costs are borne by every Australian, where they are not taken up otherwise. Those costs have been of the order of $4 billion. We are not dealing with figures like that here. But whenever a dodgy provider of education fails and foreign students have the right to claim recompense for their time, their effort and the moneys they have paid, because they have not received their due, who pays? We pay. Proper enforcement of our registration systems and standards is in our interests in terms of not only our reputation but the pockets of Australians and the fact that we are not, because of some unconscionable providers, coughing up willy-nilly to people who need to be recompensed.

The next element is a matter of protecting the reputation and integrity of not only Australia's education and training export industry but our other industries as well. We are known region-wide and worldwide as producers of quality products that are quality assured and quality tested. The enforcement regime encompassed within this bill is similar to the quality assurance mechanisms that are built in to our food industry, our electronics industry and all of the industries that develop and export our elaborately transformed manufactures—which in the mid to late eighties became our most significant new range of exports. That quality assurance ensures that once someone buys a good, a service or a product from Australia they can be sure that it is tested and meets Australian and international standards. In this more difficult area, where we are dealing with the quality assurance of service provision to human beings, this must be rigidly enforced. Otherwise we will very quickly get the reputation that the quality education that has been on sale in the past will not be on sale in the future. That is a detriment not just to students in small training colleges; it is a detriment to Australia's reputation as an international education provider through not just the smaller training entities but our major universities and colleges of higher education.

The last key element that is dealt with in the explanatory memorandum concerns strengthening public confidence in the integrity of the student visa system. We know from significant problems we have had in the past that the question of what happens with the student visa system is central. We know that there are particular problems. We had massive problems in terms of Tiananmen Square and the reaction to that. There were 49,000 students then in Australia and those students were allowed to stay. The ongoing impact of that was that 200,000 to 300,000 people eventually came as one group. We know that a number of those students, whilst they were undertaking educational courses—and doing so properly and correctly—could work for 20 hours a week. Most students did that but some students worked 80 hours a week. Some students coming to Australia on visas, particularly coming from poorer countries, see a student education visa as an entry not to education in English or to education in a particular field but to the Australian market, where we have properly said you can work 20 hours a week. Our students generally have to work in order to help support themselves. You can have that access to Australia's economy to help support yourself and your studies.

Unless you rigorously enforce the way in which service providers conduct themselves and the way in which students work within Australia, you could end up with the situation where the whole student visa system could come into question. This is a massively important part of our income earning from overseas, and the integrity of the system is fundamental. This bill underlines the integrity of that system and the reputation of Australia's service provision in education. The reason it is here is that the existing bill could not do it because some of the service providers did not want to take note of what those provisions and what those regulations were. In enforcing this properly there is a small budget impact, and the explanatory memorandum says the government expects to receive about $5.1 million over four years on an ongoing basis from increased compliance and enforcement activities. That does not seem to be all that much money, but if you think about how it adds up in every four-year period, it does indicate that there is a fundamental reason for this bill and that the enforcement provisions are important.
I will finish on the key area in terms of the criticisms from those people who have given evidence about what the situation is at the moment. The memorandum says:

quote.para: Criticisms have been raised that too little action has been taken against rogue providers who, for example, offer courses at below cost to students whose primary purpose is to gain entry to Australia, which calls into question the integrity of the industry as a whole.

speech.para: The objective of this act is to ensure that action can be taken on those people who, for their own personal benefit and their own pecuniary interest, want to take advantage of the provision of education in Australia and our education systems, to the disadvantage of those students they are supposedly providing that service for and to the disadvantage, in the end, of all Australians. They should be hammered down very hard. This bill does it, Labor support it, we have called for it, and we trust that it will succeed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003, and I am pleased to hear that Labor is also supporting this bill. It is not the most complicated piece of legislation that we are ever likely to debate in the House; it is actually a realignment of the fees that are embedded in the schedule attached to the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000. Currently, there is a five-tiered arrangement where, if providers are accommodating a certain number of students within the five bands, they are charged a fee. On the surface, that might seem like a good idea. However, under the existing regime if you are in the business of providing a couple of hundred places you pay a little over $4,000 towards the cost of monitoring and overseeing the industry, while someone providing just under 400 places is also paying a little over $4,000.

speech.para: Under this package, that will change to appoint a base fee and then a per-student fee, which is not an unreasonable change to make. Those with an interest in this, as I have, would know that you have some providers with a handful of students, you have one provider with over 9,000 international students as part of their student population and you have another eight that have between 4,000 and 5,000 students. So there are some very substantial providers, and we are looking for those very substantial providers to make an equitable contribution to the supervision, regulation and quality assurance framework that is provided in the Education Services for Overseas Students Act.

In effect, this legislation is not about providing some new tools; it is about providing the financial horsepower to properly exercise the tools that are there. The previous speaker, the member for Blaxland, correctly outlined the concerns that gave rise to this legislation for a strengthened regime. They are well known and they represent not only a concern about this industry as an important export sector but also a blemish on our reputation, doing damage to the attractiveness of Australia as a place for people to gain knowledge and skills and hopefully to stay on and contribute to the economy.

The bill is consistent with the government's cost recovery policy, which has been under way for a number of years. In my view, the government rightly believes that seeking cost recovery from the providers for the cost of administering this scheme is an appropriate way to go, and this revised way of calculating the fees of providers is a fairer approach to sharing the costs of administering the scheme. But unashamedly it will also generate some extra resources. As I mentioned at the beginning, those extra resources are designed to make sure that the regulatory tools available in the ESOS legislation are able to be used, and that requires some extra resources.

It is not just about regulating international students in Australia; it is also about ensuring that Australian providers operating offshore are not damaging our reputation and are as rigorous and quality focused as the providers in Australia. But that costs money, and the extra $5 million over four years that we anticipate will be raised by these changes will enable a better effort at the quality assurance of providers delivering courses offshore. We have seen some debate in the media about what happens when that does not go right: it brings into question the whole education system and the $5 billion sector that it represents.

The changes will also put some more information in the hands of the providers to make sure that they know what is expected of them and how to satisfy the requirements that were discussed earlier about quality of courses, actual delivery, financial protection, protecting the reputation and integrity of our education and training export industry, and strengthening public confidence. It is easy to rattle off those things, but if you are an individual provider you will find in this package an outreach focus where the funding will ensure that departmental officials are better able to support the providers of educational services so that they know what is expected of them and can meet those obligations.

At the end of the day, it is not about finding the guilty and wiping them out, because we might not do that in the first instance—and our reputation is damaged until we catch up with the shonky providers. It is about making sure that, from day one, anybody who hangs their shingle out and says that they are an Australian education and training institution is doing the right thing. So there will be no damage to our reputation, because those people will be doing what is expected of them, and the students will have available to them not only knowledge of this protection and quality assurance regime but also information about what they can look for from the providers. This will ensure that the industry is meeting the consumers' needs and that the consumers—the students—are getting what they paid for. That outreach service, reaching out to offshore provision locations, needs to be resourced, and that is part of where the extra money is going. It is also looking at the information that is available to ensure that compliance activities are focused and are making a difference.

This bill does not actually change the tools; it puts lead in the pencil of the tools. I think that is timely, because the broader issue of whether the tools are doing the job is something that is going to be discussed during the review of the ESOS Act in general, which is due to commence in December 2003. It would be a shame to have a review and an evaluation of a legislative framework that had not been properly exercised. How pointless would that be? People would be saying, `Well, the tools are there but you just have not used them,' or, `Here are some cases where there was an opportunity to bring about a better outcome for the industry and it was not taken up because the resources were not there.' I would hate to see that happen.

Some may criticise this change as being premature, given that the review is due to start in a handful of months. I would argue that it is timely, because you want to make sure that the tools that you are reviewing have been exercised properly. In that respect this is a sensible move in my view. It is a sensible move because it should bring about the recognition that the export education industry is something that our whole nation needs to have a stake in. It is not something that is owned by only the education providers; it is owned by the Australian economy and by citizens looking to make sure our global reputation for quality and innovation in education and training is maintained. That delivers benefits for domestic communities that may not be directly involved. I will refer to my electorate of sunny Dunkley, by the bay on the Mornington Peninsula.

talk.start.para: —A beautiful place.

—It is a sensational place. The Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, who has just joined us, held a fantastic citizenship forum at which one of the topics that came up was a reflection on Frankston High School—an outstanding secondary education institution that actually has its own zone. So popular is this place that students from outside the zone want to go to school there—including international students. It is an example of how quality education institutions are valued and how people want to play a part in them.

speech.para: It is fortuitous that the minister for citizenship is here, because I think we need to be consistent. When Australia walks out on the international stage and says, `We have quality, we have innovation, we have outstanding educational and training opportunities in Australia,' they do not differentiate between the government departments. They do not say, `That is a very positive message coming from Minister Nelson; if only the immigration system would reflect that view.' Study in Australia, a package that is made available around the world, does not push any specific provider; it pushes the Australian brand. It says to people, `When you are contemplating studying in Canada, the United States, the UK or anywhere else in what is a highly competitive marketplace, come to somewhere which is open, interactive and imaginative.' That is the way that students who have had the international education experience in Australia report on that experience.

This is a very positive story. It says: explore the possibilities. I say: taste the delicious range of opportunities in Australia and invite international students to pick Australia first. To do that we need to make sure that, wherever the Commonwealth brand appears, there is a consistent message and that the education department, which is doing a fantastic job, is not needlessly being harangued by unhelpful, inconsistent, out-of-step immigration practices. Thankfully, that area is also being looked at.

In my area we have Monash University. I hope the new vice-chancellor takes some interest in the Peninsula campus of Monash University. Some years ago Monash University and the TAFE college in my electorate—Chisholm TAFE—did some research and discovered that parents, particularly from Asian countries, would rather their sons and daughters did not have their educational experience smack bang in the heart of some of our larger capital cities. That is good news for us, Mr Deputy Speaker. We say: `Come out to our regions. Come out to the outer suburbs of—

talk.start.para: (Mr Mossfield)—Blacktown.

—Are you in Blacktown? I thought you were in the Newcastle patch. My mistake—sorry about that. We are trying to drag students away from your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, and bring them down to the wholesome fresh air of the Mornington Peninsula—a classic example. I am not sure what happens in Blacktown, but there was a perception that in the inner city area of major capitals there may be too many distractions available and too many delicious opportunities of a non-academic nature that could distract international students from the task at hand. That is what the research showed. What it said to me and what I hope it said to the education providers in my electorate is that we have an outstanding product that needs to be displayed and talked about. We are in the metropolis of Melbourne, we are 45 kilometres out of the CBD and we have outstanding lifestyle, housing and quality of life opportunities that sit hand in hand with quality education. That is what the story is—that is what the branding is.

speech.para: My only frustration is that I hope that the vice-chancellor and the council of Monash University see that, because I am not sure that they have seen it so far. I will continue to push the attractiveness of the Peninsula campus, which is also within a golf course shot or two of the world-renowned Mt Eliza school of management. It is also where the business faculty of Monash has a significant presence. Why Monash seems so Clayton centric and cannot recognise an outstanding resource within its own bundle of locations and recognise how well it is placed to pursue export education opportunities has got me beat. I do not understand it. It might be one of those things that are so deliciously obvious that it just does not see it.

My message to Monash University is that it should look at going forward. As the new vice-chancellor settles his feet under the table, Monash University should pause for a minute and recognise that within its assets the Peninsula campus is an outstanding overseas education resource which is greatly underutilised and is not viewed in the context of the broader community. The campus is one where you can come and meet a low-maintenance local member and talk about what the beach is like, and you can have all the facilities at your doorstep without the worry of the things that happen in the centre of major capital cities and that concern parents.

On the same subject, though, we also are faced with a discussion about visa conditions. Again my message is that we need continuity and congruence in our overseas student message. There seems little point in our recognising opportunities, embracing a $5 billion business and then needlessly driving prospective students insane by mindless visa conditions. I have had some examples in my electorate where student visas have been used as a doorway to other immigration outcomes. I understand that, but let us not snuff the life out of the process just to tackle a small part of the problem. I hope that the minister finds what I have to say persuasive enough for him to think, `Gee, that's not a bad point.'

One of the debates that are going on now relates to English language tools. I can understand that at a tertiary institution, under the framework of the ESOS legislation, there is an expectation of literacy competency and an ability to take in the academic tuition that is being offered. That is a perfectly reasonable expectation. With tertiary students, you need to go through some of those English language tools to make sure that people are gaining the education for which they have paid and that the qualifications they are seeking are being earned legitimately. But to apply a similar tool at the secondary school level is, frankly, absolutely mindless. The tool that is used at a tertiary institution tests your language skills by posing current affairs questions, and the answers need to recognise not only your understanding of the language but also your comprehension of the topic being discussed. The thoughts of a secondary school student on some current affairs issues are difficult to work through. The students might not be aware of the issues. Their language skills might be quite satisfactory but they might not be able to answer in the way the tertiary tool requires. Moreover, for some of those students—and I will pick as an example in my community the Peninsula School, which has a fantastic English language centre with many Chinese students—the whole purpose of their coming to Australia is to learn English. Where is the sense in having an English language competency tool and testing people's English competency when they are coming to Australia to learn English? Where is the sense in that?

We need to have a bit of a pause and, if there is some concern from vice-chancellors and if there is some concern in immigration quarters that student visas are being used inappropriately, let us tackle the problem. Let secondary students participate in our overseas education programs at great institutions like Toorak College, Frankston High School and the Peninsula School in my electorate. Toorak College and the Peninsula School are supported by Export Market Development Grant Scheme funding by another area of the Commonwealth. That funding is saying, `You are doing great things; here is some encouragement.' They are supported by the minister with these sorts of measures and a studying in Australia package, only to find that they are getting smacked around at visa level. Where is the sense in that?

We should be saying to the secondary student marketplace: work with us—collaborate with the Commonwealth—to track students, to ensure the bona fides of applicants and to ensure that the measures that ESOS seeks to provide are put in place, but, if English language is a test for tertiary education, test people at the point they leave secondary school and seek to move into tertiary education. How difficult could that be? Secondary school is focused on developing language skills, so test people at the time they finish secondary schooling and before they go on to tertiary education. Apply a similar English language competency test to the one that would be applied for someone who was simply entering Australia to commence at a tertiary level. That would make sure that the secondary providers are doing what they have been paid to do and are actually developing those competencies. We do not want, in our English language training, some problems that we have seen with our own students, which the government has thankfully tackled. Before we were elected, you could see students passing right the way through their schooling and not actually having literacy skills at the end of it. We do not want to see that happen. We should not see that perpetuated through the overseas students program.

My last point is that I encourage everybody to take this sector as seriously as the government does and ensure that our actions, our expressions, our gestures, our campaigns and our legislative framework are complementary—so that they come across under the Australia brand, so that we are all singing from the same page of the same hymnbook and so that we can put a very positive story out there, because there are other places where students can go. This is an export market and the competition is fierce. We have so much going for us. We have a greater opportunity into the future, with fantastic locations like the Frankston-Mornington Peninsula area. That is a perfect place for an expansion in international student intake, where people can enjoy the lifestyle and avoid the perceived sins of inner capital city living, which I am not well versed in because I live down on the peninsula. I am not quite sure what is being talked about there, but there are concerns in the minds of parents. Let us get behind this legislation, but my message is that, in a whole-of-government way, we should get behind international education and make sure we are making the very best of the great advantages we have in this country.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Dr Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, I would like to sum up the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003 and thank all of those who have contributed to the debate for the variety of support they have given. The member for Blaxland and the member for Grayndler both talked a lot about the integrity side of the industry, the reputation, and we welcome those comments. The member for Cook talked about, amongst other things, the multicultural society that we have in Australia, which is a place of great welcome, therefore, to those who travel from other countries to come and study in this country.

speech.para: We heard from the member for Dunkley, whose passion knows no bounds on matters of nurturing younger people and growing them into successful citizens. A number of the points the member for Dunkley made—and I heard all of his comments—are worth talking about. I should emphasise the sense of ownership that, from my department's point of view, we want to give—through the whole-of-government approach to international students visiting Australia—to education institutions for the people that they say are coming to study. Sadly, in recent times there has been a Queensland government institution that has been proved to have cooked the books. Certainly the strong allegation is that they have used the system to inflate the numbers of those who were actually studying—for whatever purpose.

Sadly, there are too many examples from time to time of people who come to this country supposedly on student visas who have not been correctly checked and vouched for by the institution that has been contracted to provide them with education and who then go on to make other claims. Understandably, because of the integrity of our immigration system—which very clearly underscores, if you like, the total integrity of each person who has passed through it—we want to make sure that those who come here are people who are suitable from a character and health point of view and are reliable in the sense that they are going to live up to their visa conditions. So I understand what the member for Dunkley was saying.

It is worth noting that last year 22,597 people from the People's Republic of China were granted student visas, which was a seven per cent growth—it was the No. 1 country. The growth out of Japan was 12 per cent, with 12,500 people, and the United States of America was third, with about 11,200 people, which is a 17 per cent growth. Also 11,200 people from Korea were granted student visas, as were 10,800 people from Hong Kong, 7,600 people from Malaysia, Thailand and India, and 5,500 from Taiwan. You realise that many people from our own Asia-Pacific region want to study here—and why not?—because of the quality of education. Boy, have we come a long way as a country, when you consider the $5 billion industry today. Forty or more years ago it was an education sector based on a charitable notion, such as the Colombo Plan, which sponsored a lot of people in the region to study here and try to defeat the disadvantage that many felt in their own countries.

One person whom I would like to mention in connection with this debate is Uncle Daniel David, whom I met just the other week, from the Tamil community in Brisbane. He came to Queensland and studied at the University of Queensland in the late 1950s. He formed the international student association there, which provided a sense of support for students which was completely missing. I welcome the fact that he was awarded by the Prime Minister a Centenary Medal for his contribution to Australian society. When I met with the Tamil association at Sunnybank State High School in my electorate a few weeks ago, I was absolutely impressed by the real love and affection and the way in which this man has helped to grow Australia's reputation as a good place to study.

There are some ancillary issues and I will deal with a lot of the other comments, I hope, through dealing with these ancillary issues. It is important that places of learning provide other support infrastructure for students. With my ministerial hat on, I have met a lot of people from other countries who find that universities are happy to take the fees but do not necessarily provide some of the societal support. I am distressed to know that University of Queensland students with Chinese backgrounds have been subjected to violent crimes against them, including sexually related crimes, and those students have not been provided with enough support in and around the campus. The University of Queensland may be distressed that I make that point known, but it has been reported to me and I think it is something that underscores the fact that these students come from other countries and rightly expect a variety of support. In the sense of the sectors, they need to understand these things.

It is also important, as the member for Dunkley suggested, that there is consistent information. I was distressed to know of the out-of-date nature of some of the information being used by universities as they head off overseas on their own missions to attract students. They use old information and do not understand the sorts of pathways that now exist which allow people to seek a permanent migration outcome once they have completed their studies in Australia. That is a matter I will return to further.

There are great successes. The other week I was in the electorate of Capricornia. The University of Central Queensland has campuses in Sydney and Melbourne, as well as Rockhampton, and it has certainly shown that we not only have a foothold in Asia because of our location but we also have a great deal of people coming to study here because of the value for money we provide. Regional places like Rockhampton have benefited greatly from international students. Apart from the fact that they are coming here, paying fees and studying, we also allow them to work for 20 hours a week under the visa conditions—the member for Dunkley might like to note that—and they provide a lot to the local economy in a lot of different ways: holiday breaks and fruit picking jobs. When they have qualified to stay in Australia, these students have settled, for example, in Gladstone, in the member for Hinkler's electorate.

Students who I met the other day at UCQ came from Germany, Uganda and Mexico, and a high proportion of people came from Asian backgrounds. There is a good mix of students. They are absolutely and fundamentally amazed by one key thing about Australia. Students from Korea who are studying at Rockhampton Grammar told me about this, too. It is not the fact that we have kangaroos, wombats and all the other interesting marsupials but the fact that we have every face of the world in our local streets and neighbourhoods. They find a real sense of comfort in coming and studying here in Australia.

The University of Central Queensland won an International Development Program export award in 2002. That is the university export arm of education. That university has the highest proportion of overseas student programs of any university in the country—certainly that is its belief. It is in the Good Universities Guide and has five stars in cultural diversity and graduate outcomes. I congratulate that university as I do Griffith University, whose major campus is in the middle of my electorate. Like the member for Griffith, I am a member of the Griffith Asia Pacific Research Institute board. From meeting people from Malaysia, Indonesia and academics from universities in those countries I understand how strong the links between Griffith University and our broad region are. I also understand the real benefits that flow from that. Back in the days when Daniel David came to Australia, there were only about 6,000 people studying as overseas students in Australia. Individual campuses now count their overseas student populations in those numbers and more—and Griffith University is no different.

As the Minister for Education, Science and Training often remarks, not everybody seeks a university education. The way our TAFE system is now geared to attracting overseas students to study means that this particular area of export activity is a very complex, and becoming an even more complex, set of possibilities. The broad range of possibilities is impressive. At Archerfield Airport in my electorate, the world's oldest aero club, the Royal Queensland Aero Club, of which Bert Hinkler and Kingsford Smith were once members, is training pilots from Taiwan. These people are flight engineers who want to be pilots. As there is no general aviation sector in Taiwan, they are coming to Australia and to our blue skies and green fields to study here. Here again overseas students are bringing money to Australia through the contracts they have with their providers. All in all, it shows that there is an enormous diversity in the range of activities we now undertake.

The members for Dunkley, for Blaxland and for Grayndler talked about the sense of integrity within the system we now operate. It is absolutely fundamental. My department works very strongly with my colleague Minister Ruddock to ensure that everyone who comes here is here to study legitimately and participates lawfully in Australian society.

The Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000—the ESOS Act—was established to provide a more effective industry regulatory framework for the education and training export industry. As we have said, it is of enormous value to Australia. It protects and enhances the industry's integrity and quality. It will assist in reducing the abuse of the student visa program that can take place from time to time. The national code of practice for registration authorities and providers of education and training to overseas students was established under this act. The purpose of the national code is to provide nationally consistent standards for the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students—the CRICOS registered providers. Under the ESOS Act only education providers registered on CRICOS are permitted to offer education and training services to overseas students. Also established under the ESOS Act is the provider registration and international student management system—PRISMS—which is owned and operated by the Department of Education, Science and Training. It is the electronic system which allows registered users to generate electronic confirmations of enrolments for overseas students, and it is the method by which education providers report prescribed variations to students' enrolments.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and DEST work in partnership with industry to ensure the continued growth of the overseas education industry in Australia while also maintaining the integrity of the overseas student program. This includes working to identify new markets for Australian education. Industry is also represented at regular meetings with my department and with Dr Nelson's department by the Affiliation of International Education Peak Bodies. The AIEPB consists of peak bodies representing the various education sectors.

As has been made very clear in this debate, this sector provides some $5 billion to our economy each year. I would submit that we are really only scraping the edges of the possibilities ahead. When I consider the 5,500 students from Taiwan, and having been to Taiwan—as many in this place have; and in fact I have more Taiwanese in my electorate than anybody else in this place has in their electorate—I know from talking to people from Taiwan that the possibility of defeating the traditional journey of Taiwanese students to the Ivy League schools in America represents an enormous set of export possibilities for us. The Taiwanese travel to Australia on electronic visas. The ease of access between Taiwan and Australia is enormously obvious to everyone; there are thousands of people a week going in each direction. So I think there is a need for education providers to look at the Taiwanese market as one with enormous potential.

We have a well-deserved global reputation for our high quality, our innovation and the valuable contribution we make to our society. The government are absolutely committed to protecting and expanding this valuable industry. We want to assist in its sustainable development through clear and strong policies. Our continuing commitment has been demonstrated through Dr Nelson's budget initiative this year for international education and training. We will see this innovation continue with offshore campuses, and I welcome that. The work being done by Michelle Lee and others at the Brisbane campus of the University of Canberra is proof positive of the way in which innovation offshore and Australia's growing reputation will add to our export earnings.

The new fee structure introduced by the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 2003 replaces the current inequitable tiered structure of the compulsory annual registration charge which is payable by all registered providers. The new structure is fairer and will mean that no provider will pay any more than any other provider for each international student. In future, many providers will pay less than under the current tiered structure. Obviously, providers with large numbers of international students and large revenue streams will have a larger total annual fee—because they will have more students. It is very simple. It is only fair that these providers who stand to gain the most from Australia's reputation as a quality study destination contribute equally to maintaining that reputation.

Importantly, this bill does not impose any further regulatory burden on providers. The government has committed an additional $5.1 million over four years, on an ongoing basis, to increase the capacity of Dr Nelson's department to assist providers in understanding and meeting the legislative obligations. It will also see action taken in a more proactive manner to remove providers who breach the ESOS Act requirements. As all contributors to this debate have pointed out, if there are bad guys we need to weed them out. We do not need people damaging the reputation of the good providers. The protection and, indeed, the enhancement of Australia's quality reputation is crucial for providers and for their international students, who rely on the strength of an Australian qualification as they further their careers both here and overseas. The government continues its support through this bill for a strengthened regulatory framework to ensure that Australia's education and training export industry will grow, that its integrity will grow and that its long-term viability will also grow.

We will see a continuing rise in the number of overseas students; we have no doubt about that. Globally, student visa grants continue to rise. The number of student visas granted last year was up by over seven per cent compared to the previous program year. In your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, in the areas around Blacktown you would see examples of many people from so many places. It is interesting to note that Bangladesh has shown an increase of 42 per cent in grants last year compared to the previous year; India is showing an increase of 39 per cent, and that might be good for local cricket teams as these students get involved; Germany is up by 25 per cent; the UK is up by 20 per cent; Poland, a solid contributor to Australia's migration program, is up by 37 per cent; and Taiwan, mentioned often in my contribution today, has shown a 10 per cent growth.

Interestingly, and also perhaps underscoring our great reputation as a multicultural country, the non-award sector—those who perhaps come on exchange programs or to study some units in Australia which count towards their own diplomas, many of them American—has shown the most growth, with visa grants up by nearly 128 per cent, and grants for the masters and doctorate sector have increased by nearly 19 per cent. These are people who, like those students from Germany I met at the University of Central Queensland, already have a degree.

talk.start.para: —It was in Rockhampton. The member for Hinkler is of course here now. Many do study in Gladstone. They sing the praises of the member for Hinkler after their short stay in Australia. They know he is a good member. The number of those who have come to seek an additional degree—masters and doctorates—to add to the degree they have already earned in their home country has increased by nearly 19 per cent.

speech.para: This feeds very well into the skilled migration pathway that Minister Ruddock, Minister Nelson and I worked very strongly on. It means that overseas students who have undertaken studies in Australia may be eligible for a skilled migration outcome. It means that applicants under the onshore general skilled migration program are exempt from the recent work experience requirement if, within six months of applying, they have completed at least two years of Australian study in Australia. This provides them with a quick fit into our country. They come with enough knowledge and enough skills, and they gain additional knowledge and skills and Australian experience to provide a very good additional boost to Australia. As a result of a real whole-of-government commitment to international students coming to Australia, which is outlined in this bill and outlined in other initiatives, we are finding that we are getting the best of both worlds: we are getting money from full fee paying overseas students and, as well, we are getting people who make a quick contribution to the Australia economy. The student from Mexico I met that day in Rockhampton made a point to me that the advantage of an Australian degree, and the possibility of residency in Australia, was too great an attraction to ignore.

I also welcome the commitment from Dr Nelson for initiatives in the budget worth $113 million to support the industry offshore. I think that the growth of the industry offshore is an absolutely fantastic investment. It will see increased promotion and government support, from the government-to-government point of view, in overseas countries to better develop our export opportunities and develop new ones. All round, this government is very serious about providing encouragement to the providers, providing a sense of integrity to all those who participate as students and, from the Australian society point of view, ensuring that all who come to study here make a great contribution while they are here. The possibilities of them making a further contribution through other potential migration pathways show, I think, that we are very serious about developing this sector, and the possibilities for growth are endless. In regards to all of that, I thank again all of the members who contributed to this debate and commend this bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Mr McGauran:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2003 contains various minor technical amendments to the communications legislation—the Broadcasting Services Act, the Radiocommunications Act and the Telecommunications Act. The opposition supports the bill. All the amendments are sensible amendments that improve the operation of the various pieces of legislation that I referred to. The only comment I wish to make is that one of the driving rationales behind the amendments that are being made to these various pieces of legislation is the effective collapse of the datacasting option that the government put forward as part of its regime to transfer Australia to digital television. It is yet another testament to the failure of the government's digital TV program.

speech.para: Since 1998 when the digital regime was first legislated, we have only managed to see digital television being adopted by one to 1½ per cent of Australian households. The datacasting strategy involved two licences being made available by auction to prospective datacasters—a unique category in the world deliberately created to minimise competition being imposed upon the existing terrestrial broadcasters. That auction collapsed so there has been no datacasting and no use of that spectrum. Of course, the government has been obliged to put back the time lines for the introduction of the high-definition TV requirements and indeed to water down those requirements to make them less onerous for the broadcasters.

In overall terms, the government's strategy to bring about a transition from analog to digital television in Australia is in a complete shambles and there is no sign yet that the government has a new strategy for dealing with the mess that it has created. In particular, the government has flirted with the idea of allowing multichanneling. Under the 1998 legislation, the commercial broadcasters are prohibited from using the spectrum that they have obtained for the purpose of digital broadcasting to broadcast more than one signal, even though that spectrum allows them to broadcast three—and possibly even four—separate signals, separate channels. The government has failed to grapple with this issue. The minister appears to have given undertakings to some people in the industry that he would allow multichanneling. Indeed, he has taken to cabinet submissions suggesting that multichanneling be permitted but he has been rolled in cabinet on more than one occasion, I suspect. As a result, Australia is still left with the framework that was put in place in 1998, albeit marginally amended with respect to high-definition TV, and our transition to digital broadcasting is languishing completely.

The import of the legislation before the chamber today is essentially to clean up one or two minor consequential issues associated with that, and one or two other things. For example, there were certain arrangements put in place to protect the datacasters from unfair competition on the part of regional broadcasters. These restrictions on the regional broadcasters are clearly no longer relevant because there are no datacasters to be protected. The opposition have no objection to the legislation but we call on the government to revisit the entire issue of digital broadcasting. We need to go back to square one on this issue. Clearly, the strategy that was adopted in 1998 has taken us nowhere and there is a need for a complete rethink of the approach to generating a transition from analog to digital in Australia.

It is important that we ensure that there is a transition to digital and the digital age. The opportunities that are going to eventually be opened up, not only for consumers but also creative content industries, as a result of the transition to digital will be enormous. Australia has failed to grasp those opportunities, yet we are a nation that has tremendous potential in this sector. Australia has always had a great profile in the creative industry sector. It has always done well in exporting music and educational products and a variety of entertainment products. We are significant players now in the world film industry and, as the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Information Technology and the Arts is discovering in the inquiry chaired by the member for Sturt—and I see that the member for Blaxland, who is also on that committee, is present today—we have great potential in other electronic and digital industries as well. So there is a great need for Australia to unleash the power of digital to both empower consumers—to give more choice to consumers and to have more competition—and to enliven those sectors that are involved in creative content and have enormous export potential.

The time is nigh for the government to rethink its approach to digital and to develop an alternative strategy that will mean more competition, better choice for consumers, more pressures on producers—to actually innovate, to take risks and to produce new products—and fewer restrictions on how the market can operate. These issues are difficult for all sides in the debate. One of the questions that we all have to confront is the importance of not unduly disturbing existing arrangements and, in particular, not unnecessarily prejudicing existing investments. People who make investments, particularly of the scale that tends to be the case in the broadcasting industry, are entitled, when those investments are made, to some regulatory certainty and some expectation of knowing what the playing field will be into the future. That is a very important consideration. We can no longer stand around and allow the failing digital broadcasting regime to continue in this country. If we want to have a good future both for broadcasting viewers and listeners and for people who are involved in the creation of content and in the creation of new opportunities and export products then it is vital that we get the transition to digital right.

It is a difficult issue. It is an issue that many countries around the world are grappling with and not many are having great success at this stage. It is an issue that has to be dealt with; it has to be fixed. We have to ensure that our nation will be at the forefront of the information economy, will be at the forefront of creative content industries around the world and will be a great place not only for viewers and listeners to consume that content but also for those particularly involved in creating content to have opportunities to develop skills, earn money and develop good careers that will allow them to provide content to people all around a digitally connected world. The opposition support the legislation, and we hope that the government will, with some urgency, rethink its approach to the digital television issue. It cannot be allowed to languish for much longer. There is a clear need to rethink and revisit the framework that was put in place in 1998 and to develop a new strategy that will give us these opportunities that we as a nation so desperately need.

talk.start.para: —Bless their little hearts! The government try so hard in this area of communications. The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts really works as hard as he can, but what he has provided here today is mutton dressed up as lamb.
—It takes one to know one!

—We have an interjection from the chair of the communications committee. The chair and I have just been cooperatively working with the Games Association of Australia and the gaming industry and looking at ways in which we can expand the scale of a nascent industry association so that we can end up with a games industry in Australia as significant as our film industry. The committee has been extremely good, and I have just popped in here after hearing evidence in that committee.
—Thank you very much.

—That is all right, Mr Chair. As the chair would know, when we are dealing with the question of digital television, you say, `What have we got here?' On the face of it, the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2003 is just a series of minor changes made because things have moved on a bit, we need a little more flexibility, a few things were overlooked previously and there are minor problems within regional areas. One of the key factors here is what you do with solus television markets. Before this bill I did not know what a solus television market was, but I am reliably informed by the explanatory memorandum and the Bills Digest that country areas which have just one or two commercial operators are regarded as solus areas. They do not have the diversity that we have in the rest of Australia. Specific provisions in the preceding bills allow, where you have one operator, for them to run a second analog service. With the move to digital TV services, in running that second analog service, they are allowed to transmit that into two digital services. But there is a question of timing in how that is to be the case.

speech.para: If I am correct, all of them, except for the solus provider in the Griffith area, have come within the compass of the new arrangements where they were given a different way of going about things. In relation to the provider at Griffith, they were quick off the mark. Because they were quick off the mark—they got in prior to 2001 to make their arrangements—they have not been allowed the flexibility that has been provided to other solus providers in regional Australia. So a proper, necessary and sensible correction to that in this bill will allow this one commercial operator to be brought up to speed and to be allowed access to the same kind of flexibility that others have in regional Australia.

In looking at these providers, you have to look at the way the regime was originally put into place. In fact, the word `regime' would be going a bit too far when looking at something as organised, as credible and as entrenched as the word `regime' presents, because this has been a hodgepodge of adhoceries within a larger design that failed to understand the central core impetus within the area of change to digital TV.

That runs alongside the desire of the major players in the cities to make the big jump to high-definition television, or HDTV, paid for in large part by the Commonwealth. The free-to-air providers want to step up to high-definition television but they want that step up to be tax deductible and to have a range of measures available, because of the costs to them. High-definition television was demanded by good Mr Packer and PBL, and by Mr Murdoch as an outrider—both people have an enormous vested interest in this area. The decision to go to HDTV, as laudable as that may seem for those who want the crispest possible vision, has enormous costs. In regional areas with single or dual operators and only one commercial provider, they now have SBS and the ABC. A lot of places did not have that. There are now new satellite services. Yesterday I was briefed by Austar and other members of the subscription pay TV service. A new satellite has gone up which has a footprint covering all of Australia. That solves two key problems. Areas to which it was not possible to deliver the ABC and SBS before can now be covered. The fundamental problems of ghosting and lack of television reception even in areas close to the major cities can be solved because of this new footprint.

The fundamental design in regional Australia is not based on HDTV. That may not be filled for a very long period of time because the market has not yet attached itself to it. Regional Australia has standard definition television. It is a matter of providing them with what they do not have at the moment. They have an analog service. They used to have an analog phone service until the former Labor government said, `The best evidence placed before us by the industry and the experts is that we need to close down the analog system and move to a digital system. That is the way of the future.' That took a lot longer than was expected, probably because the efficiency of the analog system was underrated. There was also the issue of how long it would take to get a new system. We finally had the roll-out of CDMA, but there were significant problems because it needed much more investment and entrenching than was previously thought.

That long period of time is going to be mirrored, but far more dramatically, when we come to the question of how we change over to digital. If it was not instructive enough, it should have been. This particular minister for communications and those in cahoots with him flailed us whilst we were in government on the issue of removing the analog telephone service and putting in a digital service Australia wide.
