The flailing can come back the other way now because of the way this whole package has been put together and progressed. This is not a spring lamb; this is mutton dressed up as lamb. It has all of the characteristics of a policy that is not new, fresh and alive. It is not open to the problems that could have been foreseen and the demands of people not only in regional Australia but elsewhere. They are not just going to buy a product because they are told to do it. There is strong resistance.

In the second reading speech, Minister McGauran, speaking on behalf of the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, made the point that there has been resistance but, through the series of mechanisms proposed here, we will wander along the path towards the change to digital television. As we wander towards 2008 and expect to turn off the analog systems Australia wide, I can only agree with Paul Budde, one of Australia's pre-eminent broadcasting experts and someone who lives in regional Australia. We saw him at a committee hearing in the Newcastle area. This is really drawing a long bow. If you expect to turn off the analog service in country Australia—and in the country at large—by 2008, you have to be kidding yourself.

This government are still operating on the basis of their forward projections. They have already made changes. Late last year we had a series of changes to accommodate the fact that what was prospective did not turn out. Paul Budde argues that we should be looking at another decade on—2018 or so rather than 2008—when the market will be ready to make the fundamental change.

What we have seen already—the minister refers to this—is that the take-up of DVD has been so strong that the expectation is that it will provide the floor for the launch of HDTV. The take-up of DVD has been remarkable but it has been driven by the fact that the cost of a DVD is so great and its usefulness and its clarity at a particular level are so great that people have just gone in droves to adopt the new technology. We have seen it across a range of technologies before but there has been a fundamental within the core of people taking up this technology. If the price is right, people will go for it if the quality and the capacity are there.

Now that Chinese manufacturers have entered the market, you can buy a DVD that is fully spec'ed at $150, whereas just six or eight months previously—it is probably a bit longer—you were looking at a Japanese machine for $500 with less ability; it could not incorporate MP3 or MP4, certainly, because that is a new standard, but it is coming to us. New compression standards that are not yet incorporated will be coming and will allow digital television to operate more effectively. Better compression technologies will allow online digitised services to operate more effectively because you can pump more down the existing tubes.

What is not appreciated is this: people have made the jump to DVD and its greater sense of immersiveness, I suppose, because of its clarity—it looks more real, even when you are watching things that are not real. Part of that jump has been due to the fact that they have gone down to the corner video store and hired cassette tapes. The cassette tapes that have been available have been appallingly bad because they have been used so many times, they have been stretched, they have lost vision, they have not been of good quality and they have involved a very high replacement cost. People in video stores are very happy, thank you very much, to have DVD because, except for problems with scratching and so on, they can provide a product that is of exceptionally high quality and that people have taken to greatly.

I doubt that there are very many consumers in Australia who understand that the move from the picture quality of DVD to the picture quality of high definition television is enormous. The reason there is a current entry cost for high definition integrated televisions is that the picture quality is just so much better. That has not been explained by this government or by most commentators. It is hard to believe that you can have a much larger image with much greater quality embedded within it but it is one of the reasons that people have not made the jump to pay the extra cost.

The other thing, if you look at the point and purpose of going to the digitisation of material and going to digital television, is what we have argued from the outset: instead of agreeing to help foot the bill for the Packer and Murdoch organisations to make their transition to high definition television, it would have been better to mandate standard definition television, as has been mandated in other countries, and to stick with the world standards in this regard. If you talk to any of the people running the changeover to digital TV or you talk to those people who are the providers of content to those television stations, you will find that there are a whole series of embedded new standards in what is supposed to be the one high definition television standard, which provides a series of problems for content providers here, because we do not have one straight, strict standard, based largely, as was the genius in the period of the Menzies government, on determining that we would go with the European power system—the best. It has been said by the secretary of the communications committee—he has heard of it but is not sure of it—that former Prime Minister Menzies actually talked to the then Telecom technicians and asked the people in the research labs how we should go about it and what was best, because he did not have that facility.

The decision making process at the basis of the original bills was flawed. We see before us today that these attempts to get greater flexibility are simple catch-ups. They are trying to provide stopgaps so that the problems that are there can be patched over. As I said in another context recently, it is a bit like AstroBoy. When AstroBoy got into a punch-up, he would immediately emerge with a whole stack of sticky tape all over his face to indicate that he had had a bit of a fight. This was the bandaid approach that AstroBoy had. It is the same thing as the government trying to patch up what they have put together.

The fundamental flaws go to this: if you want to use the capacity of digital TV to really expand choice within Australia, there are two ways in which you are best able to do that. The first is to now put the emphasis on standard definition television and the ability to break the seven megahertz spectrum into much smaller slices and deliver a series of channels to people so that they can have greater choice, whereas now they only have a small number of choices of what they can look at. The choice is greater, of course, for subscription TV but, in the free-to-air digital area, if you had a greater series of choices of content delivered digitally—it is standard definition television—it would be quite possible, as the Bills Digest and Brendan Bailey point out. At the end of the Bills Digest, he quotes a lady who argues that, if you did that, one of the things you might achieve is what has been achieved overseas. The diversity of content and the wide range of channels that have been available overseas have been behind the much better take-up of digital TV than what we have comparatively in Australia.

We know that we suffer in terms of take-up of not just digital TV but also broadband. I would hazard a guess that, rather than what is involved effectively in these amendments to the original bills, the thing that may drive a move towards HDTV will have nothing at all to do with what the government have proposed already or will propose in the future. What will probably drive it is what is happening out in the market in terms of people accessing new technologies, as they have accessed DVDs.

The other thing that really is becoming cost effective is digital projectors. You can get the latest for around $3,000. Digital projectors which can project an HDTV image of a very large size—wall size—are available. You can have it smaller but, certainly, with a large size allied with the quality of sound that is now available, an in-home cinema experience is possible without having to go to the $10,000 plasma TV that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts had been given, because of the largesse of Telstra, for such a long period of time to assess what HDTV was about. With digital projectors, they do not have to pay the initial costs of that and they do not, after about five years, have to pay $1,000 to $2,000 to re-gas a plasma television screen. They do not have to pay the high cost of entry by buying the newest technology that will probably override plasma—that is, LCD—which has been increased in size and capacity from originally computer screens to screens equivalent to plasma. They will not have to do that.

In terms of entry, what used to cost $20,000 and then $15,000 has dropped to $10,000. For $3,000—and that will decrease—you can buy a room sized TV projection system linked into a very good sound system that can provide you with an immersive cinema experience, an immersive digital TV experience or an immersive Internet experience—an experience that could well bind the family together in the same way that the original television sets lobbing into Australia in 1956 supplied a new experience for everyone in this country. Entirely due to something totally outside the government's control—and that is probably why it will succeed—digital television may succeed in Australia. It will not succeed because of this series of changes to try to patch up a regime which was ill-designed in the first place.

The other fundamental failing we have—and it is not addressed here either, except tangentially—is the question of providing choice through getting the datacasting act together. We have seen datacasting knocked on the head because the minister does not want to play in that area. We have seen $6 million, I think, worth of commitment to ABC digital television such as Fly TV and ABC Kids discontinued because there is not enough support for digital TV programming from the government to our main broadcasting entity. I support the bill, but it is really mutton dressed up as lamb.

talker.name: Cameron, Ross, MP
Mr ROSS CAMERON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, who is of course in the other place, I am happy to sum up the debate on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 2003 and to make a few brief remarks. This is an area of government policy that is somewhat arcane. It is a field, some would say, for the specialist, and it involves a fairly high degree of technical complexity. So it is probably not a bad idea to begin by returning to the first principles and to note that the bill involves some relatively minor changes to the broadbrush regime established for the process by which Australia will move from analog to digital television.

speech.para: When we talk about the movement from analog to digital, I am reminded of a work by Nicholas Negroponte, which I recall is titled OnBeing Digital. He says that the movement from analog to digital involves a revolution which, over time, will have such consequences that history will look back upon it as being as great in magnitude as the agricultural revolution or the Industrial Revolution that followed it. The digital idea—that one can reduce data to a sequence of two bits of information and then repackage that information into a stream of bits—is an apparently simple idea but is one which, as Negroponte argues, is going to have very far-reaching consequences for Australia and the world.

Many Australians may ask themselves: what are the practical benefits to me or to our community of this move, to which governments and industry are dedicating very considerable resources? One of them is that digital information can be transmitted using much less of the spectrum than is required by the fairly bandwidth-hungry traditional analog technology. The spectrum available to us is a limited resource. There is a certain amount available for all of the possible needs, whether that be for transmitting a signal to open one's garage door, for transmitting a movie in high definition television or perhaps for scientific or educational purposes. As we move to digital technology more of the information that we communicate, it frees up more of the available spectrum—which is a national resource of the Australian people—and that is a fundamentally good thing. At the same time, it allows us to produce a much sharper, as my colleague Mr Hatton mentioned, and clearer picture, and of course there is a range of transmissions which particularly benefit from that level of high resolution.

Digital technology means that we can now engage the customer as a communicator in the broadcasting process, where it is possible for customers not only to receive picture and data but to respond with data of their own. This is part of the revolution. It is one of the things that are allowing us to contemplate, for example, online shopping. It will involve, for example, university students responding online to their lecturers and fellow students. The list of potential uses is enormous.

As the government approached the question of how we provide leadership without being too dictatorial in a very significant technological transition, we felt we should be guided by four key principles. Those principles are: the conversion from digital television should proceed with a minimum of disruption to viewers; the framework should encourage the introduction of a range of new services rather than simply strengthen the hold of incumbent services; it should involve a range of options for viewers in terms of equipment capability and price, including openness to market entry for lower cost products; and, finally, it should provide a measure of stability and certainty for the television industry, who are shouldering a very significant cost burden in terms of the introduction of new technology. It is very capital intensive. It is labour intensive, requiring highly specialised services. The commercial stations and the national broadcasters are undertaking very great investment under this framework. We feel as a government that if we are going to require the broadcasters to undertake that very great investment we ought to provide a framework that gives them some certainty for the years ahead.

The specific and more technical provisions of the bill involve minor changes to the legislation to facilitate the introduction of additional digital television services in markets that are currently underserved, particularly regional markets. We expect the capital cities to fare well. It is in the outlying areas where the capital costs are harder to justify in terms of market size that the bill provides some more specific encouragement. The bill corrects an anomaly which would otherwise have prevented a licensee with a second analog licence allocated before 1 January 2001—in this case in and around Griffith, which is described as a solus market, meaning it has only one commercial network provider—from multichannelling the digital transmission of the original and second service on a single seven-megahertz channel.

The bill amends the legislation so that the timetable for the introduction of a third digital service by commercial television broadcasting licensees in regional two-service markets, which are overlapped by a remote licence area, is not restricted to the same timetable that applies to the remote areas. To deconstruct that rather complex sentence, which for many people will have a tendency to cause their eyes to glaze over, in capital cities each of us is serviced by a minimum of three commercial free-to-air television networks and the two national broadcasters—the ABC and the SBS—but in many of the regional and rural communities of Australia there may be only one or two commercial network servicing the area. We wanted to encourage those single and dual providers to deliver digital services in those markets, so the framework provided a sweetener for those services in terms of their capacity to also run an additional analog service—one of the more traditional, low-cost services—to try and ensure that the capital cities did not get all the benefits of the new framework. This bill simply tweaks that arrangement to ensure that a couple of these minor anomalies—circumstances that were not anticipated at the time the framework was developed—will not penalise those regional and rural areas.

The amendments will enhance the ability of commercial broadcasters to quickly provide an additional digital service in these underserved markets. In relation to datacasting, the bill removes the prohibitions on the transmission of datacasting services by free-to-air broadcasters until the earlier of 12 months after commencement of simulcast in their area, or the first time a datacasting service was transmitted by an independent datacasting transmitter licensee. This is required following the government decision not to allocate any datacasting transmitter licences.

The bill also allows the minister to delegate the power to approve variations to the national broadcasters' implementation plans to the secretary or senior officers of the department. This simply reflects the fact that there will be not dozens but hundreds and probably thousands of conversations taking place between the national broadcasters and the ABA. It allows the minister to delegate some of those functions to ensure that there can be a free and speedy communication from both sides.

Finally the bill allows the establishment of a penalty in lieu of prosecution scheme in respect of certain offences under part 21 of the Telecommunications Act. The scheme will allow the ACA to issue infringement notices for alleged breaches of the offences under part 21 of the Telecommunications Act that are specified in proposed section 453A. This will allow the ACA to act more quickly in relation to possible breaches of those offences and therefore encourage compliance more effectively with consequent benefits to consumers.

The situation is, as the member for Blaxland rightly and factually pointed out, that the level of penetration of digital in the Australian market at the moment is very small. In fact, it represents about one per cent of the total television sets in the country. But we ought to remember that Australia has historically been at the absolute forefront of the world in speed of take-up of new technology. Just to put our situation into perspective, I referred in the chamber yesterday to the problems of the Solomon Islands. As an indicator I referred to the state of the Solomons economy and to its industrial technology and to the fact that the 500,000 people in the Solomons are serviced by 5,000 television sets. In other words, there is one television set for every 1,000 Solomon Islanders. In Australia, which has a population of just under 20 million, there are 20 million television sets. So we have penetration by the medium of television at an average of one television set for every Australian citizen.

Inevitably we will see this movement where the one per cent will grow and grow, and we accept that the principal impediment to that taking place at the moment is the cost of the digital television sets. A corollary to that is the availability of services from the commercial and national broadcasters which are being broadcast in the digital format. As the penetration of the market grows, no doubt the number of services being broadcast in digital will grow.

The key point is that the cost of sets is falling all the time. The availability of sets will grow and eventually they will become available to people on average, and we hope on less than average, incomes. As the benefits of the service become better known throughout the community in terms of the capacity for interaction and for customers and users of the service to participate in the broadcasting enterprise, I am confident that we will see a greater take-up rate.

In the process, as I say, the minister has established this framework, guided by four commonsense principles which reflect a proper concern for the interest of consumers, a willingness to recognise the investment being made by existing broadcasters, a porous and permeable market which allows the entry of new players and of new technologies and, in the end, a level of certainty that will provide the fewest disruptions and inconveniences to service delivery for the 20 million Australian consumers of television. That is the purpose of the bill. It is a good commonsense series of measures and I commend it to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 18 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Will the Government ensure that media, entertainment and arts industries are explicitly excluded from future free trade agreement negotiations including the General Agreement on Trade in Ser-vices (GATS)?

(2) Will the Government refuse any claim from negotiating nations that Australia's local content protections or constraints on media ownership constitute an unfair trade advantage in any future free trade agreement?
(3) What steps will the Government be taking to ensure that diversity in media content will be protected and further nourished in any future free trade agreement?

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows

answer.para: (1) Australia's general policy in this regard was set out by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, on 19 March 1999. He said “the Govern-ment will ensure that Australia's cultural objectives for the audio visual sector are taken into account in negotiating future trade agreements.”

The Government's statement of objectives for the Free Trade Agreement (FTA) negotiations with the United States, which I announced on 3 March 2003, reflected this principle. It specified that we will ensure these negotiations take account of Australia's cultural and social policy objectives, and the need for appropriate regulation and support measures to achieve these objectives in areas such as audiovisual media.

In public statements I have indicated that we will ensure that any agreement will not compromise fundamental objectives in areas like health, education, and culture and our capacity to support Australian culture and national identity, including in audio-visual media, is not undermined in the negotiations.

Trade agreements such as FTAs and the WTO provide Australian industries with a predictable and certain trading environment. This is as important to Australia's media, entertainment and arts industries as it is to other industries. Therefore, the issue is not about totally excluding them from trade agreements but of ensuring that these agreements allow appropriate flexibility to achieve our social and cultural policy objectives.

The means by which this is achieved will depend on the structure of the particular agreement. The recently concluded Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement (SAFTA) uses a “negative list” with respect to services and investment whereby a number of key obligations of those chapters apply to all sectors except where specific reservations are taken out. In the SAFTA context, therefore, Australia included a specific reservation covering “the creative arts, cultural heritage and other cultural industries including audiovisual services, entertainment services and libraries, archives, museums and other cultural services” and “broadcasting and audiovisual services”.

The General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), on the other hand, employs a “positive list” approach whereby certain key obligations apply only to services listed by WTO members. In this context, therefore, no specific exemption was required and Australia achieved its objectives by not listing audiovisual and other cultural services.

The Government will approach each trade negotiation on a case-by-case basis to ensure that the nature and coverage of disciplines is consistent with our social and cultural policy interests, as well as taking account of the trade and investment interests of the media, entertainment and arts industries.

(2) The FTA negotiations with the United States are at the stage of sharing information and perspectives on policies that are of concern to either side, and commenting on initial offers of commitments. In relation to the audiovisual sector, this has provided an opportunity for us to explain that our policy interventions are modest and targeted at addressing a range of market failures. Furthermore, we have pointed out that these interventions are not aimed at keeping out imports, and that Australia is a substantial net importer of audiovisual services and products. We have noted that our policies ensure a diversity of Australian product is available to the Australian community to enable a choice in their viewing experience.

Following this stage of the negotiations both sides will be exchanging detailed request lists setting out the improvements we are seeking in each other's offers. It is not possible to speculate at this stage on any requests the United States may make of Australia in relation to the audiovisual sector. However, Australia would need to assess carefully any US request in relation to local content requirements and media ownership in light of the Government's stated objective of ensuring the negotiations take account of Australia's cultural and social policy objectives, and the need for appropriate regulation and support measures to achieve these objectives.

At press conferences following both the second and third rounds of negotiations, the United States' Chief Negotiator, Ralph Ives, has clearly stated that the United States is not seeking to abolish either the TV local content requirements or the subsidies provided to the film and TV industry.
The Government would expect to put forward arguments similar to those it is putting forward in the FTA talks with the United States if these issues are raised in any other negotiation in the future.

(3) As described above, the Government's statement of objectives for the Free Trade Agreement negotiations with the United States, which I announced on 3 March 2003, specifies that we will ensure the negotiations take account of Australia's cultural and social policy objectives, and the need for appropriate regulation and support measures to achieve these objectives in areas such as audiovisual media.

In addition, the FTA negotiations with the US as well as other trade negotiations, provide an opportunity to examine ways in which to improve the access of our audiovisual and other services and products to other markets and the ability of our cultural sector to attract foreign investment. The Government is consulting with Australia's cultural industries to examine our priorities in this regard under the FTA negotiations with the United States and under WTO negotiations. Trade agreements such as the recently concluded SAFTA also contain provisions with regard to the protection of Intellectual Property Rights and the enforcement of those rights. We are also pursuing this issue in the WTO.
It is expected that Australia would pursue similar objectives in any future trade agreement.
